name: Stealth Mango and Tangelo
description: This threat actor targets organizations in the satellite communications, telecommunications, geospatial-imaging, and defense sectors in the United States and Southeast Asia for espionage purposes.

name: ALPHV
description:
(Palo Alto) BlackCat (aka ALPHV) is a ransomware family that surfaced in mid-November 2021 and quickly gained notoriety for its sophistication and innovation. Operating a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) business model, BlackCat was observed soliciting for affiliates in known cybercrime forums, offering to allow affiliates to leverage the ransomware and keep 80-90% of the ransom payment. The remainder would be paid to the BlackCat author.

The threat actors leveraging BlackCat, often referred to as the 'BlackCat gang,' utilize numerous tactics that are becoming increasingly commonplace in the ransomware space. Notably, they use multiple extortion techniques in some cases, including the siphoning of victim data before ransomware deployment, threats to release data if the ransom is not paid and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.

Known affiliates are:
1. Subgroup: Scattered Spider

name: ALTDOS
description: ALTDOS is a threat actor group that has targeted entities in Southeast Asia, including Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia. They have been involved in data breaches of companies in various sectors, such as real estate and retail, compromising sensitive information like customer names, bank account numbers, and transaction details. ALTDOS uses tactics like ransomware attacks, data exfiltration, and dumping data publicly or for sale on underground forums. The group has been known to demand ransom payments from victims, but also leaks data if demands are not met.

name: APT 20
description:
(Palo Alto) We’ve uncovered some new data and likely attribution regarding a series of APT watering hole attacks this past summer. Watering hole attacks are an increasingly popular component of APT campaigns, as many people are more aware of spear phishing and are less likely to open documents or click on links in unsolicited emails.  Watering hole attacks offer a much better chance of success because they involve compromising legitimate websites and installing malware intended to compromise website visitors. These are often popular websites frequented by people who work in specific industries or have political sympathies to which the actors want to gain access.
In contrast to many other APT campaigns, which tend to rely heavily on spear phishing to gain victims, “th3bug” is known for compromising legitimate websites their intended visitors are likely to frequent.  Over the summer they compromised several sites, including a well-known Uyghur website written in that native language.

This group could be related to Axiom, Group 72.

name: APT 6
description:
(Kaspersky) The FBI issued a rare bulletin admitting that a group named Advanced Persistent Threat 6 (APT6) hacked into US government computer systems as far back as 2011 and for years stole sensitive data.

The FBI alert was issued in February and went largely unnoticed. Nearly a month later, security experts are now shining a bright light on the alert and the mysterious group behind the attack.

“This is a rare alert and a little late, but one that is welcomed by all security vendors as it offers a chance to mitigate their customers and also collaborate further in what appears to be an ongoing FBI investigation,” said Deepen Desai, director of security research at the security firm Zscaler in an email to Threatpost.

Details regarding the actual attack and what government systems were infected are scant. Government officials said they knew the initial attack occurred in 2011, but are unaware of who specifically is behind the attacks.

“Given the nature of malware payload involved and the duration of this compromise being unnoticed – the scope of lateral movement inside the compromised network is very high possibly exposing all the critical systems,” Deepen said.

name: APT 7
description: APT7 engages in cyber operations where the goal is intellectual property theft, usually focusing on data and projects that make an organization competitive within its field.

name: APT-C-12
description: According to 360 TIC the actor has carried out continuous cyber espionage activities since 2011 on key units and departments of the Chinese government, military industry, scientific research, and finance. The organization focuses on information related to the nuclear industry and scientific research. The targets were mainly concentrated in mainland China...[M]ore than 670 malware samples have been collected from the group, including more than 60 malicious plugins specifically for lateral movement; more than 40 C2 domain names and IPs related to the organization have also been discovered.

name: APT-C-23
description: APT-C-23 is a threat group that has been active since at least 2014. APT-C-23 has primarily focused its operations on the Middle East, including Israeli military assets. APT-C-23 has developed mobile spyware targeting Android and iOS devices since 2017.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: APT-C-23 can collect the victim’s phone number, device information, IMSI, etc.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: APT-C-23 has masqueraded malware as legitimate applications.

techniques.name: Phishing
techniques.use: APT-C-23 sends malicious links to victims to download the masqueraded application.

name: APT-C-36
description: APT-C-36 is a suspected South America espionage group that has been active since at least 2018. The group mainly targets Colombian government institutions as well as important corporations in the financial sector, petroleum industry, and professional manufacturing.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has used ConfuserEx to obfuscate its variant of Imminent Monitor, compressed payload and RAT packages, and password protected encrypted email attachments to avoid detection.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has disguised its scheduled tasks as those used by Google.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has used a macro function to set scheduled tasks, disguised as those used by Google.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has embedded a VBScript within a malicious Word document which is executed upon the document opening.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has downloaded binary data from a specified domain after the malicious document is opened.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has prompted victims to accept macros in order to execute the subsequent payload.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has used spearphishing emails with password protected RAR attachment to avoid being detected by the email gateway.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.use: APT-C-36 has used port 4050 for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: APT-C-36 obtained and used a modified variant of Imminent Monitor.

name: APT-C-60
description: APT-C-60

name: APT1
description: APT1 is a Chinese threat group that has been attributed to the 2nd Bureau of the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) General Staff Department’s (GSD) 3rd Department, commonly known by its Military Unit Cover Designator (MUCD) as Unit 61398.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, 2nd Bureau of the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) General Staff Department’s (GSD) 3rd Department, commonly known by its Military Unit Cover Designator (MUCD) as Unit 61398

techniques.name: LSASS Memory

techniques.name: Data from Local System

techniques.name: System Service Discovery

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: APT1 used the ipconfig /all command to gather network configuration information.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery

techniques.name: Process Discovery

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell

techniques.name: Local Account

techniques.name: Local Email Collection
techniques.use: APT1 uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. GETMAIL extracts emails from archived Outlook .pst files.

techniques.name: Remote Email Collection
techniques.use: APT1 uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. MAPIGET steals email still on Exchange servers that has not yet been archived.

techniques.name: Automated Collection

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: APT1 listed connected network shares.

techniques.name: Pass the Hash
techniques.use: The APT1 group is known to have used pass the hash.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: APT1 has used RAR to compress files before moving them outside of the victim network.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT1 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT1 has sent spearphishing emails containing hyperlinks to malicious files.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: APT1 has registered hundreds of domains for use in operations.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: APT1 hijacked FQDNs associated with legitimate websites hosted by hop points.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: APT1 has created email accounts for later use in social engineering, phishing, and when registering domains.

techniques.name: Malware

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: APT1 has used various open-source tools for privilege escalation purposes.

name: APT16
description: APT16 is a China-based threat group that has launched spearphishing campaigns targeting Japanese and Taiwanese organizations.

techniques.use: APT16 has compromised otherwise legitimate sites as staging servers for second-stage payloads.

name: APT18
description: APT18 is a threat group that has operated since at least 2009 and has targeted a range of industries, including technology, manufacturing, human rights groups, government, and medical.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell

techniques.name: File Deletion

techniques.name: Valid Accounts

name: APT29
associatedGroups: Grizzly Steppe together with APT 29, Cozy Bear, The Dukes
Grizzly Steppe together with Sofacy, APT 28, Fancy Bear, Sednit
description: APT29 is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. APT29 reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the SolarWinds Compromise to the SVR; public statements included citations to APT29, Cozy Bear, and The Dukes. Industry reporting also referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm.
targetedCountries: Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE)

techniques.name: Junk Data
techniques.use: APT28 added "junk data"to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm. Each implant was given a "junk length"value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.

techniques.name: Steganography
techniques.use: During Operation Ghost, APT29 used steganography to hide the communications between the implants and their C&C servers.

techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.use: APT28 regularly deploys both publicly available (ex: Mimikatz) and custom password retrieval tools on victims.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: APT28 regularly deploys both publicly available (ex: Mimikatz) and custom password retrieval tools on victims.

techniques.name: Security Account Manager
techniques.use: APT29 has used the reg save command to save registry hives.

techniques.name: NTDS

techniques.name: LSA Secrets

techniques.name: DCSync
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used privileged accounts to replicate directory service data with domain controllers.

techniques.name: Data from Local System

techniques.name: Rootkit

techniques.name: Internet Connection Discovery

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used AdFind to enumerate remote systems.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used RDP sessions from public-facing systems to internal servers.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used administrative accounts to connect over SMB to targeted users.

techniques.name: Windows Remote Management
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used WinRM via PowerShell to execute commands and payloads on remote hosts.

techniques.name: Cloud Services
techniques.use: APT29 has leveraged compromised high-privileged on-premises accounts synced to Office 365 to move laterally into a cloud environment, including through the use of Azure AD PowerShell.

techniques.name: Data from Removable Media
techniques.use: An APT28 backdoor may collect the entire contents of an inserted USB device.
APT28 encrypted a .dll payload using RTL and a custom encryption algorithm. APT28 has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.

techniques.name: Binary Padding
techniques.use: APT29 used large size files to avoid detection by security solutions with hardcoded size limits.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: APT29 used UPX to pack files.

techniques.name: Steganography
techniques.use: During Operation Ghost, APT29 used steganography to hide payloads inside valid images.

techniques.name: HTML Smuggling

techniques.name: Data Transfer Size Limits

techniques.name: Masquerading

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: APT29 has renamed malicious DLLs with legitimate names to appear benign; they have also created an Azure AD certificate with a Common Name that matched the display name of the compromised service principal.

techniques.name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts

techniques.name: RC Scripts

techniques.name: Data from Network Shared Drive

techniques.name: Network Sniffing

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol

techniques.name: Scheduled Task

techniques.name: Keylogging

techniques.name: Process Discovery

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used cmd.exe to execute commands on remote machines.

techniques.name: Visual Basic

techniques.name: Python

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

techniques.name: Web Protocols

techniques.name: Domain Accounts

techniques.name: System Information Discovery

techniques.name: Additional Cloud Roles

techniques.name: Device Registration

techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used stolen cookies to access cloud resources and a forged duo-sid cookie to bypass MFA set on an email account.

techniques.name: Private Keys
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 obtained PKI keys, certificate files, and the private encryption key from an Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) container to decrypt corresponding SAML signing certificates.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 was able to get SUNBURST signed by SolarWinds code signing certificates by injecting the malware into the SolarWinds Orion software lifecycle.

techniques.name: Mark-of-the-Web Bypass
techniques.use: APT29 has embedded ISO images and VHDX files in HTML to evade Mark-of-the-Web.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 stole users' saved passwords from Chrome.

techniques.name: Hybrid Identity
techniques.use: APT29 has edited the Microsoft.IdentityServer.Servicehost.exe.config file to load a malicious DLL into the AD FS process, thereby enabling persistent access to any service federated with AD FS for a user with a specified User Principal Name.

techniques.name: Kerberoasting
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 obtained Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets for Active Directory Service Principle Names to crack offline.

techniques.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
techniques.use: APT28 has delivered JHUHUGIT and Koadic by executing PowerShell commands through DDE in Word documents.

techniques.name: Archive Collected Data
techniques.use: APT28 used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used 7-Zip to compress stolen emails into password-protected archives prior to exfltration; APT29 also compressed text files into zipped archives.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used the service control manager on a remote system to disable services associated with security monitoring products.

techniques.name: Disable Windows Event Logging
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29, used AUDITPOL to prevent the collection of audit logs.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used netsh to configure firewall rules that limited certain UDP outbound packets.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Cloud Logs
techniques.use: APT29 has disabled Purview Audit on targeted accounts prior to stealing emails from Microsoft 365 tenants.

techniques.name: Hidden Files and Directories
techniques.use: APT28 has saved files with hidden file attributes.

techniques.name: Hidden Window
techniques.use: APT28 has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal PowerShell windows.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT29 has used spearphishing emails with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT29 has used spearphishing with a link to trick victims into clicking on a link to a zip file containing malicious files.

techniques.name: Spearphishing via Service
techniques.use: APT29 has used the legitimate mailing service Constant Contact to send phishing e-mails.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Web Service
techniques.use: APT28 can exfiltrate data over Google Drive.

techniques.name: Dynamic Resolution
techniques.use: APT29 has used Dynamic DNS providers for their malware C2 infrastructure.

techniques.name: Encrypted Channel
techniques.use: APT29 has used multiple layers of encryption within malware to protect C2 communication.

techniques.name: Symmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: APT28 installed a Delphi backdoor that used a custom algorithm for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 acquired C2 domains, sometimes through resellers.

techniques.name: Virtual Private Server
techniques.use: APT28 hosted phishing domains on free services for brief periods of time during campaigns.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: APT29 has registered algorithmically generated Twitter handles that are used for C2 by malware, such as HAMMERTOSS. APT29 has also used legitimate web services such as Dropbox and Constant Contact in their operations.
APT28 compromised Ubiquiti network devices to act as collection devices for credentials compromised via phishing webpages.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 compromised domains to use for C2.

techniques.name: Social Media Accounts
techniques.use: For Operation Ghost, APT29 registered Twitter accounts to host C2 nodes.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: APT29 has compromised email accounts to further enable phishing campaigns and taken control of dormant accounts.

techniques.name: Cloud Accounts
techniques.use: APT29 has used residential proxies, including Azure Virtual Machines, to obfuscate their access to victim environments.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: APT29 has used unique malware in many of their operations.

techniques.name: Digital Certificates
techniques.use: APT29 has created self-signed digital certificates to enable mutual TLS authentication for malware.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: APT29 has obtained and used a variety of tools including Mimikatz, SDelete, Tor, meek, and Cobalt Strike.

techniques.name: Hide Infrastructure
techniques.use: APT29 uses compromised residential endpoints, typically within the same ISP IP address range, as proxies to hide the true source of C2 traffic.

techniques.name: Vulnerability Scanning
techniques.use: APT29 has conducted widespread scanning of target environments to identify vulnerabilities for exploit.

techniques.name: Phishing for Information
techniques.use: APT28 has used spearphishing to compromise credentials.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT28 has conducted credential phishing campaigns with embedded links to attacker-controlled domains.

techniques.name: Web Cookies
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 bypassed MFA set on OWA accounts by generating a cookie value from a previously stolen secret key.

techniques.name: SAML Tokens
techniques.use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 created tokens using compromised SAML signing certificates.

techniques.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Request Generation
techniques.use: APT29 has used repeated MFA requests to gain access to victim accounts.

techniques.name: Steal or Forge Authentication Certificates
techniques.use: APT29 has abused misconfigured AD CS certificate templates to impersonate admin users and create additional authentication certificates.

techniques.name: Cloud Administration Command
techniques.use: APT29 has used Azure Run Command and Azure Admin-on-Behalf-of (AOBO) to execute code on virtual machines.

name: APT32
description: APT32 is a suspected Vietnam-based threat group that has been active since at least 2014. The group has targeted multiple private sector industries as well as foreign governments, dissidents, and journalists with a strong focus on Southeast Asian countries like Vietnam, the Philippines, Laos, and Cambodia. They have extensively used strategic web compromises to compromise victims.

techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.use: APT32 used GetPassword_x64 to harvest credentials.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: APT32 used Mimikatz and customized versions of Windows Credential Dumper to harvest credentials.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor can query the Windows Registry to gather system information.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: APT32 used the ipconfig /all command to gather the IP address from the system.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: APT32 has enumerated DC servers using the command net group "Domain Controllers"/domain. The group has also used the ping command.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: APT32 used Net to use Windows' hidden network shares to copy their tools to remote machines for execution.

APT32 has performed code obfuscation, including encoding payloads using Base64 and using a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC). APT32 also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.

techniques.name: Binary Padding
techniques.use: APT32 includes garbage code to mislead anti-malware software and researchers.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: APT32 has used the Invoke-Obfuscation framework to obfuscate their PowerShell.

techniques.name: Fileless Storage
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor has stored its configuration in a registry key.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: APT32 collected the victim's username and executed the whoami command on the victim's machine. APT32 executed shellcode to collect the username on the victim's machine.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.use: APT32 has disguised a Cobalt Strike beacon as a Flash Installer.

techniques.name: Rename System Utilities
techniques.use: APT32 has moved and renamed pubprn.vbs to a .txt file to avoid detection.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: APT32 has used hidden or non-printing characters to help masquerade service names, such as appending a Unicode no-break space character to a legitimate service name. APT32 has also impersonated the legitimate Flash installer file name "install_flashplayer.exe".

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: APT32 has renamed a NetCat binary to kb-10233.exe to masquerade as a Windows update. APT32 has also renamed a Cobalt Strike beacon payload to install_flashplayers.exe.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor has exfiltrated data using the already opened channel with its C&C server.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: APT32 performed network scanning on the network to search for open ports, services, OS finger-printing, and other vulnerabilities.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: APT32 used WMI to deploy their tools on remote machines and to gather information about the Outlook process.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor can exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: APT32 used the netstat -anpo tcp command to display TCP connections on the victim's machine.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: APT32 has used scheduled tasks to persist on victim systems.

techniques.name: Process Injection
techniques.use: APT32 malware has injected a Cobalt Strike beacon into Rundll32.exe.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: APT32 has abused the PasswordChangeNotify to monitor for and capture account password changes.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.use: APT32 has used COM scriptlets to download Cobalt Strike beacons.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: APT32 has used PowerShell-based tools, PowerShell one-liners, and shellcode loaders for execution.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: APT32 has used cmd.exe for execution.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: APT32 has used macros, COM scriptlets, and VBS scripts.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: APT32 has used JavaScript for drive-by downloads and C2 communications.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: APT32 has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.

techniques.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
techniques.use: APT32 has cleared select event log entries.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: APT32's macOS backdoor can receive a "delete"command.

techniques.name: Timestomp
techniques.use: APT32 has used scheduled task raw XML with a backdated timestamp of June 2, 2016. The group has also set the creation time of the files dropped by the second stage of the exploit to match the creation time of kernel32.dll. Additionally, APT32 has used a random value to modify the timestamp of the file storing the clientID.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: APT32 has used JavaScript that communicates over HTTP or HTTPS to attacker controlled domains to download additional frameworks. The group has also used downloaded encrypted payloads over HTTP.

techniques.name: Mail Protocols
techniques.use: APT32 has used email for C2 via an Office macro.

techniques.name: Software Deployment Tools
techniques.use: APT32 compromised McAfee ePO to move laterally by distributing malware as a software deployment task.

techniques.name: Local Accounts
techniques.use: APT32 has used legitimate local admin account credentials.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: APT32 has collected the OS version and computer name from victims. One of the group's backdoors can also query the Windows Registry to gather system information, and another macOS backdoor performs a fingerprint of the machine on its first connection to the C&C server. APT32 executed shellcode to identify the name of the infected host.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor possesses the capability to list files and directories on a machine.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: APT32 enumerated administrative users using the commands net localgroup administrators.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: APT32 has used Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive to host malicious downloads.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT32 has added JavaScript to victim websites to download additional frameworks that profile and compromise website visitors.

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor has modified the Windows Registry to store the backdoor's configuration.

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: APT32 used the net view command to show all shares available, including the administrative shares such as C$ and ADMIN$.

techniques.name: Office Application Startup
techniques.use: APT32 have replaced Microsoft Outlook's VbaProject.OTM file to install a backdoor macro for persistence.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: APT32 has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: APT32 has used RTF document that includes an exploit to execute malicious code. (CVE-2017-11882)

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: APT32 has lured targets to download a Cobalt Strike beacon by including a malicious link within spearphishing emails.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: APT32 has attempted to lure users to execute a malicious dropper delivered via a spearphishing attachment.

techniques.name: PubPrn
techniques.use: APT32 has used PubPrn.vbs within execution scripts to execute malware, possibly bypassing defenses.

techniques.name: Mshta
techniques.use: APT32 has used mshta.exe for code execution.

techniques.name: Regsvr32
techniques.use: APT32 created a Scheduled Task/Job that used regsvr32.exe to execute a COM scriptlet that dynamically downloaded a backdoor and injected it into memory. The group has also used regsvr32 to run their backdoor.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: APT32 malware has used rundll32.exe to execute an initial infection process.

techniques.name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
techniques.use: APT32's macOS backdoor changes the permission of the file it wants to execute to 755.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: APT32 has used Web shells to maintain access to victim websites.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: APT32 modified Windows Services to ensure PowerShell scripts were loaded on the system. APT32 also creates a Windows service to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: APT32 established persistence using Registry Run keys, both to execute PowerShell and VBS scripts as well as to execute their backdoor directly.

techniques.name: Pass the Hash
techniques.use: APT32 has used pass the hash for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Pass the Ticket
techniques.use: APT32 successfully gained remote access by using pass the ticket.

techniques.name: Credentials in Registry
techniques.use: APT32 used Outlook Credential Dumper to harvest credentials stored in Windows registry.

techniques.name: Archive Collected Data
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor has used LZMA compression and RC4 encryption before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Hidden Files and Directories
techniques.use: APT32's macOS backdoor hides the clientID file via a chflags function.

techniques.name: Hidden Window
techniques.use: APT32 has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal PowerShell windows.

techniques.name: NTFS File Attributes
techniques.use: APT32 used NTFS alternate data streams to hide their payloads.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT32 has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT32 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.

techniques.name: Service Execution
techniques.use: APT32's backdoor has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT32 has deployed tools after moving laterally using administrative accounts.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.use: An APT32 backdoor can use HTTP over a non-standard TCP port (e.g 14146) which is specified in the backdoor configuration.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: APT32 ran legitimately-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which load a malicious DLL. The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable (AcroTranscoder).

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: APT32 has set up and operated websites to gather information and deliver malware.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: APT32 has set up Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive to host malicious downloads.

techniques.name: Social Media Accounts
techniques.use: APT32 has set up Facebook pages in tandem with fake websites.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: APT32 has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz and Cobalt Strike, and a variety of other open-source tools from GitHub.

techniques.name: Gather Victim Identity Information
techniques.use: APT32 has conducted targeted surveillance against activists and bloggers.

techniques.name: Email Addresses
techniques.use: APT32 has collected e-mail addresses for activists and bloggers in order to target them with spyware.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT32 has used malicious links to direct users to web pages designed to harvest credentials.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: APT32 has hosted malicious payloads in Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive for use during targeting.

techniques.name: Drive-by Target
techniques.use: APT32 has stood up websites containing numerous articles and content scraped from the Internet to make them appear legitimate, but some of these pages include malicious JavaScript to profile the potential victim or infect them via a fake software update.

name: APT33
description: APT33 is a suspected Iranian threat group that has carried out operations since at least 2013. The group has targeted organizations across multiple industries in the United States, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea, with a particular interest in the aviation and energy sectors.

techniques.name: Screen Capture
techniques.use: APT33 utilize backdoors capable of capturing screenshots once installed on a system.

techniques.name: Scripting
techniques.use: APT33 utilized PowerShell scripts to establish command and control and install files for execution.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT33 sent spear phishing emails containing links to HTML application files, which were embedded with malicious code.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne, Mimikatz, and ProcDump to dump credentials.

techniques.name: LSA Secrets
techniques.use: APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.

techniques.name: Cached Domain Credentials
techniques.use: APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.
APT33 has used base64 to encode payloads.

techniques.name: Network Sniffing
techniques.use: APT33 has used SniffPass to collect credentials by sniffing network traffic.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: APT33 has used FTP to exfiltrate files (separately from the C2 channel).

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: APT33 has created a scheduled task to execute a .vbe file multiple times a day.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: APT33 has utilized PowerShell to download files from the C2 server and run various scripts.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: APT33 has used VBScript to initiate the delivery of payloads.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: APT33 has used a publicly available exploit for CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges on a local system.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: APT33 has used HTTP for command and control.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: APT33 has used valid accounts for initial access and privilege escalation.

techniques.name: Cloud Accounts
techniques.use: APT33 has used compromised Office 365 accounts in tandem with Ruler in an attempt to gain control of endpoints.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT33 has downloaded additional files and programs from its C2 server.

techniques.name: Password Spraying
techniques.use: APT33 has used password spraying to gain access to target systems.

techniques.name: Standard Encoding
techniques.use: APT33 has used base64 to encode command and control traffic.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: APT33 has attempted to exploit a known vulnerability in WinRAR (CVE-2018-20250), and attempted to gain remote code execution via a security bypass vulnerability (CVE-2017-11774).

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: APT33 has lured users to click links to malicious HTML applications delivered via spearphishing emails.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: APT33 has used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malware.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
techniques.use: APT33 has attempted to use WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence on compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: APT33 has deployed a tool known as DarkComet to the Startup folder of a victim, and used Registry run keys to gain persistence.

techniques.name: Credentials In Files
techniques.use: APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.

techniques.name: Group Policy Preferences
techniques.use: APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like Gpppassword to gather credentials.

techniques.name: Credentials from Password Stores
techniques.use: APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne to gather credentials.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: APT33 has used WinRAR to compress data prior to exfil.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT33 has sent spearphishing e-mails with archive attachments.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT33 has sent spearphishing emails containing links to .hta files.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.use: APT33 has used HTTP over TCP ports 808 and 880 for command and control.

techniques.name: Symmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: APT33 has used AES for encryption of command and control traffic.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: APT33 has obtained and leveraged publicly-available tools for early intrusion activities.

name: APT37
description: APT37 is a North Korean state-sponsored cyber espionage group that has been active since at least 2012. The group has targeted victims primarily in South Korea, but also in Japan, Vietnam, Russia, Nepal, China, India, Romania, Kuwait, and other parts of the Middle East. APT37 has also been linked to the following campaigns between 2016-2018: Operation Daybreak, Operation Erebus, Golden Time, Evil New Year, Are you Happy?, FreeMilk, North Korean Human Rights, and Evil New Year 2018.North Korean group definitions are known to have significant overlap, and some security researchers report all North Korean state-sponsored cyber activity under the name Lazarus Group instead of tracking clusters or subgroups.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: APT37 has collected data from victims' local systems.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.use: APT37 obfuscates strings and payloads.

techniques.name: Steganography
techniques.use: APT37 uses steganography to send images to users that are embedded with shellcode.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: APT37 identifies the victim username.

techniques.name: Invalid Code Signature
techniques.use: APT37 has signed its malware with an invalid digital certificates listed as "Tencent Technology (Shenzhen) Company Limited."

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: APT37 has created scheduled tasks to run malicious scripts on a compromised host.

techniques.name: Process Injection
techniques.use: APT37 injects its malware variant, ROKRAT, into the cmd.exe process.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: APT37's Freenki malware lists running processes using the Microsoft Windows API.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.use: APT37 has used Ruby scripts to execute payloads.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: APT37 has used the command-line interface.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: APT37 executes shellcode and a VBA script to decode Base64 strings.

techniques.name: Python
techniques.use: APT37 has used Python scripts to execute payloads.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: APT37 uses HTTPS to conceal C2 communications.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: APT37 collects the computer name, the BIOS model, and execution path.

techniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
techniques.use: APT37 leverages social networking sites and cloud platforms (AOL, Twitter, Yandex, Mediafire, pCloud, Dropbox, and Box) for C2.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT37 has downloaded second stage malware from compromised websites.

techniques.name: Native API
techniques.use: APT37 leverages the Windows API calls: VirtualAlloc(), WriteProcessMemory(), and CreateRemoteThread() for process injection.

techniques.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
techniques.use: APT37 has a Bluetooth device harvester, which uses Windows Bluetooth APIs to find information on connected Bluetooth devices.

techniques.name: Audio Capture
techniques.use: APT37 has used an audio capturing utility known as SOUNDWAVE that captures microphone input.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: APT37 has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware. The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims. As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: APT37 has used exploits for Flash Player (CVE-2016-4117, CVE-2018-4878), Word (CVE-2017-0199), Internet Explorer (CVE-2020-1380 and CVE-2020-26411), and Microsoft Edge (CVE-2021-26411) for execution.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: APT37 has sent spearphishing attachments attempting to get a user to open them.

techniques.name: System Shutdown/Reboot
techniques.use: APT37 has used malware that will issue the command shutdown /r /t 1 to reboot a system after wiping its MBR.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: APT37's has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\.

techniques.name: Bypass User Account Control
techniques.use: APT37 has a function in the initial dropper to bypass Windows UAC in order to execute the next payload with higher privileges.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: APT37 has used a credential stealer known as ZUMKONG that can harvest usernames and passwords stored in browsers.

techniques.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
techniques.use: APT37 has used Windows DDE for execution of commands and a malicious VBS.

techniques.name: Disk Structure Wipe
techniques.use: APT37 has access to destructive malware that is capable of overwriting a machine's Master Boot Record (MBR).

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT37 delivers malware using spearphishing emails with malicious HWP attachments.

name: APT39
description: APT39 is one of several names for cyber espionage activity conducted by the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS) through the front company Rana Intelligence Computing since at least 2014. APT39 has primarily targeted the travel, hospitality, academic, and telecommunications industries in Iran and across Asia, Africa, Europe, and North America to track individuals and entities considered to be a threat by the MOIS.

techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.use: APT39 has used different versions of Mimikatz to obtain credentials.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: APT39 has used Mimikatz, Windows Credential Editor and ProcDump to dump credentials.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: APT39 has used various tools to steal files from the compromised host.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: APT39 has used various strains of malware to query the Registry.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: APT39 has used NBTscan and custom tools to discover remote systems.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: APT39 has been seen using RDP for lateral movement and persistence, in some cases employing the rdpwinst tool for mangement of multiple sessions.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: APT39 has used SMB for lateral movement.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: APT39 used secure shell (SSH) to move laterally among their targets.
APT39 has used malware to drop encrypted CAB files.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: APT39 has packed tools with UPX, and has repacked a modified version of Mimikatz to thwart anti-virus detection.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: APT39 has used malware disguised as Mozilla Firefox and a tool named mfevtpse.exe to proxy C2 communications, closely mimicking a legitimate McAfee file mfevtps.exe.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: APT39 has exfiltrated stolen victim data through C2 communications.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: APT39 has used CrackMapExec and a custom port scanner known as BLUETORCH for network scanning.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task

techniques.name: Input Capture

techniques.name: Keylogging

APT39 has utilized AutoIt malware scripts embedded in Microsoft Office documents or malicious links.

techniques.name: Visual Basic

techniques.name: Python

techniques.name: File Deletion

techniques.name: Web Protocols

techniques.name: DNS

techniques.name: Local Data Staging

techniques.name: Valid Accounts

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery

techniques.name: Internal Proxy
techniques.use: APT39 used custom tools to create SOCK5 and custom protocol proxies between infected hosts.

techniques.name: External Proxy
techniques.use: APT39 has used various tools to proxy C2 communications.

techniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
techniques.use: APT39 has communicated with C2 through files uploaded to and downloaded from DropBox.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT39 has downloaded tools to compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.use: APT39 has used Ncrack to reveal credentials.

techniques.name: Screen Capture

techniques.name: Clipboard Data

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: APT39 has used the post exploitation tool CrackMapExec to enumerate network shares.

techniques.name: Local Account

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application

techniques.name: BITS Jobs
techniques.use: APT39 has used the BITS protocol to exfiltrate stolen data from a compromised host.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: APT39 has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious link.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: APT39 has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious attachment.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: APT39 has installed ANTAK and ASPXSPY web shells.

techniques.name: AppInit DLLs
techniques.use: APT39 has used malware to set LoadAppInit_DLLs in the Registry key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows in order to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: APT39 has maintained persistence using the startup folder.

techniques.name: Shortcut Modification
techniques.use: APT39 has modified LNK shortcuts.

techniques.name: Code Signing Policy Modification
techniques.use: APT39 has used malware to turn off the RequireSigned feature which ensures only signed DLLs can be run on Windows.

techniques.name: Credentials from Password Stores
techniques.use: APT39 has used the Smartftp Password Decryptor tool to decrypt FTP passwords.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: APT39 has used WinRAR and 7-Zip to compress an archive stolen data.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT39 leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT39 leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious links to initially compromise victims.

techniques.name: Service Execution
techniques.use: APT39 has used post-exploitation tools including RemCom and the Non-sucking Service Manager (NSSM) to execute processes.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: APT39 has modified and used customized versions of publicly-available tools like PLINK and Mimikatz.

name: AVIVORE
description:
(Context) Until now, most prominent supply chain intrusions have been 'vertical'; initial victims are typically Managed Services Providers or software vendors leveraged by attackers to move up or down the supply chain. However, since summer 2018, Context Information Security has been investigating a series of incidents targeting UK and European Aerospace and Defence that are best described as 'horizontal'. Advanced attackers have been leveraging direct connectivity between suppliers and partners who are integrated into each other’s value chains. We have been tracking this activity under the codename AVIVORE.

Affected victims include large multinational firms (Primes) and smaller engineering or consultancy firms within their supply chain (Secondaries). Context has worked closely with victims, the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), security organisations, and law enforcement agencies across Europe to reduce impact and prevent further compromise.

name: Actor240524
description: Actor240524 is a newly identified APT group that targeted Azerbaijani and Israeli diplomats through spear-phishing emails to steal sensitive data. The group employs a Trojan program known as ABCloader and ABCsync, demonstrating capabilities to steal secrets and modify file data. Their operations appear to focus on undermining the cooperative relationship between Azerbaijan and Israel. Actor240524 utilizes various countermeasures to obscure their attack tactics and techniques.

name: Adrastea
description: Adrastea is a threat actor who has been active on cybercrime forums, claiming to have breached organizations like MBDA and offering stolen data for sale. They describe themselves as a group of independent cybersecurity experts and researchers. Adrastea has been linked to ransomware operations, data leak platforms, and network access groups. The actor has been known to exploit critical vulnerabilities in target organizations' infrastructure to gain access to sensitive data.

name: AeroBlade
description:
(BlackBerry) BlackBerry has uncovered a previously unknown threat actor targeting an aerospace organization in the United States, with the apparent goal of conducting commercial and competitive cyber espionage. The BlackBerry Threat Research and Intelligence team is tracking this threat actor as AeroBlade. The actor used spear-phishing as a delivery mechanism: A weaponized document, sent as an email attachment, contains an embedded remote template injection technique and a malicious VBA macro code, to deliver the next stage to the final payload execution.

Evidence suggests that the attacker’s network infrastructure and weaponization became operational around September 2022. BlackBerry assesses with medium to high confidence that the offensive phase of the attack occurred in July 2023. The attacker improved its toolset during that time, making it stealthier, while the network infrastructure remained the same.

Given the final payload functionality and the subject of the attack, BlackBerry assesses with medium to high confidence that the goal of this attack was commercial cyber espionage.

name: Aggah
description:
(Palo Alto) In March 2019, Unit 42 began looking into an attack campaign that appeared to be primarily focused on organizations within a Middle Eastern country. Further analysis revealed that this activity is likely part of a much larger campaign impacting not only that region but also the United States, and throughout Europe and Asia.

Our analysis of the delivery document revealed it was built to load a malicious macro-enabled document from a remote server via Template Injection. These macros use BlogSpot posts to obtain a script that uses multiple Pastebin pastes to download additional scripts, which ultimately result in the final payload being RevengeRAT configured with a duckdns[.]org domain for C2. During our research, we found several related delivery documents that followed the same process to ultimately install RevengeRAT hosted on Pastebin, which suggests the actors used these TTPs throughout their attack campaign.

Initially, we believed this activity to be potentially associated with the Gorgon Group. Our hypothesis was based on the high level TTPs including the use of RevengeRAT. However, Unit 42 has not yet identified direct overlaps with other high-fidelity Gorgon Group indicators. Based on this, we are not able to assign this activity to the Gorgon group with an appropriate level of certainty.

In light of that, Unit 42 refers to the activity described in this blog as the Aggah Campaign based on the actor’s alias “hagga”, which was used to split data sent to the RevengeRAT C2 server and was the name of one of the Pastebin accounts used to host the RevengeRAT payloads.

name: Agrius
description: (SentinelLabs) A new threat actor SentinelLabs track as Agrius was observed operating in Israel beginning in 2020. An analysis of what at first sight appeared to be a ransomware attack revealed new variants of wipers that were deployed in a set of destructive attacks against Israeli targets. The operators behind the attacks intentionally masked their activity as ransomware attacks.

name: Akira
description: Akira is a ransomware variant and ransomware deployment entity active since at least March 2023. Akira uses compromised credentials to access single-factor external access mechanisms such as VPNs for initial access, then various publicly-available tools and techniques for lateral movement. Akira operations are associated with "double extortion"ransomware activity, where data is exfiltrated from victim environments prior to encryption, with threats to publish files if a ransom is not paid. Technical analysis of Akira ransomware indicates multiple overlaps with and similarities to Conti malware.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Akira uses software such as Advanced IP Scanner and MASSCAN to identify remote hosts within victim networks.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: Akira uses valid account information to remotely access victim networks, such as VPN credentials.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: Akira uses compromised VPN accounts for initial access to victim networks.

techniques.name: Sharepoint
techniques.use: Akira has accessed and downloaded information stored in SharePoint instances as part of data gathering and exfiltration activity.

techniques.name: Remote Access Software
techniques.use: Akira uses legitimate utilities such as AnyDesk and PuTTy for maintaining remote access to victim environments.

techniques.name: Domain Trust Discovery
techniques.use: Akira uses the built-in Nltest utility or tools such as AdFind to enumerate Active Directory trusts in victim environments.

techniques.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
techniques.use: Akira encrypts files in victim environments as part of ransomware operations.

techniques.name: Account Access Removal
techniques.use: Akira deletes administrator accounts in victim networks prior to encryption.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: Akira uses utilities such as WinRAR to archive data prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: Akira will exfiltrate victim data using applications such as Rclone.

techniques.name: Financial Theft
techniques.use: Akira engages in double-extortion ransomware, exfiltrating files then encrypting them, in order to prompt victims to pay a ransom.

name: Alpha Spider
description: ALPHA SPIDER is a threat actor known for developing and operating the Alphv ransomware as a service. They have been observed using novel offensive techniques, such as exploiting software vulnerabilities and leveraging legitimate administration tools for malicious activities. ALPHA SPIDER affiliates have demonstrated persistence in exfiltrating data and have shown the ability to bypass security measures like DNS-based filtering and multifactor authentication. Despite lacking specific operational security measures, defenders have opportunities to detect and respond to ALPHA SPIDER's operations effectively.

name: Altahrea Team
description: Altahrea Team is a pro-Iranian hacking group that has been active since at least 2020. The group has claimed responsibility for a number of cyberattacks, including DDoS attacks against Israeli websites, a hack of the Israel Airports Authority website, and a cyberattack on the Orot Yosef power plant in Israel.

name: Anchor Panda
description:
(CrowdStrike) Anchor Panda is an adversary that CrowdStrike has tracked extensively over the last year targeting both civilian and military maritime operations in the green/brown water regions primarily in the area of operations of the South Sea Fleet of the PLA Navy. In addition to maritime operations in this region, Anchor Panda also heavily targeted western companies in the US, Germany, Sweden, the UK, and Australia, and other countries involved in maritime satellite systems, aerospace companies, and defense contractors.

Not surprisingly, embassies and diplomatic missions in the region, foreign intelligence services, and foreign governments with space programs were also targeted.

name: Anonymous Sudan
description: Since January 23, 2023, a threat actor identifying as "Anonymous Sudan"has been conducting denial of service (DDoS) attacks against multiple organizations in Sweden. This group claims to be "hacktivists,"politically motivated hackers from Sudan. According to Truesec’s report, the threat actor has nothing to do with the online activists collectively known as Anonymous.

name: Antlion
description:
(Symantec) Antlion is believed to have been involved in espionage activities since at least 2011, and this recent activity shows that it is still an actor to be aware of more than 10 years after it first appeared.

The length of time that Antlion was able to spend on victim networks is notable, with the group able to spend several months on victim networks, affording plenty of time to seek out and exfiltrate potentially sensitive information from infected organizations. The targeting of Taiwan is perhaps unsurprising given we know Chinese state-backed groups tend to be interested in organizations in that region.

name: Aoqin Dragon
description: Aoqin Dragon is a suspected Chinese cyber espionage threat group that has been active since at least 2013. Aoqin Dragon has primarily targeted government, education, and telecommunication organizations in Australia, Cambodia, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Vietnam. Security researchers noted a potential association between Aoqin Dragon and UNC94, based on malware, infrastructure, and targets.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has used the Themida packer to obfuscate malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has used fake icons including antivirus and external drives to disguise malicious payloads.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has run scripts to identify file formats including Microsoft Word.

techniques.name: Replication Through Removable Media
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has used a dropper that employs a worm infection strategy using a removable device to breach a secure network environment.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has exploited CVE-2012-0158 and CVE-2010-3333 for execution against targeted systems.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has lured victims into opening weaponized documents, fake external drives, and fake antivirus to execute malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has spread malware in target networks by copying modules to folders masquerading as removable devices.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon has used custom malware, including Mongall and Heyoka Backdoor, in their operations.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Aoqin Dragon obtained the Heyoka open source exfiltration tool and subsequently modified it for their operations.

name: AppMilad
description: AppMilad is an Iranian hacking group that has been identified as the source of a spyware campaign called RatMilad. This spyware is designed to silently infiltrate victims' devices and gather personal and corporate information, including private communications and photos. The group has been distributing the spyware through fake apps and targeting primarily Middle Eastern enterprises.

name: Aslan Neferler Tim
description: Turkish nationalist hacktivist group that has been active for roughly one year. According to Domaintools, the group’s site has been registered since December 2015, with an active Twitter account since January 2016. The group carries out distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and defacements against the sites of news organizations and governments perceived to be critical of Turkey’s policies or leadership, and purports to act in defense of Islam

name: AtlasCross
description:
(NSFOCUS) After an in-depth study of the attack process, NSFOCUS Security Labs found that this APT attacker is quite different from known attacker characteristics in terms of execution flow, attack technology stack, attack tools, implementation details, attack objectives, behavior tendency and other main attribution indicators. The technical level and cautious attitude shown by this attacker during this activity are also worthy of attention.

Therefore, NSFOCUS Security Labs identified the orchestrator of this event as a new attacker and named it AtlasCross.

NSFOCUS Security Labs validated the high-level threat attributes of AtlasCross in terms of development technology and attack strategy through an in-depth analysis of its attack metrics. At this current stage, AtlasCross has a relatively limited scope of activity, primarily focusing on targeted attacks against specific hosts within a network domain. However, the attack processes they employ are highly robust and mature. NSFOCUS Security Labs deduce that this attacker is highly likely to deploy this attack process into larger-scale network attack operations.

The organizational origin of the AtlasCross attacker cannot be determined.

name: Attor
description: Adversary group targeting diplomatic missions and governmental organisations.

name: Awaken Likho
description: Awaken Likho is an APT group that has targeted Russian government agencies and industrial enterprises, employing techniques such as information gathering via search engines and using MeshCentral for remote access. The group has been active since at least December 2021 and has ramped up its activities following the Russo-Ukrainian conflict. Recent reports indicate that they are focusing on espionage against critical infrastructure in the defense and energy sectors. Analysis of their malware reveals a new version that is still in development, suggesting ongoing operational capabilities.

name: Ayyıldız Tim
description: Ayyıldız (Crescent and Star) Tim is a nationalist hacking group founded in 2002. It performs defacements and DDoS attacks against the websites of governments that it considers to be repressing Muslim minorities or engaged in Islamophobic policies.

name: AzzaSec
description: AzzaSec is a hacktivist group that originated in Italy. Known for their pro-Palestine stance, they have been involved in various cyberattacks targeting Israel and pro-Israel countries. Additionally, AzzaSec has engaged in ransomware activities and has been known to collaborate with other cybercriminal groups.

name: BAMBOO SPIDER
description: Crowdstrike tracks the developer of Panda Zeus as BAMBOO SPIDER

name: BANISHED KITTEN
description: BANISHED KITTEN is an Iranian state-nexus adversary active since at least 2008. While the adversary’s most prominent activity is the July and September 2022 disruptive attacks targeting Albanian government infrastructure and the use of the HomelandJustice persona to leak stolen data, BANISHED KITTEN has likely targeted dissidents using the AllinOneNeo malware family.

name: BITTER
description: BITTER is a suspected South Asian cyber espionage threat group that has been active since at least 2013. BITTER has targeted government, energy, and engineering organizations in Pakistan, China, Bangladesh, and Saudi Arabia.

techniques.use: BITTER has used a RAR SFX dropper to deliver malware.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: BITTER has disguised malware as a Windows Security update service.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: BITTER has used scheduled tasks for persistence and execution.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: BITTER has exploited CVE-2021-1732 for privilege escalation.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: BITTER has used HTTP POST requests for C2.

techniques.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
techniques.use: BITTER has used TCP for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: BITTER has downloaded additional malware and tools onto a compromised host.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: BITTER has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerabilities CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2018-0798, and CVE-2018-0802.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: BITTER has attempted to lure victims into opening malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing.

techniques.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
techniques.use: BITTER has executed OLE objects using Microsoft Equation Editor to download and run malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: BITTER has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious RTF document or Excel spreadsheet.

techniques.name: Dynamic Resolution
techniques.use: BITTER has used DDNS for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Encrypted Channel
techniques.use: BITTER has encrypted their C2 communications.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: BITTER has registered a variety of domains to host malicious payloads and for C2.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: BITTER has obtained tools such as PuTTY for use in their operations.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: BITTER has registered domains to stage payloads.

techniques.name: Phishing
techniques.use: BITTER has delivered malicious applications to victims via shortened URLs distributed through SMS, WhatsApp, and various social media platforms.

name: BOSON SPIDER
description: BOSON SPIDER is a cyber criminal group, which was first identified in 2015, recently and inexplicably went dark in the spring of 2016, appears to be a tightly knit group operating out of Eastern Europe. They have used a variety of distribution mechanisms such as the infamous (and now defunct) angler exploit kit, and obfuscated JavaScript to reduce the detection by antivirus solutions.

name: BRONZE BUTLER
description: BRONZE BUTLER is a cyber espionage group with likely Chinese origins that has been active since at least 2008. The group primarily targets Japanese organizations, particularly those in government, biotechnology, electronics manufacturing, and industrial chemistry.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, National University of Defense and Technology

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools (such as Mimikatz and WCE) to perform credential dumping.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from local systems.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used TROJ_GETVERSION to discover system services.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER typically use ping and Net to enumerate systems.

techniques.name: Binary Padding
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER downloader code has included "0"characters at the end of the file to inflate the file size in a likely attempt to evade anti-virus detection.

techniques.name: Steganography
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used steganography in multiple operations to conceal malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has masked executables with document file icons including Word and Adobe PDF.

techniques.name: Right-to-Left Override
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used Right-to-Left Override to deceive victims into executing several strains of malware.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has given malware the same name as an existing file on the file share server to cause users to unwittingly launch and install the malware on additional systems.

techniques.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from file shares.

techniques.name: At
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used at to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used schtasks to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used PowerShell for execution.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used batch scripts and the command-line interface for execution.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used VBS and VBE scripts for execution.

techniques.name: Python
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has made use of Python-based remote access tools.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: The BRONZE BUTLER uploader or malware the uploader uses command to delete the RAR archives after they have been exfiltrated.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER malware has used HTTP for C2.

techniques.name: Taint Shared Content
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has placed malware on file shares and given it the same name as legitimate documents on the share.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has collected a list of files from the victim and uploaded it to its C2 server, and then created a new list of specific files to steal.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used net user /domain to identify account information.

techniques.name: Dead Drop Resolver
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER's MSGET downloader uses a dead drop resolver to access malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools to download files, including DGet (a similar tool to wget).

techniques.name: Screen Capture
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool to capture screenshots.

techniques.name: System Time Discovery
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used net time to check the local time on a target system.

techniques.name: Standard Encoding
techniques.use: Several BRONZE BUTLER tools encode data with base64 when posting it to a C2 server.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER downloads encoded payloads and decodes them on the victim.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerabilities CVE-2014-4114, CVE-2018-0802, and CVE-2018-0798 for execution.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

techniques.name: Software Discovery
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used tools to enumerate software installed on an infected host.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used a batch script that adds a Registry Run key to establish malware persistence.

techniques.name: Bypass User Account Control
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used a Windows 10 specific tool and xxmm to bypass UAC for privilege escalation.

techniques.name: Pass the Ticket
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has created forged Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) and Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets to maintain administrative access.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has compressed data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has incorporated code into several tools that attempts to terminate anti-virus processes.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to infect victims.

techniques.name: Symmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used RC4 encryption (for Datper malware) and AES (for xxmm malware) to obfuscate HTTP traffic. BRONZE BUTLER has also used a tool called RarStar that encodes data with a custom XOR algorithm when posting it to a C2 server.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has used legitimate applications to side-load malicious DLLs.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: BRONZE BUTLER has obtained and used open-source tools such as Mimikatz, gsecdump, and Windows Credential Editor.

name: BRONZE SPIRAL
description:
In December 2020, the IT management software provider SolarWinds announced that an unidentified threat actor had exploited a vulnerability in their Orion Platform software to deploy a web shell dubbed SUPERNOVA. CTU researchers track the operators of the SUPERNOVA web shell as BRONZE SPIRAL and assess with low confidence that the group is of Chinese origin. SUPERNOVA was likely deployed through exploitation of CVE-2020-10148, and CTU researchers observed post-exploitation reconnaissance commands roughly 30 minutes before the web shell was deployed. This may have been indicative of the threat actor conducting scan-and-exploit activity and then triaging for victims of particular interest, before deploying SUPERNOVA and attempting to dump credentials and move laterally.

BRONZE SPIRAL has been associated with previous intrusions involving the targeting of ManageEngine servers, maintenance of long-term access to periodically harvest credentials and exfiltrate data, and espionage or theft of intellectual property. The threat group makes extensive use of native system tools and 'living off the land' techniques.

name: BRONZE SPRING
description:
BRONZE SPRING is a threat group that CTU researchers assess with high confidence operates on behalf of China in the theft of intellectual property from defense, engineering, pharmaceutical and technology companies. The threat group typically uses scan-and-exploit for initial access, deploys the China Chopper webshell for remote execution and persistence, and creates RAR archives with a '.jpg' file extension for data exfiltration. 
In July 2020 the U.S. Department of Justice indicted two Chinese hackers CTU researchers assess are members of the BRONZE SPRING threat group. The Department of Justice allege these hackers were responsible for compromising networks of hundreds of organisations and individuals in the U.S. and abroad since 2009, and that exfiltrated data would be passed to the Chinese Ministry of State Security or sold for financial gain.

name: BRONZE VAPOR
description:
BRONZE VAPOR is a targeted threat group assessed with moderate confidence to be of Chinese origin. Artefacts from tools associated with this group and open source reporting on related incidents indicate that BRONZE VAPOR have operated since at least 2017.  The group conducts espionage against multiple industries including semiconductors, aviation and telecommunications.  CTU researchers assess BRONZE VAPOR's intent to be information theft, with operations focused on intellectual property (semiconductors) and personally identifiable information such as traveller records (aviation).  Compromise of telecommunications companies can yield personally identifiable information and meta data on client communications such as Call Data Records (CDR).

Prior to 2019 their operational focus, with some exceptions, revolved around targets in East Asia particularity Taiwan with it's thriving semiconductor industry. In 2021 details emerged in open source of attacks on at least one European semiconductor company believed to date back to 2017.  In 2019 BRONZE VAPOR attacked one of more entities in the European airlines sector. The group gains initial access via VPN services, may use spearphishing with 'Letter of Appointment' themed lures, and deploys Cobalt Strike along with custom data exfiltration tools to target organizations.
