It is currently difficult to check whether this groupware product has a vulnerability or not, but if a server that is this exposed has a vulnerability, then there is a chance that companies could be affected gravely through the leakage of confidential information and ransomware behavior. Furthermore, this Dalbit group leaves some infected companies as proxies and download servers to later use them as means to communicate with the threat actor upon infiltration of another company.

name: DangerousSavanna
description:
Malicious campaign called DangerousSavanna has been targeting multiple major financial service groups in French-speaking Africa for the last two years. The threat actors behind this campaign use spear-phishing as a means of initial infection, sending emails with malicious attachments to the employees of financial institutions in at least five different French-speaking countries: Ivory Coast, Morocco, Cameroon, Senegal, and Togo.
DangerousSavanna tends to install relatively unsophisticated software tools in the infected environments. These tools are both self-written and based on open-source projects such as Metasploit, PoshC2, DWservice, and AsyncRAT. The threat actors’ creativity is on display in the initial infection stage, as they persistently pursue the employees of the targeted companies, constantly changing infection chains that utilize a wide range of malicious file types, from self-written executable loaders and malicious documents, to ISO, LNK, JAR and VBE files in various combinations. The evolving infection chains by the threat actor reflect the changes in the threat landscape seen over the past few years as infection vectors became more and more sophisticated and diverse.

name: Danti
description: Danti is an APT actor identified by Kaspersky Labs that has been active at least since 2015, predominantly targeting Indian government organizations. According to Kaspersky’s telemetry, Danti has also been actively hitting targets in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Myanmar, Nepal and the Philippines.

name: Dark Basin
description:
Dark Basin is a hack-for-hire group that has targeted thousands of individuals and hundreds of institutions on six continents. Targets include advocacy groups and journalists, elected and senior government officials, hedge funds, and multiple industries.
Dark Basin extensively targeted American nonprofits, including organisations working on a campaign called #ExxonKnew, which asserted that ExxonMobil hid information about climate change for decades.
We also identify Dark Basin as the group behind the phishing of organizations working on net neutrality advocacy, previously reported by the Electronic Frontier Foundation.
We link Dark Basin with high confidence to an Indian company, BellTroX InfoTech Services, and related entitie

name: Dark Caracal
description: Dark Caracal is threat group that has been attributed to the Lebanese General Directorate of General Security (GDGS) and has operated since at least 2012.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, General Directorate of General Security (GDGS)

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Dark Caracal collected complete contents of the 'Pictures' folder from compromised Windows systems.
Dark Caracal has obfuscated strings in Bandook by base64 encoding, and then encrypting them.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: Dark Caracal has used UPX to pack Bandook.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Dark Caracal has used macros in Word documents that would download a second stage if executed.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Dark Caracal's version of Bandook communicates with their server over a TCP port using HTTP payloads Base64 encoded and suffixed with the string "&&&".

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Dark Caracal collected file listings of all default Windows directories.

techniques.name: Screen Capture
techniques.use: Dark Caracal took screenshots using their Windows malware.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Dark Caracal leveraged a watering hole to serve up malicious code.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Dark Caracal makes their malware look like Flash Player, Office, or PDF documents in order to entice a user to click on it.

techniques.name: Compiled HTML File
techniques.use: Dark Caracal leveraged a compiled HTML file that contained a command to download and run an executable.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Dark Caracal controls implants using standard HTTP communication.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Dark Caracal's version of Bandook adds a registry key to HKEY_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run for persistence.

techniques.name: Spearphishing via Service
techniques.use: Dark Caracal spearphished victims via Facebook and Whatsapp.

name: Dark Pink
description: (Group-IB) Group-IB, one of the global cybersecurity leaders, has today published its findings into Dark Pink, an ongoing advanced persistent threat (APT) campaign launched against high-profile targets in Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Vietnam, and Bosnia and Herzegovina that we believe, with moderate confidence, was launched by a new threat actor. To date, Group-IB’s Threat Intelligence has been able to attribute seven successful attacks to this particular group from June-December 2022, with targets including military bodies, government ministries and agencies, and religious and non-profit organizations, although the list of victims could be significantly longer. Group-IB also noted one unsuccessful attack on a European state development body based in Vietnam.

name: DarkCasino
description:
(NSFOCUS) In 2022, NSFOCUS Research Labs revealed a large-scale APT attack campaign called DarkCasino and identified an active and dangerous aggressive threat actor. By continuously tracking and in-depth study of the attacker’s activities, NSFOCUS Research Labs has ruled out its link with known APT groups, confirmed its high-level persistent threat nature, and following the operational name, named this APT group DarkCasino.

In August 2023, security vendor Group-IB followed up and disclosed a DarkCasino activity against cryptocurrency forum users, and captured a WinRAR 0-day vulnerability CVE-2023-38831 used by the APT threat actor DarkCasino in this attack.

NSFOCUS Research Labs analyzed the APT group DarkCasino’s attack activities in WinRAR vulnerability exploitation and confirmed its techniques and tactics; At the same time, NSFOCUS Research Labs also found a large number of attacks by known APT organizations and unconfirmed attackers when tracking the exploitation of WinRAR vulnerabilities. Most of these attacks targeted national governments or multinational organizations.

name: DarkHydrus
description: DarkHydrus is a threat group that has targeted government agencies and educational institutions in the Middle East since at least 2016. The group heavily leverages open-source tools and custom payloads for carrying out attacks.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: DarkHydrus leveraged PowerShell to download and execute additional scripts for execution.

techniques.name: Forced Authentication
techniques.use: DarkHydrus used Template Injection to launch an authentication window for users to enter their credentials.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: DarkHydrus has sent malware that required users to hit the enable button in Microsoft Excel to allow an .iqy file to be downloaded.

techniques.name: Template Injection
techniques.use: DarkHydrus used an open-source tool, Phishery, to inject malicious remote template URLs into Microsoft Word documents and then sent them to victims to enable Forced Authentication.

techniques.name: Hidden Window
techniques.use: DarkHydrus has used -WindowStyle Hidden to conceal PowerShell windows.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: DarkHydrus has sent spearphishing emails with password-protected RAR archives containing malicious Excel Web Query files (.iqy). The group has also sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office documents that use the "attachedTemplate"technique to load a template from a remote server.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: DarkHydrus has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz, Empire, and Cobalt Strike.

name: DarkUniverse
description: (Kaspersky) DarkUniverse is an interesting example of a full cyber-espionage framework used for at least eight years. The malware contains all the necessary modules for collecting all kinds of information about the user and the infected system and appears to be fully developed from scratch. Due to unique code overlaps, we assume with medium confidence that DarkUniverse’s creators were connected with the ItaDuke set of activities. The attackers were resourceful and kept updating their malware during the full lifecycle of their operations, so the observed samples from 2017 are totally different from the initial samples from 2009. The suspension of its operations may be related to the publishing of the ‘Lost in Translation’ leak, or the attackers may simply have decided to switch to more modern approaches and start using more widely available artefacts for their operations.

name: DarkVishnya
description: DarkVishnya is a financially motivated threat actor targeting financial institutions in Eastern Europe. In 2017-2018 the group attacked at least 8 banks in this region.

techniques.name: Network Sniffing
techniques.use: DarkVishnya used network sniffing to obtain login data.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: DarkVishnya performed port scanning to obtain the list of active services.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: DarkVishnya used PowerShell to create shellcode loaders.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.use: DarkVishnya used brute-force attack to obtain login data.

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: DarkVishnya scanned the network for public shared folders.

techniques.name: Hardware Additions
techniques.use: DarkVishnya used Bash Bunny, Raspberry Pi, netbooks or inexpensive laptops to connect to the company’s local network.

techniques.name: Remote Access Software
techniques.use: DarkVishnya used DameWare Mini Remote Control for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: DarkVishnya created new services for shellcode loaders distribution.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.use: DarkVishnya used ports 5190 and 7900 for shellcode listeners, and 4444, 4445, 31337 for shellcode C2.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: DarkVishnya has obtained and used tools such as Impacket, Winexe, and PsExec.

name: DefrayX
description: DefrayX is a threat actor group known for their RansomExx ransomware operations. They primarily target Linux operating systems, but also release versions for Windows. The group has been active since 2018 and has targeted various sectors, including healthcare and manufacturing. They have also developed other malware strains such as PyXie RAT, Vatet loader, and Defray ransomware.

name: Denim Tsunami
description: Denim Tsunami is a threat actor group that has been involved in targeted attacks against European and Central American customers. They have been observed using multiple Windows and Adobe 0-day exploits, including one for CVE-2022-22047, which is a privilege escalation vulnerability. Denim Tsunami developed a custom malware called Subzero, which has capabilities such as keylogging, capturing screenshots, data exfiltration, and running remote shells. They have also been associated with the Austrian spyware distributor DSIRF.

name: Desorden Group
description: Desorden (Disorder in Spanish, previously known as ChaosCC), is a financially motivated hacker group. The group first emerged under the new name Desorden in September 2021, on Raidforums. Today the group maintains users under that name on several popular English-speaking hacking forums, where they share their attacks and ransom demands, and offer databases for sale. The group gained an excellent reputation among the cybercriminal communities due to their successful operations and the unique data that they share and offer for sale.

name: DiceyF
description: DiceyF is an advanced persistent threat group that has been targeting online casinos and other victims in Southeast Asia for an extended period. They have exhibited overlapping activity with LuckyStar PlugX and Earth Berberoka/GamblingPuppet, as reported by various cybersecurity vendors. While their motivations remain unclear, previous incidents suggest a combination of espionage and intellectual property theft rather than immediate financial gain. DiceyF continuously evolves their codebase and adds encryption capabilities to enhance their stealthy cyberespionage activities.

name: Doppel Spider
description:
(CrowdStrike) CrowdStrike Intelligence has identified a new ransomware variant identifying itself as BitPaymer. This new variant was behind a series of ransomware campaigns beginning in June 2019, including attacks against the City of Edcouch, Texas and the Chilean Ministry of Agriculture.

We have dubbed this new ransomware DoppelPaymer because it shares most of its code with the BitPaymer ransomware operated by Indrik Spider. However, there are a number of differences between DoppelPaymer and BitPaymer, which may signify that one or more members of Indrik Spider have split from the group and forked the source code of both Dridex and BitPaymer to start their own Big Game Hunting ransomware operation.

DoppelPaymer has been observed to be distributed by Smoke Loader (operated by Smoky Spider) and Emotet (operated by Mummy Spider, TA542).

name: DragonForce
description: DragonForce is a hacktivist group based in Malaysia that has been involved in cyberattacks targeting government institutions and commercial organizations in India. They have also targeted websites affiliated with Israel and have shown support for pro-Palestinian causes. The group has been observed using defacement attacks, distributed denial-of-service attacks, and data leaks as part of their campaigns. DragonForce Malaysia has demonstrated an ability to adapt and evolve their tactics over time.

name: DragonRank
description: DragonRank is a threat actor primarily targeting web application services in Asia and Europe, utilizing TTPs associated with Simplified Chinese-speaking hacking groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in platforms like phpMyAdmin and WordPress to deploy web shells, enabling the installation of PlugX and BadIIS malware for black hat SEO practices. Their operations involve lateral movement within compromised networks to maintain control and elevate privileges, while also engaging in unethical online marketing strategies. DragonRank's activities include manipulating search engine rankings and distributing scam websites through compromised Windows IIS servers.

name: DragonSpark
description:
(SentinelLabs) SentinelLabs has been monitoring recent attacks against East Asian organizations we track as ‘DragonSpark’. The attacks are characterized by the use of the little known open source SparkRAT and malware that attempts to evade detection through Golang source code interpretation.

The DragonSpark attacks represent the first concrete malicious activity where we observe the consistent use of the open source SparkRAT, a relatively new occurrence on the threat landscape. SparkRAT is multi-platform, feature-rich, and frequently updated with new features, making the RAT attractive to threat actors.

The Microsoft Security Threat Intelligence team reported in late December 2022 on indications of threat actors using SparkRAT. However, we have not observed concrete evidence linking DragonSpark to the activity documented in the report by Microsoft.

We observed that the threat actor behind the DragonSpark attacks uses Golang malware that interprets embedded Golang source code at runtime as a technique for hindering static analysis and evading detection by static analysis mechanisms. This uncommon technique provides threat actors with yet another means to evade detection mechanisms by obfuscating malware implementations.

name: Dragonbridge
description: DRAGONBRIDGE is a Chinese state-sponsored threat actor known for engaging in information operations to promote the political interests of the People's Republic of China. They have been observed using AI-generated images and videos to spread propaganda on social media platforms. The group has targeted various countries and regions, including the US, Taiwan, and Japan, with narratives promoting pro-PRC viewpoints. DRAGONBRIDGE has been linked to campaigns discrediting the US political system, sowing division between allies, and criticizing specific companies and individuals.

name: DriftingCloud
description: DriftingCloud is a persistent threat actor known for targeting various industries and locations. They are skilled at developing or acquiring zero-day exploits to gain unauthorized access to target networks. Compromising gateway devices is a common tactic used by DriftingCloud, making network monitoring solutions crucial for detecting their attacks.

name: Dust Storm
description:
(Cylance) Very little public information was available throughout 2010 on this threat, despite the group’s primary backdoor gaining some level of prominence in targeted Asian attacks. This may be explained by the group’s early reliance on Dynamic DNS domains for their command and control (C2) infrastructure, as well as their use of public RATs like Poison Ivy and Gh0st RAT for second-stage implants.

It wasn’t until June 2011 that Operation Dust Storm started to garner some notoriety from a series of attacks which leveraged an unpatched Internet Explorer 8 vulnerability, CVE-2011-1255, to gain a foothold into victim networks. In these attacks, a link to the exploit was sent via a spear phishing email from a purported Chinese student seeking advice or asking the target a question following a presentation.

As to other documented cases, the attacker started interacting with the infected machine within minutes of compromise to begin manual network and host enumeration.

In October 2011, the group attempted to take advantage of the ongoing Libyan crisis at the time and phish the news cycle regarding Muammar Gaddafi’s death on October 20, 2011. It appears that in addition to some US defense targets, this campaign was also directed at a Uyghur mailing list. This time, the group used a specially crafted malicious Windows Help (.hlp) file, which exploited CVE-2010-1885.

name: EXOTIC LILY
description: EXOTIC LILY is a financially motivated group that has been closely linked with Wizard Spider and the deployment of ransomware including Conti and Diavol. EXOTIC LILY may be acting as an initial access broker for other malicious actors, and has targeted a wide range of industries including IT, cybersecurity, and healthcare since at least September 2021.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has used file-sharing services including WeTransfer, TransferNow, and OneDrive to deliver payloads.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has used malicious documents containing exploits for CVE-2021-40444 affecting Microsoft MSHTML.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has used malicious links to lure users into executing malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has gained execution through victims clicking on malicious LNK files contained within ISO files, which can execute hidden DLLs within the ISO.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY conducted an e-mail thread-hijacking campaign with malicious ISO attachments.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has relied on victims to open malicious links in e-mails for execution.

techniques.name: Spearphishing via Service
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has used the e-mail notification features of legitimate file sharing services for spearphishing.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has registered domains to spoof targeted organizations by changing the top-level domain (TLD) to ".us", ".co"or ".biz".

techniques.name: Social Media Accounts
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has established social media profiles to mimic employees of targeted companies.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has created e-mail accounts to spoof targeted organizations.

techniques.name: Email Addresses
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has gathered targeted individuals' e-mail addresses through open source research and website contact forms.

techniques.name: Social Media
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has copied data from social media sites to impersonate targeted individuals.

techniques.name: Search Victim-Owned Websites
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has used contact forms on victim websites to generate phishing e-mails.

techniques.name: Search Closed Sources
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has searched for information on targeted individuals on business databases including RocketReach and CrunchBase.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: EXOTIC LILY has uploaded malicious payloads to file-sharing services including TransferNow, TransferXL, WeTransfer, and OneDrive.

name: Earth Baxia
description: Earth Baxia is a threat actor opearting out of China, targeting government organizations in Taiwan and potentially across the APAC region, using spear-phishing emails and exploiting the GeoServer vulnerability CVE-2024-36401 for remote code execution, deploying customized Cobalt Strike components with altered signatures, leveraging GrimResource and AppDomainManager injection techniques to deliver additional payloads, and utilizing a new backdoor named EAGLEDOOR for multi-protocol communication and payload delivery.

name: Earth Berberoka
description: (Trend Micro) We recently discovered a new advanced persistent threat (APT) group that we have dubbed Earth Berberoka (aka GamblingPuppet). Based on our analysis, this group targets gambling websites. Our investigation has also uncovered that Earth Berberoka targets the Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms, and uses malware families that have been historically attributed to Chinese-speaking individuals.

name: Earth Freybug
description:
A subgroup of APT 41.

(Trend Micro) Earth Freybug is a cyberthreat group that has been active since at least 2012 that focuses on espionage and financially motivated activities. It has been observed to target organizations from various sectors across different countries. Earth Freybug actors use a diverse range of tools and techniques, including LOLBins and custom malware. This article provides an in-depth look into two techniques used by Earth Freybug actors: dynamic-link library (DLL) hijacking and application programming interface (API) unhooking to prevent child processes from being monitored via a new malware we’ve discovered and dubbed UNAPIMON.

name: Earth Kitsune
description: Earth Kitsune is an advanced persistent threat actor that has been active since at least 2019. They primarily target individuals interested in North Korea and use various tactics, such as compromising websites and employing social engineering, to distribute self-developed backdoors. Earth Kitsune demonstrates technical proficiency and continuously evolves their tools, tactics, and procedures. They have been associated with malware such as WhiskerSpy and SLUB.

name: Earth Krahang
description:
(Trend Micro) Since early 2022, we have been monitoring an APT campaign that targets several government entities worldwide, with a strong focus in Southeast Asia, but also seen targeting Europe, America, and Africa. The threat actor exploits public-facing servers and sends spear phishing emails to deliver previously unseen backdoors.

Our research allowed us to identify the campaign’s multiple connections with a China-nexus threat actor we track as Earth Lusca. However, since the campaign employs independent infrastructure and unique backdoors, we believe it to be a separate intrusion set that we named Earth Krahang.

name: Earth Longzhi
description:
A subgroup of APT 41.

(Trend Micro) In early 2022, we investigated an incident that compromised a company in Taiwan. The malware used in the incident was a simple but custom Cobalt Strike loader. After further investigation, however, we found incidents targeting multiple regions using a similar Cobalt Strike loader. While analyzing code similarities and tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we discovered that the actor behind this attack has been active since 2020. After clustering each intrusion, we concluded that the threat actor is a new subgroup of advanced persistent threat (APT) group APT41 that we call Earth Longzhi.

name: Earth Lusca
description: Earth Lusca is a suspected China-based cyber espionage group that has been active since at least April 2019. Earth Lusca has targeted organizations in Australia, China, Hong Kong, Mongolia, Nepal, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam, the United Arab Emirates, Nigeria, Germany, France, and the United States. Targets included government institutions, news media outlets, gambling companies, educational institutions, COVID-19 research organizations, telecommunications companies, religious movements banned in China, and cryptocurrency trading platforms; security researchers assess some Earth Lusca operations may be financially motivated.Earth Lusca has used malware commonly used by other Chinese threat groups, including APT41 and the Winnti Group cluster, however security researchers assess Earth Lusca's techniques and infrastructure are separate.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: Earth Lusca has used ProcDump to obtain the hashes of credentials by dumping the memory of the LSASS process.

techniques.name: DCSync
techniques.use: Earth Lusca has used a DCSync command with Mimikatz to retrieve credentials from an exploited controller.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.use: Earth Lusca has used Tasklist to obtain information from a compromised host.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Earth Lusca used the command ipconfig to obtain information about network configurations.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Earth Lusca used the command powershell "Get-EventLog -LogName security -Newest 500 | where {$_.EventID -eq 4624} | format-list -property * | findstr "Address""to find the network information of successfully logged-in accounts to discovery addresses of other machines. Earth Lusca has also used multiple scanning tools to discover other machines within the same compromised network.

name: Earth Wendigo
description:
(Trend Micro) We discovered a new campaign that has been targeting several organizations — including government organizations, research institutions and universities in Taiwan — since May 2019, aiming to exfiltrate emails from targeted organizations via the injection of JavaScript backdoors to a webmail system that is widely-used in Taiwan.  With no clear connection to any previous attack group, we gave this new threat actor the name “Earth Wendigo.”

Additional investigation shows that the threat actor also sent spear-phishing emails embedded with malicious links to multiple individuals, including politicians and activists, who support movements in Tibet, the Uyghur region, or Hong Kong. However, this is a separate series of attacks from their operation in Taiwan, which this report covers.

name: Edalat-e Ali
description: Edalat-e Ali is a hacktivist group known for disrupting Iranian state-run TV and radio transmissions during significant events, such as the Revolution Day ceremonies. They have also targeted government facilities, releasing security camera footage to expose abuses and draw attention to human rights violations. The group has used their hacks to call for protests against the Iranian regime and have displayed anti-government messages during their disruptions. Edalat-e Ali has been active in releasing sensitive information and footage to embarrass Iranian officials and highlight injustices within the country.

name: Elderwood
description: Elderwood is a suspected Chinese cyber espionage group that was reportedly responsible for the 2009 Google intrusion known as Operation Aurora. The group has targeted defense organizations, supply chain manufacturers, human rights and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), and IT service providers.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, the Jiangsu Bureau of the MSS (JSSD/江苏省国家安全厅)

name: Ember Bear
description: Ember Bear is a suspected Russian state-sponsored cyber espionage group that has been active since at least March 2021. Ember Bear has primarily focused their operations against Ukraine and Georgia, but has also targeted Western European and North American foreign ministries, pharmaceutical companies, and financial sector organizations. Security researchers assess Ember Bear likely conducted the WhisperGate destructive wiper attacks against Ukraine in early 2022.

name: EmpireMonkey
description:
(Blueliv) EmpireMonkey is an advanced financially motivated cybercriminal gang. The group gained notoriety for a heist they conducted in February 2019 against the Maltese Bank of Valletta, which initially resulted in roughly €13 million in losses, though much of this was subsequently recovered or frozen. While a thorough post-mortem of the Bank of Valletta attack has yet to be made public, it is highly likely that the threat actors sent malicious spear phishing emails to employees at Bank of Valletta and other European financial institutions. In October 2018, HSBC Malta reported receiving phishing emails that bore hallmarks of the subsequent EmpireMonkey attack against Bank of Valletta.

This group seems to be directly related to Carbanak, Anunak and/or FIN7.

name: Equation
description: Equation is a sophisticated threat group that employs multiple remote access tools. The group is known to use zero-day exploits and has developed the capability to overwrite the firmware of hard disk drives.

techniques.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
techniques.use: Equation has used tools with the functionality to search for specific information about the attached hard drive that could be used to identify and overwrite the firmware.

techniques.name: Environmental Keying
techniques.use: Equation has been observed utilizing environmental keying in payload delivery.

techniques.name: Component Firmware
techniques.use: Equation is known to have the capability to overwrite the firmware on hard drives from some manufacturers.

techniques.name: Hidden File System
techniques.use: Equation has used an encrypted virtual file system stored in the Windows Registry.

name: Equation Group
description:
(Ars Technica) Kaspersky researchers have documented 500 infections by Equation Group in at least 42 countries, with Iran, Russia, Pakistan, Afghanistan, India, Syria, and Mali topping the list. Because of a self-destruct mechanism built into the malware, the researchers suspect that this is just a tiny percentage of the total; the actual number of victims likely reaches into the tens of thousands.

A long list of almost superhuman technical feats illustrate Equation Group’s extraordinary skill, painstaking work, and unlimited resources. They include:
• The use of virtual file systems, a feature also found in the highly sophisticated Regin malware. Recently published documents provided by Ed Snowden indicate that the NSA used Regin to infect the partly state-owned Belgian firm Belgacom.
• The stashing of malicious files in multiple branches of an infected computer’s registry. By encrypting all malicious files and storing them in multiple branches of a computer’s Windows registry, the infection was impossible to detect using antivirus software.
• Redirects that sent iPhone users to unique exploit Web pages. In addition, infected machines reporting to Equation Group command servers identified themselves as Macs, an indication that the group successfully compromised both iOS and OS X devices.
• The use of more than 300 Internet domains and 100 servers to host a sprawling command and control infrastructure.
• USB stick-based reconnaissance malware to map air-gapped networks, which are so sensitive that they aren’t connected to the Internet. Both Stuxnet and the related Flame malware platform also had the ability to bridge airgaps.
• An unusual if not truly novel way of bypassing code-signing restrictions in modern versions of Windows, which require that all third-party software interfacing with the operating system kernel be digitally signed by a recognized certificate authority. To circumvent this restriction, Equation Group malware exploited a known vulnerability in an already signed driver for CloneCD to achieve kernel-level code execution.

Taken together, the accomplishments led Kaspersky researchers to conclude that Equation Group is probably the most sophisticated computer attack group in the world, with technical skill and resources that rival the groups that developed Stuxnet and the Flame espionage malware in Operation Olympic Games.

Other publicly exposed major APT activities from the NSA involve the wholesale worldwide spying from programs such as PRISM and, together with GCHQ, INCENSER, where various international Internet trunks were tapped.

China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) has accused the U.S. of breaking into Huawei's servers, stealing critical data, and implanting backdoors since 2009, amid mounting geopolitical tensions between the two countries.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, believed to be tied to the NSA’s Tailored Access Operations unit

name: EvilPost
description: In December 2015, Kaspersky Lab became aware of a targeted attack against the Japanese defense sector. In order to infect victims, the attacker sent an email with an attached DOCX file exploiting the CVE-2015-2545 vulnerability in Microsoft Office using an embedded EPS (Encapsulated Postscript) object. The EPS object contained a shellcode that dropped and loaded a 32-bit or 64-bit DLL file depending on the system architecture. This, in turn exploited another vulnerability to elevate privileges to Local System (CVE-2015-1701) and download additional malware components from the C&C server.

name: EvilTraffic
description: Malware experts at CSE Cybsec uncovered a massive malvertising campaign dubbed EvilTraffic leveraging tens of thousands compromised websites. Crooks exploited some CMS vulnerabilities to upload and execute arbitrary PHP pages used to generate revenues via advertising.

name: Evilnum
description: Evilnum is a financially motivated threat group that has been active since at least 2018.

name: FASTCash
description: Treasury has identified a sophisticated cyber-enabled ATM cash out campaign we are calling FASTCash. FASTCash has been active since late 2016 targeting banks in Africa and Asia to remotely compromise payment switch application servers within banks to facilitate fraudulent transactions, primarily involving ATMs, to steal cash equivalent to tens of millions of dollars. FBI has attributed malware used in this campaign to the North Korean government. We expect FASTCash to continue targeting retail payment systems vulnerable to remote exploitation.

name: FIN1
description: FireEye first identified this activity during a recent investigation at an organization in the financial industry. They identified the presence of a financially motivated threat group that they track as FIN1, whose activity at the organization dated back several years. The threat group deployed numerous malicious files and utilities, all of which were part of a malware ecosystem referred to as ‘Nemesis’ by the malware developer(s), and used this malware to access the victim environment and steal cardholder data. FIN1, which may be located in Russia or a Russian-speaking country based on language settings in many of their custom tools, is known for stealing data that is easily monetized from financial services organizations such as banks, credit unions, ATM operations, and financial transaction processing and financial business services companies.

name: FIN10
description: FIN10 is a financially motivated threat group that has targeted organizations in North America since at least 2013 through 2016. The group uses stolen data exfiltrated from victims to extort organizations.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: FIN10 has used RDP to move laterally to systems in the victim environment.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: FIN10 has used Meterpreter to enumerate users on remote systems.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: FIN10 has established persistence by using S4U tasks as well as the Scheduled Task option in PowerShell Empire.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: FIN10 uses PowerShell for execution as well as PowerShell Empire to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: FIN10 has executed malicious .bat files containing PowerShell commands.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: FIN10 has used batch scripts and scheduled tasks to delete critical system files.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: FIN10 has used stolen credentials to connect remotely to victim networks using VPNs protected with only a single factor.

techniques.name: Local Accounts
techniques.use: FIN10 has moved laterally using the Local Administrator account.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: FIN10 has established persistence by using the Registry option in PowerShell Empire to add a Run key.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.use: FIN10 has deployed Meterpreter stagers and SplinterRAT instances in the victim network after moving laterally.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: FIN10 has relied on publicly-available software to gain footholds and establish persistence in victim environments.

name: FIN13
description: FIN13 is a financially motivated cyber threat group that has targeted the financial, retail, and hospitality industries in Mexico and Latin America, as early as 2016. FIN13 achieves its objectives by stealing intellectual property, financial data, mergers and acquisition information, or PII.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: FIN13 has obtained memory dumps with ProcDump to parse and extract credentials from a victim's LSASS process memory with Mimikatz.

techniques.name: Security Account Manager
techniques.use: FIN13 has extracted the SAM and SYSTEM registry hives using the reg.exe binary for obtaining password hashes from a compromised machine.

techniques.name: NTDS
techniques.use: FIN13 has harvested the NTDS.DIT file and leveraged the Impacket tool on the compromised domain controller to locally decrypt it.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: FIN13 has gathered stolen credentials, sensitive data such as point-of-sale (POS), and ATM data from a compromised network before exfiltration.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has used nslookup and ipconfig for network reconnaissance efforts. FIN13 has also utilized a compromised Symantec Altiris console and LanDesk account to retrieve network information.

techniques.name: Internet Connection Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has used Ping and tracert for network reconnaissance efforts.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: FIN13 has remotely accessed compromised environments via Remote Desktop Services (RDS) for lateral movement.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: FIN13 has leveraged SMB to move laterally within a compromised network via application servers and SQL servers.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: FIN13 has remotely accessed compromised environments via secure shell (SSH) for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Windows Remote Management
techniques.use: FIN13 has leveraged WMI to move laterally within a compromised network via application servers and SQL servers.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.use: FIN13 has masqueraded staged data by using the Windows certutil utility to generate fake Base64 encoded certificates with the input file.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: FIN13 has used scheduled tasks names such as acrotyr and AppServicesr to mimic the same names in a compromised network's C:\Windows directory.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: FIN13 has masqueraded WAR files to look like legitimate packages such as, wsexample.war, wsexamples.com, examples.war, and exampl3s.war.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized nmap for reconnaissance efforts. FIN13 has also scanned for internal MS-SQL servers in a compromised network.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized WMI to execute commands and move laterally on compromised Windows machines.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has used netstat and other net commands for network reconnaissance efforts.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: FIN13 has created scheduled tasks in the C:\Windows directory of the compromised network.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: FIN13 has logged the keystrokes of victims to escalate privileges.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: FIN13 has used PowerShell commands to obtain DNS data from a compromised network.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: FIN13 has leveraged xp_cmdshell and Windows Command Shell to execute commands on a compromised machine. FIN13 has also attempted to leverage the ‘xp_cmdshell’ SQL procedure to execute remote commands on internal MS-SQL servers.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: FIN13 has used VBS scripts for code execution on comrpomised machines.

techniques.name: Permission Groups Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has enumerated all users and roles from a victim's main treasury system.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: FIN13 has used HTTP requests to chain multiple web shells and to contact actor-controlled C2 servers prior to exfiltrating stolen data.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized the following temporary folders on compromised Windows and Linux systems for their operations prior to exfiltration: C:\Windows\Temp and /tmp.

techniques.name: Default Accounts
techniques.use: FIN13 has leveraged default credentials for authenticating myWebMethods (WMS) and QLogic web management interface to gain initial access.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has collected local host information by utilizing Windows commands systeminfo, fsutil, and fsinfo. FIN13 has also utilized a compromised Symantex Altiris console and LanDesk account to retrieve host information.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has used the Windows dir command to enumerate files and directories in a victim's network.

techniques.name: Account Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has enumerated all users and their roles from a victim's main treasury system.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: FIN13 can identify user accounts associated with a Service Principal Name and query Service Principal Names within the domain by utilizing the following scripts: GetUserSPNs.vbs and querySpn.vbs.

techniques.name: Internal Proxy
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized a proxy tool to communicate between compromised assets.

techniques.name: Account Manipulation
techniques.use: FIN13 has assigned newly created accounts the sysadmin role to maintain persistence.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: FIN13 has downloaded additional tools and malware to compromised systems.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: FIN13 has gained access to compromised environments via remote access services such as the corporate virtual private network (VPN).

techniques.name: Make and Impersonate Token
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized tools such as Incognito V2 for token manipulation and impersonation.

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: FIN13 has executed net view commands for enumeration of open shares on compromised machines.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: FIN13 has created MS-SQL local accounts in a compromised network.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized certutil to decode base64 encoded versions of custom malware.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.use: FIN13 has exploited known vulnerabilities such as CVE-2017-1000486 (Primefaces Application Expression Language Injection), CVE-2015-7450 (WebSphere Application Server SOAP Deserialization Exploit), CVE-2010-5326 (SAP NewWeaver Invoker Servlet Exploit), and EDB-ID-24963 (SAP NetWeaver ConfigServlet Remote Code Execution) to gain initial access.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized obfuscated and open-source web shells such as JspSpy, reGeorg, MiniWebCmdShell, and Vonloesch Jsp File Browser 1.2 to enable remote code execution and to execute commands on compromised web server.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: FIN13 has used Windows Registry run keys such as, HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\hosts to maintain persistence.

techniques.name: Pass the Hash
techniques.use: FIN13 has used the PowerShell utility Invoke-SMBExec to execute the pass the hash method for lateral movement within an compromised environment.

techniques.name: Credentials In Files
techniques.use: FIN13 has obtained administrative credentials by browsing through local files on a compromised machine.

techniques.name: Modify Authentication Process
techniques.use: FIN13 has replaced legitimate KeePass binaries with trojanized versions to collect passwords from numerous applications.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: FIN13 has compressed the dump output of compromised credentials with a 7zip binary.

techniques.name: Hidden Files and Directories
techniques.use: FIN13 has created hidden files and folders within a compromised Linux system /tmp directory. FIN13 also has used attrib.exe to hide gathered local host information.

techniques.name: Data Manipulation
techniques.use: FIN13 has injected fraudulent transactions into compromised networks that mimic legitimate behavior to siphon off incremental amounts of money.

techniques.name: Protocol Tunneling
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized web shells and Java tools for tunneling capabilities to and from compromised assets.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: FIN13 has used IISCrack.dll as a side-loading technique to load a malicious version of httpodbc.dll on old IIS Servers (CVE-2001-0507).

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized custom malware to maintain persistence in a compromised environment.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: FIN13 has utilized publicly available tools such as Mimikatz, Impacket, PWdump7, ProcDump, Nmap, and Incognito V2 for targeting efforts.

techniques.name: Gather Victim Identity Information
techniques.use: FIN13 has researched employees to target for social engineering attacks.

techniques.name: Network Topology
techniques.use: FIN13 has searched for infrastructure that can provide remote access to an environment for targeting efforts.

techniques.name: Financial Theft
techniques.use: FIN13 has observed the victim's software and infrastructure over several months to understand the technical process of legitimate financial transactions, prior to attempting to conduct fraudulent transactions.

name: FIN4
description: FIN4 is a financially-motivated threat group that has targeted confidential information related to the public financial market, particularly regarding healthcare and pharmaceutical companies, since at least 2013. FIN4 is unique in that they do not infect victims with typical persistent malware, but rather they focus on capturing credentials authorized to access email and other non-public correspondence.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: FIN4 has captured credentials via fake Outlook Web App (OWA) login pages and has also used a .NET based keylogger.

techniques.name: GUI Input Capture
techniques.use: FIN4 has presented victims with spoofed Windows Authentication prompts to collect their credentials.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: FIN4 has used VBA macros to display a dialog box and collect victim credentials.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: FIN4 has used HTTP POST requests to transmit data.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: FIN4 has used legitimate credentials to hijack email communications.

techniques.name: Multi-hop Proxy
techniques.use: FIN4 has used Tor to log in to victims' email accounts.

techniques.name: Remote Email Collection
techniques.use: FIN4 has accessed and hijacked online email communications using stolen credentials.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: FIN4 has lured victims to click malicious links delivered via spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts).

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: FIN4 has lured victims to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts).

techniques.name: Email Hiding Rules
techniques.use: FIN4 has created rules in victims' Microsoft Outlook accounts to automatically delete emails containing words such as "hacked,""phish,"and "malware"in a likely attempt to prevent organizations from communicating about their activities.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: FIN4 has used spearphishing emails containing attachments (which are often stolen, legitimate documents sent from compromised accounts) with embedded malicious macros.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: FIN4 has used spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts) containing malicious links.

name: FIN5
description: FIN5 is a financially motivated threat group that has targeted personally identifiable information and payment card information. The group has been active since at least 2008 and has targeted the restaurant, gaming, and hotel industries. The group is made up of actors who likely speak Russian.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: FIN5 has used the open source tool Essential NetTools to map the network and build a list of targets.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.use: FIN5 scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.

techniques.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
techniques.use: FIN5 has cleared event logs from victims.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: FIN5 uses SDelete to clean up the environment and attempt to prevent detection.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: FIN5 scripts save memory dump data into a specific directory on hosts in the victim environment.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, RDP, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.

techniques.name: External Proxy
techniques.use: FIN5 maintains access to victim environments by using FLIPSIDE to create a proxy for a backup RDP tunnel.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.use: FIN5 has has used the tool GET2 Penetrator to look for remote login and hard-coded credentials.

techniques.name: Automated Collection
techniques.use: FIN5 scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: FIN5 has obtained and used a customized version of PsExec, as well as use other tools such as pwdump, SDelete, and Windows Credential Editor.

name: FIN6
description: FIN6 is a cyber crime group that has stolen payment card data and sold it for profit on underground marketplaces. This group has aggressively targeted and compromised point of sale (PoS) systems in the hospitality and retail sectors.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, Ministry of State Security and Internet security firm Guangzhou Bo Yu Information Technology Company Limited (“Boyusec”)

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: FIN6 has used Windows Credential Editor for credential dumping.

techniques.name: NTDS
techniques.use: FIN6 has used Metasploit’s PsExec NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: FIN6 has collected and exfiltrated payment card data from compromised systems.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: A keylogging tool used by APT3 gathers network information from the victim, including the MAC address, IP address, WINS, DHCP server, and gateway.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: FIN6 used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: FIN6 used RDP to move laterally in victim networks.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: APT3 will copy files over to Windows Admin Shares (like ADMIN$) as part of lateral movement.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.use: APT3 obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: APT3 has been known to pack their tools.

techniques.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
techniques.use: APT3 has been known to remove indicators of compromise from tools.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: FIN6 has used encoded PowerShell commands.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: An APT3 downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe"/C whoami to verify that it is running with the elevated privileges of "System."

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: FIN6 has renamed the "psexec"service name to "mstdc"to masquerade as a legitimate Windows service.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that exfiltrates data over the C2 channel.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: FIN6 used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: FIN6 has used WMI to automate the remote execution of PowerShell scripts.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: FIN6 has sent stolen payment card data to remote servers via HTTP POSTs.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that can enumerate current network connections.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: FIN6 has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for various malware it uses, including downloaders known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD and FrameworkPOS.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: APT3 has used a keylogging tool that records keystrokes in encrypted files.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that can list out currently running processes.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.use: FIN6 has used scripting to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: FIN6 has used PowerShell to gain access to merchant's networks, and a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: FIN6 has used kill.bat script to disable security tools.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: FIN6 has used malicious JavaScript to steal payment card data from e-commerce sites.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: FIN6 has used tools to exploit Windows vulnerabilities in order to escalate privileges. The tools targeted CVE-2013-3660, CVE-2011-2005, and CVE-2010-4398, all of which could allow local users to access kernel-level privileges.

techniques.name: Permission Groups Discovery
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that can enumerate the permissions associated with Windows groups.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: FIN6 has removed files from victim machines.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: APT3 has been known to stage files for exfiltration in a single location.

techniques.name: Remote Data Staging
techniques.use: FIN6 actors have compressed data from remote systems and moved it to another staging system before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: To move laterally on a victim network, FIN6 has used credentials stolen from various systems on which it gathered usernames and password hashes.

techniques.name: Domain Accounts
techniques.use: APT3 leverages valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: APT3 has used a tool that can obtain info about local and global group users, power users, and administrators.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: FIN6 has used Metasploit’s PsExec NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.

techniques.name: External Proxy
techniques.use: An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.

techniques.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
techniques.use: FIN6 has used Metasploit Bind and Reverse TCP stagers.

techniques.name: Account Manipulation
techniques.use: APT3 has been known to add created accounts to local admin groups to maintain elevated access.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: FIN6 has used Pastebin and Google Storage to host content for their operations.

techniques.name: Multi-Stage Channels
techniques.use: An APT3 downloader first establishes a SOCKS5 connection to 192.157.198

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that can copy files to remote machines.

techniques.name: Password Cracking
techniques.use: FIN6 has extracted password hashes from ntds.dit to crack offline.

techniques.name: Automated Collection
techniques.use: FIN6 has used a script to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy and remove data to a log file, and to bind to events from the submit payment button.

techniques.name: Access Token Manipulation
techniques.use: FIN6 has used has used Metasploit’s named-pipe impersonation technique to escalate privileges.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: APT3 has been known to create or enable accounts, such as support_388945a0.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: APT3 has exploited the Adobe Flash Player vulnerability CVE-2015-3113 and Internet Explorer vulnerability CVE-2014-1776.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: APT3 has lured victims into clicking malicious links delivered through spearphishing.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: FIN6 has used malicious documents to lure victims into allowing execution of PowerShell scripts.

techniques.name: Data from Information Repositories
techniques.use: FIN6 has collected schemas and user accounts from systems running SQL Server.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that can run DLLs.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that creates a new service for persistence.

techniques.name: Accessibility Features
techniques.use: APT3 replaces the Sticky Keys binary C:\Windows\System32\sethc.exe for persistence.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: FIN6 has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence for its downloader tools known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD.

techniques.name: Credentials In Files
techniques.use: APT3 has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: FIN6 has used Comodo code-signing certificates.

techniques.name: Credentials from Password Stores
techniques.use: FIN6 has used the Stealer One credential stealer to target e-mail and file transfer utilities including FTP.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: FIN6 has used the Stealer One credential stealer to target web browsers.

techniques.name: Archive Collected Data
techniques.use: Following data collection, FIN6 has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: APT3 has used tools to compress data before exfilling it.

techniques.name: Archive via Custom Method
techniques.use: FIN6 has encoded data gathered from the victim with a simple substitution cipher and single-byte XOR using the 0xAA key, and Base64 with character permutation.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: FIN6 has deployed a utility script named kill.bat to disable anti-virus.

techniques.name: Hidden Window
techniques.use: APT3 has been known to use -WindowStyle Hidden to conceal PowerShell windows.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: FIN6 has targeted victims with e-mails containing malicious attachments.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: APT3 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.

techniques.name: Spearphishing via Service
techniques.use: FIN6 has used fake job advertisements sent via LinkedIn to spearphish targets.

techniques.name: Service Execution
techniques.use: FIN6 has created Windows services to execute encoded PowerShell commands.

techniques.name: Protocol Tunneling
techniques.use: FIN6 used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.

techniques.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: FIN6 used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: APT3 has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: FIN6 has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz, Cobalt Strike, and AdFind.

name: FIN7
description: FIN7 is a financially-motivated threat group that has been active since 2013. FIN7 has primarily targeted the retail, restaurant, hospitality, software, consulting, financial services, medical equipment, cloud services, media, food and beverage, transportation, and utilities industries in the U.S. A portion of FIN7 was run out of a front company called Combi Security and often used point-of-sale malware for targeting efforts. Since 2020, FIN7 shifted operations to a big game hunting (BGH) approach including use of REvil ransomware and their own Ransomware as a Service (RaaS), Darkside. FIN7 may be linked to the Carbanak Group, but there appears to be several groups using Carbanak malware and are therefore tracked separately.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: FIN7 has collected files and other sensitive information from a compromised network.

techniques.name: Fallback Channels
techniques.use: FIN7's Harpy backdoor malware can use DNS as a backup channel for C2 if HTTP fails.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: FIN7 has used RDP to move laterally in victim environments.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: FIN7 has used SSH to move laterally through victim environments.

techniques.name: VNC
techniques.use: FIN7 has used TightVNC to control compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Binary Padding
techniques.use: FIN7 has used random junk code to obfuscate malware code.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: FIN7 has used fragmented strings, environment variables, standard input (stdin), and native character-replacement functionalities to obfuscate commands.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: FIN7 has used the command cmd.exe /C quser to collect user session information.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: FIN7 has created a scheduled task named "AdobeFlashSync"to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: FIN7 has attempted to run Darkside ransomware with the filename sleep.exe.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: FIN7 has used WMI to install malware on targeted systems.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: FIN7 malware has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.use: FIN7 used SQL scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: FIN7 used a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieved an additional payload.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: FIN7 used the command prompt to launch commands on the victim’s machine.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: FIN7 used VBS scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: FIN7 used JavaScript scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.

techniques.name: Domain Groups
techniques.use: FIN7 has used the command net group "domain admins"/domain to enumerate domain groups.

techniques.name: DNS
techniques.use: FIN7 has performed C2 using DNS via A, OPT, and TXT records.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: FIN7 has harvested valid administrative credentials for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Local Accounts
techniques.use: FIN7 has used compromised credentials for access as SYSTEM on Exchange servers.

techniques.name: Replication Through Removable Media
techniques.use: FIN7 actors have mailed USB drives to potential victims containing malware that downloads and installs various backdoors, including in some cases for ransomware operations.

techniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
techniques.use: FIN7 used legitimate services like Google Docs, Google Scripts, and Pastebin for C2.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: FIN7 has downloaded additional malware to execute on the victim's machine, including by using a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.

techniques.name: Screen Capture
techniques.use: FIN7 captured screenshots and desktop video recordings.

techniques.name: Video Capture
techniques.use: FIN7 created a custom video recording capability that could be used to monitor operations in the victim's environment.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.use: FIN7 has compromised targeted organizations through exploitation of CVE-2021-31207 in Exchange.

techniques.name: Compromise Software Supply Chain
techniques.use: FIN7 has gained initial access by compromising a victim's software supply chain.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: FIN7 has used malicious links to lure victims into downloading malware.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: FIN7 lured victims to double-click on images in the attachments they sent which would then execute the hidden LNK file.

techniques.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
techniques.use: FIN7 has exploited ZeroLogon (CVE-2020-1472) against vulnerable domain controllers.

techniques.name: Mshta
techniques.use: FIN7 has used mshta.exe to execute VBScript to execute malicious code on victim systems.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: FIN7 has used rundll32.exe to execute malware on a compromised network.

techniques.name: Remote Access Software
techniques.use: FIN7 has utilized the remote management tool Atera to download malware to a compromised system.

techniques.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
techniques.use: FIN7 has encrypted virtual disk volumes on ESXi servers using a version of Darkside ransomware.

techniques.name: User Activity Based Checks
techniques.use: FIN7 used images embedded into document lures that only activate the payload when a user double clicks to avoid sandboxes.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: FIN7 created new Windows services and added them to the startup directories for persistence.

techniques.name: Application Shimming
techniques.use: FIN7 has used application shim databases for persistence.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: FIN7 malware has created Registry Run and RunOnce keys to establish persistence, and has also added items to the Startup folder.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: FIN7 has signed Carbanak payloads with legally purchased code signing certificates. FIN7 has also digitally signed their phishing documents, backdoors and other staging tools to bypass security controls.

techniques.name: Kerberoasting
techniques.use: FIN7 has used Kerberoasting PowerShell commands such as, Invoke-Kerberoast for credential access and to enable lateral movement.

techniques.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
techniques.use: FIN7 spear phishing campaigns have included malicious Word documents with DDE execution.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
techniques.use: Carbanak may use netsh to add local firewall rule exceptions.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: FIN7 sent spearphishing emails with either malicious Microsoft Documents or RTF files attached.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: FIN7 has conducted broad phishing campaigns using malicious links.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: FIN7 has exfiltrated stolen data to the MEGA file sharing site.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.use: FIN7 has used port-protocol mismatches on ports such as 53, 80, 443, and 8080 during C2.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: FIN7 has registered look-alike domains for use in phishing campaigns.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: FIN7 has set up Amazon S3 buckets to host trojanized digital products.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: FIN7 has developed malware for use in operations, including the creation of infected removable media.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: FIN7 has utilized a variety of tools such as Cobalt Strike, PowerSploit, and the remote management tool, Atera for targeting efforts.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: FIN7 has staged legitimate software, that was trojanized to contain an Atera agent installer, on Amazon S3.

techniques.name: Drive-by Target
techniques.use: FIN7 has compromised a digital product website and modified multiple download links to point to trojanized versions of offered digital products.

name: FIN8
description: FIN8 is a financially motivated threat group that has been active since at least January 2016, and known for targeting organizations in the hospitality, retail, entertainment, insurance, technology, chemical, and financial sectors. In June 2021, security researchers detected FIN8 switching from targeting point-of-sale (POS) devices to distributing a number of ransomware variants.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: FIN8 harvests credentials using Invoke-Mimikatz or Windows Credentials Editor (WCE).

techniques.name: Internet Connection Discovery
techniques.use: FIN8 has used the Ping command to check connectivity to actor-controlled C2 servers.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: FIN8 has used dsquery and other Active Directory utilities to enumerate hosts; they have also used nltest.exe /dclist to retrieve a list of domain controllers.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: FIN8 has used RDP for lateral movement.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: FIN8 has attempted to map to C$ on enumerated hosts to test the scope of their current credentials/context. FIN8 has also used smbexec from the Impacket suite for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: FIN8 has used environment variables and standard input (stdin) to obfuscate command-line arguments. FIN8 also obfuscates malicious macros delivered as payloads.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: FIN8 has executed the command quser to display the session details of a compromised machine.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: FIN8's malicious spearphishing payloads use WMI to launch malware and spawn cmd.exe execution. FIN8 has also used WMIC and the Impacket suite for lateral movement, as well as during and post compromise cleanup activities.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: FIN8 has used FTP to exfiltrate collected data.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: FIN8 has used scheduled tasks to maintain RDP backdoors.

techniques.name: Asynchronous Procedure Call
techniques.use: FIN8 has injected malicious code into a new svchost.exe process.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: FIN8's malicious spearphishing payloads are executed as PowerShell. FIN8 has also used PowerShell for lateral movement and credential access.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: FIN8 has used a Batch file to automate frequently executed post compromise cleanup activities.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: FIN8 has exploited the CVE-2016-0167 local vulnerability.

techniques.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
techniques.use: FIN8 has cleared logs during post compromise cleanup activities.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: FIN8 has deleted tmp and prefetch files during post compromise cleanup activities. FIN8 has also deleted PowerShell scripts to evade detection on compromised machines.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: FIN8 has used HTTPS for command and control.

techniques.name: Remote Data Staging
techniques.use: FIN8 aggregates staged data from a network into a single location.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: FIN8 has used valid accounts for persistence and lateral movement.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: FIN8 has used PowerShell Scripts to check the architecture of a compromised machine before the selection of a 32-bit or 64-bit version of a malicious .NET loader.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: FIN8 has used sslip.io, a free IP to domain mapping service that also makes SSL certificate generation easier for traffic encryption, as part of their command and control.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: FIN8 has used remote code execution to download subsequent payloads.

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: FIN8 has deleted Registry keys during post compromise cleanup activities.

techniques.name: Token Impersonation/Theft
techniques.use: FIN8 has used a malicious framework designed to impersonate the lsass.exe/vmtoolsd.exe token.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: FIN8 has used emails with malicious links to lure victims into installing malware.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: FIN8 has used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malware.

techniques.name: Domain Trust Discovery
techniques.use: FIN8 has retrieved a list of trusted domains by using nltest.exe /domain_trusts.

techniques.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
techniques.use: FIN8 has deployed ransomware such as Ragnar Locker, White Rabbit, and attempted to execute Noberus on compromised networks.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: FIN8 has used Registry keys to detect and avoid executing in potential sandboxes.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
techniques.use: FIN8 has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: FIN8 has used RAR to compress collected data before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing Word documents with embedded malicious macros.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing links to malicious documents with embedded macros.

techniques.name: Asymmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: FIN8 has used the Plink utility to tunnel RDP back to C2 infrastructure.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: FIN8 has used open-source tools such as Impacket for targeting efforts.

techniques.name: Code Signing Certificates
techniques.use: FIN8 has used an expired open-source X.509 certificate for testing in the OpenSSL repository, to connect to actor-controlled C2 servers.

name: FOXY PANDA
description: Adversary group targeting telecommunication and technology organizations.

name: Fail0verflow
description: Fail0verflow is a hacking group known for exploiting vulnerabilities in gaming consoles, notably the Nintendo Wii and PlayStation 3. They utilized techniques such as RAM shorting, buffer overflow, and a signing bug to achieve code execution and develop the Homebrew Channel for the Wii. In 2010, they compromised an ECDSA key for the PS3, and later announced the retrieval of PS5 symmetric root keys, enabling the potential for custom firmware and homebrew software. Their exploits often involve kernel access and have raised concerns about the implications for piracy and litigation in the gaming community.

name: Ferocious Kitten
description: Ferocious Kitten is a threat group that has primarily targeted Persian-speaking individuals in Iran since at least 2015.

techniques.use: Ferocious Kitten has named malicious files update.exe and loaded them into the compromise host's "Public"folder.
Ferocious Kitten has attempted to convince victims to enable malicious content within a spearphishing email by including an odd decoy message.
Ferocious Kitten has conducted spearphishing campaigns containing malicious documents to lure victims to open the attachments.
Ferocious Kitten has acquired domains imitating legitimate sites.
Ferocious Kitten has obtained open source tools for its operations, including JsonCPP and Psiphon.

name: Fishing Elephant
description: (Kaspersky) During the last months of 2019, we observed an ongoing campaign conducted by Fishing Elephant. The group continues to use both Heroku and Dropbox in order to deliver its tool of choice, AresRAT. We discovered that the actor incorporated a new technique into its operations that is meant to hinder manual and automatic analysis – geo-fencing and hiding executables within certificate files.
