techniques.use: Inception used a file hunting plugin to collect .txt, .pdf, .xls or .doc files from the infected host.
Inception has encrypted malware payloads dropped on victim machines with AES and RC4 encryption.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Inception has used a reconnaissance module to identify active processes and other associated loaded modules.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Inception has used PowerShell to execute malicious commands and payloads.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: Inception has used VBScript to execute malicious commands and payloads.

techniques.name: Domain Groups
techniques.use: Inception has used specific malware modules to gather domain membership.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Inception has used HTTP, HTTPS, and WebDav in network communications.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Inception has used a reconnaissance module to gather information about the operating system and hardware on the infected host.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Inception used a file listing plugin to collect information about file and directories both on local and remote drives.

techniques.name: Multi-hop Proxy
techniques.use: Inception used chains of compromised routers to proxy C2 communications between them and cloud service providers.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: Inception has incorporated at least five different cloud service providers into their C2 infrastructure including CloudMe.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: Inception has exploited CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2014-1761, CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2018-0802 for execution.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Inception lured victims into clicking malicious files for machine reconnaissance and to execute malware.

techniques.name: Mshta
techniques.use: Inception has used malicious HTA files to drop and execute malware.

techniques.name: Regsvr32
techniques.use: Inception has ensured persistence at system boot by setting the value regsvr32 %path%\ctfmonrn.dll /s.

techniques.name: Template Injection
techniques.use: Inception has used decoy documents to load malicious remote payloads via HTTP.

techniques.name: Software Discovery
techniques.use: Inception has enumerated installed software on compromised systems.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Inception has maintained persistence by modifying Registry run key value HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: Inception used a browser plugin to steal passwords and sessions from Internet Explorer, Chrome, Opera, Firefox, Torch, and Yandex.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Inception has used weaponized documents attached to spearphishing emails for reconnaissance and initial compromise.

techniques.name: Symmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: Inception has encrypted network communications with AES.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Inception has obtained and used open-source tools such as LaZagne.

name: IndigoZebra
description: IndigoZebra is a suspected Chinese cyber espionage group that has been targeting Central Asian governments since at least 2014.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: IndigoZebra has downloaded additional files and tools from its C2 server.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: IndigoZebra sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments that urged recipients to review modifications in the file which would trigger the attack.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: IndigoZebra sent spearphishing emails containing malicious password-protected RAR attachments.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: IndigoZebra has established domains, some of which were designed to look like official government domains, for their operations.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: IndigoZebra created Dropbox accounts for their operations.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: IndigoZebra has compromised legitimate email accounts to use in their spearphishing operations.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: IndigoZebra has acquired open source tools such as NBTscan and Meterpreter for their operations.

name: Indra
description:
(Check Point) Check Point Research (CPR) warns governments everywhere of the importance of protecting critical infrastructure, as it learns that the July 9 cyber attack on Iran’s train system was carried out by Indra, a group that identifies itself as regime opposition and has the capability to wipe out data without direct means for recovery.

• CPR analyzed artifacts left by the July 9 cyber attack on Iran’s train system, attributing the attacks to a group that self-identifies as Indra
• CPR confirms that Indra was also responsible for cyber attacks against multiple companies in Syria in 2019 and 2020
• CPR cites cyber attack on Iran’s train system as an example for governments around the world of how a single group can create disruption on critical infrastructure

name: Infy
description:
Since early 2013, we have observed activity from a unique threat actor group, which we began to investigate based on increased activities against human right activists in the beginning of 2015. In line5with other research on the campaign, released prior to publication of this document, we have adopted the name “Infy”, which is based on labels used in the infrastructure and its two families of malware agents.

Thanks to information we have been able to collect during the course of our research, such as characteristics of the group’s malware and development cycle, our research strongly supports the claim that the Infy group is of Iranian origin and potentially connected to the Iranian state. Amongst a backdrop of other incidents, Infy became one of the most frequently observed agents for attempted malware attacks against Iranian civil society beginning in late 2014, growing in use up to the February 2016 parliamentary election in Iran. After the conclusion of the parliamentary election, the rate of attempted intrusions and new compromises through the Infy agent slowed, but did not end. The trends witnessed in reports from recipients are reinforced through telemetry provided by design failures in more recent versions of the Infy malware.

name: IntelBroker
description: IntelBroker is a threat actor known for orchestrating high-profile data breaches targeting companies like Apple, Zscaler, and Facebook Marketplace. They have a reputation for selling access to compromised systems and data on underground forums like BreachForums. IntelBroker has claimed responsibility for breaches involving government agencies such as Europol, the U.S. Department of Transportation, and the Pentagon, leaking sensitive information and classified documents. The actor has been linked to breaches at companies like Acuity, General Electric, and Home Depot, showcasing a pattern of targeting critical infrastructure and major corporations.

name: InvisiMole
description:
(ESET) This is the modus operandi of the two malicious components of InvisiMole. They turn the affected computer into a video camera, letting the attackers see and hear what’s going on in the victim’s office or wherever their device may be. Uninvited, InvisiMole’s operators access the system, closely monitoring the victim’s activities and stealing the victim’s secrets.

Our telemetry indicates that the malicious actors behind this malware have been active at least since 2013, yet the cyber-espionage tool was never analyzed nor detected until discovered by ESET products on compromised computers in Ukraine and Russia.

The campaign is highly targeted – no wonder the malware has a low infection ratio, with only a few dozen computers being affected.

ESET also found that InvisiMole targeted computers already compromised by Gamaredon Group.

name: IronHusky
description: (Kaspersky) IronHusky is a Chinese-speaking actor that we first detected in summer 2017. It is very focused on tracking the geopolitical agenda of targets in central Asia with a special focus in Mongolia, which seems to be an unusual target. This actor crafts campaigns for upcoming events of interest. In this case, they prepared and launched one right before a meeting with the International Monetary Fund and the Mongolian government at the end of January 2018. At the same time, they stopped their previous operations targeting Russian military contractors, which speaks volumes about the group’s limitations. In this new campaign, they exploited CVE-2017-11882 to spread common RATs typically used by Chinese-speaking groups, such as PlugX and PoisonIvy.

name: JuiceLedger
description: JuiceLedger is a threat actor known for infostealing through their JuiceStealer .NET assembly. They have evolved from spreading fraudulent applications to conducting supply chain attacks, targeting PyPI contributors with phishing campaigns and typosquatting. Their malicious packages contain a code snippet that downloads and executes JuiceStealer, which has evolved to support additional browsers and Discord. Victims of JuiceLedger attacks are advised to reset passwords and report any suspicious activity to security@pypi.org.

name: KAX17
description: KAX17 is a sophisticated threat actor that has been active since at least 2017. They have operated hundreds of malicious servers within the Tor network, primarily as entry and middle points. Their main objective appears to be collecting information on Tor users and mapping their routes within the network. Despite efforts to remove their servers, KAX17 has shown resilience and continues to operate.

name: Karakurt
description: Karakurt actors have employed a variety of tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), creating significant challenges for defense and mitigation. Karakurt victims have not reported encryption of compromised machines or files; rather, Karakurt actors have claimed to steal data and threatened to auction it off or release it to the public unless they receive payment of the demanded ransom. Known ransom demands have ranged from $25,000 to $13,000,000 in Bitcoin, with payment deadlines typically set to expire within a week of first contact with the victim.

name: Karkadann
description: (Kaspersky) Karkadann is a threat actor that has been targeting government bodies and news outlets in the Middle East since at least October 2020. The threat actor leverages tailor-made malicious documents with embedded macros that trigger an infection chain, opening a URL in Internet Explorer. The minimal functionality present in the macros and the browser specification suggest that the threat actor might be exploiting a privilege-escalation vulnerability in Internet Explorer. Despite the small amount of evidence available for analysis in the Karkadann case, we were able to find several similarities to the Piwiks case, a watering-hole attack we discovered that targeted multiple prominent websites in the Middle East.

name: Kasablanka
description:
The Kasablanka group is a cyber-criminal organization that has
specifically targeted Russia between September and December 2022,
using various payloads delivered through phishing emails containing
socially engineered lnk files, zip packages, and executables attached to
virtual disk image files.

name: Ke3chang
description: Ke3chang is a threat group attributed to actors operating out of China. Ke3chang has targeted oil, government, diplomatic, military, and NGOs in Central and South America, the Caribbean, Europe, and North America since at least 2010.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: Ke3chang has dumped credentials, including by using Mimikatz.

techniques.name: Security Account Manager
techniques.use: Ke3chang has dumped credentials, including by using gsecdump.

techniques.name: NTDS
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used NTDSDump and other password dumping tools to gather credentials.

techniques.name: LSA Secrets
techniques.use: Ke3chang has dumped credentials, including by using gsecdump.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Ke3chang gathered information and files from local directories for exfiltration.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang performs service discovery using net start commands.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang has performed local network configuration discovery using ipconfig.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used network scanning and enumeration tools, including Ping.

techniques.name: Automated Exfiltration
techniques.use: Ke3chang has performed frequent and scheduled data exfiltration from compromised networks.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: Ke3chang actors have been known to copy files to the network shares of other computers to move laterally.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used Base64-encoded shellcode strings.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used implants capable of collecting the signed-in username.

techniques.name: Right-to-Left Override
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used the right-to-left override character in spearphishing attachment names to trick targets into executing .scr and .exe files.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has disguised their backdoor droppers with naming conventions designed to blend into normal operations.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: Ke3chang has dropped their malware into legitimate installed software paths including: C:\ProgramFiles\Realtek\Audio\HDA\AERTSr.exe, C:\Program Files (x86)\Foxit Software\Foxit Reader\FoxitRdr64.exe, C:\Program Files (x86)\Adobe\Flash Player\AddIns\airappinstaller\airappinstall.exe, and C:\Program Files (x86)\Adobe\Acrobat Reader DC\Reader\AcroRd64.exe.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: Ke3chang transferred compressed and encrypted RAR files containing exfiltration through the established backdoor command and control channel during operations.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has used SMBTouch, a vulnerability scanner, to determine whether a target is vulnerable to EternalBlue malware.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang performs local network connection discovery using netstat.

techniques.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has dropped legitimate software onto a compromised host and used it to execute malicious DLLs.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used keyloggers.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang performs process discovery using tasklist commands.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.use: Malware used by Ke3chang can run commands on the command-line interface.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used batch scripts in its malware to install persistence mechanisms.

techniques.name: Domain Groups
techniques.use: Ke3chang performs discovery of permission groups net group /domain.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Ke3chang malware including RoyalCli and BS2005 have communicated over HTTP with the C2 server through Internet Explorer (IE) by using the COM interface IWebBrowser2.

techniques.name: DNS
techniques.use: Ke3chang malware RoyalDNS has used DNS for C2.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has copied files of interest to the main drive's recycle bin.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used credential dumpers or stealers to obtain legitimate credentials, which they used to gain access to victim accounts.

techniques.name: Cloud Accounts
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used compromised credentials to sign into victims’ Microsoft 365 accounts.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang performs operating system information discovery using systeminfo and has used implants to identify the system language and computer name.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang uses command-line interaction to search files and directories.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: Ke3chang performs account discovery using commands such as net localgroup administrators and net group "REDACTED"/domain on specific permissions groups.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: Ke3chang performs account discovery using commands such as net localgroup administrators and net group "REDACTED"/domain on specific permissions groups.

techniques.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has used EarthWorm for network tunneling with a SOCKS5 server and port transfer functionalities.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used tools to download files to compromised machines.

techniques.name: Remote Email Collection
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used compromised credentials and a .NET tool to dump data from Microsoft Exchange mailboxes.

techniques.name: Automated Collection
techniques.use: Ke3chang has performed frequent and scheduled data collection from victim networks.

techniques.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has used an executable to detect removable media, such as USB flash drives.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: Ke3chang has gained access through VPNs including with compromised accounts and stolen VPN certificates.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: Ke3chang has deobfuscated Base64-encoded shellcode strings prior to loading them.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.use: Ke3chang has compromised networks by exploiting Internet-facing applications, including vulnerable Microsoft Exchange and SharePoint servers.

techniques.name: Sharepoint
techniques.use: Ke3chang used a SharePoint enumeration and data dumping tool known as spwebmember.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has used web shells to establish an initial foothold and for lateral movement within a victim's system.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: Ke3chang backdoor RoyalDNS established persistence through adding a service called Nwsapagent.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Several Ke3chang backdoors achieved persistence by adding a Run key.

techniques.name: Golden Ticket
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used Mimikatz to generate Kerberos golden tickets.

techniques.name: Archive Collected Data
techniques.use: The Ke3chang group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: Ke3chang is known to use 7Zip and RAR with passwords to encrypt data prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Service Execution
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used a tool known as RemoteExec (similar to PsExec) to remotely execute batch scripts and binaries.

techniques.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has executed DLL search order hijacking.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: Ke3chang has developed custom malware that allowed them to maintain persistence on victim networks.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: BackdoorDiplomacy has obtained and used leaked malware, including DoublePulsar, EternalBlue, EternalRocks, and EternalSynergy, in its operations.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Ke3chang has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz.

techniques.name: System Language Discovery
techniques.use: Ke3chang has used implants to collect the system language ID of a compromised machine.

name: Keksec
description: The threat group behind EnemyBot, Keksec, is well-resourced and has the ability to update and add new capabilities to its arsenal of malware on a daily basis (see below for more detail on Keksec)

name: Kelvin SecTeam
description: KelvinSecTeam is a probable Russian hacking organization with a robust presence on Deep and Dark Web forums popular with hackers and cybercriminals, with probable team members in Central and South America — and they are growing.

name: KelvinSecurity
description: KelvinSecurity is a hacker group that has been active since at least 2015. They are known for their hacktivist and black hat activities, targeting public and private organizations globally. The group sells and leaks databases, documents, and access belonging to their victims, often on the dark web or their own platforms. They have been involved in attacks against various sectors, including telecommunications, political parties, and healthcare.

name: Killnet
description: A group targeting various countries using Denial of Services attacked.

name: Kimsuky
description: Kimsuky is a North Korea-based cyber espionage group that has been active since at least 2012. The group initially focused on targeting South Korean government entities, think tanks, and individuals identified as experts in various fields, and expanded its operations to include the United States, Russia, Europe, and the UN. Kimsuky has focused its intelligence collection activities on foreign policy and national security issues related to the Korean peninsula, nuclear policy, and sanctions.Kimsuky was assessed to be responsible for the 2014 Korea Hydro & Nuclear Power Co. compromise; other notable campaigns include Operation STOLEN PENCIL (2018), Operation Kabar Cobra (2019), and Operation Smoke Screen (2019).North Korean group definitions are known to have significant overlap, and some security researchers report all North Korean state-sponsored cyber activity under the name Lazarus Group instead of tracking clusters or subgroups.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: Kimsuky has gathered credentials using Mimikatz and ProcDump.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Kimsuky has collected Office, PDF, and HWP documents from its victims.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used an instrumentor script to gather the names of all services running on a victim's system.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: Kimsuky has obtained specific Registry keys and values on a compromised host.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used ipconfig/all to gather network configuration information.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used RDP for direct remote point-and-click access.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.use: Kimsuky has obfuscated binary strings including the use of XOR encryption and Base64 encoding.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: Kimsuky has packed malware with UPX.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: Kimsuky has disguised services to appear as benign software or related to operating system functions.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: Kimsuky has renamed malware to legitimate names such as ESTCommon.dll or patch.dll.

techniques.name: Network Sniffing
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used the Nirsoft SniffPass network sniffer to obtain passwords sent over non-secure protocols.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: Kimsuky has exfiltrated data over its C2 channel.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: Kimsuky has downloaded additional malware with scheduled tasks.

techniques.name: Process Injection
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used Win7Elevate to inject malicious code into explorer.exe.

techniques.name: Process Hollowing
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used a file injector DLL to spawn a benign process on the victim's system and inject the malicious payload into it via process hollowing.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used a PowerShell-based keylogger as well as a tool called MECHANICAL to log keystrokes.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Kimsuky can gather a list of all processes running on a victim's machine.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Kimsuky has executed a variety of PowerShell scripts.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Kimsuky has executed Windows commands by using cmd and running batch scripts.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used Visual Basic to download malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Python
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used a macOS Python implant to gather data as well as MailFetcher.py code to automatically collect email data.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used JScript for logging and downloading additional tools.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: Kimsuky has deleted the exfiltrated data on disk after transmission. Kimsuky has also used an instrumentor script to terminate browser processes running on an infected system and then delete the cookie files on disk.

techniques.name: Timestomp
techniques.use: Kimsuky has manipulated timestamps for creation or compilation dates to defeat anti-forensics.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used HTTP GET and POST requests for C2.

techniques.name: File Transfer Protocols
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used FTP to download additional malware to the target machine.

techniques.name: Mail Protocols
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used e-mail to send exfiltrated data to C2 servers.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: Kimsuky has staged collected data files under C:\Program Files\Common Files\System\Ole DB\.

techniques.name: Local Accounts
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used a tool called GREASE to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them continued access via RDP.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Kimsuky has enumerated drives, OS type, OS version, and other information using a script or the "systeminfo"command.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Kimsuky has the ability to enumerate all files and directories on an infected system.

techniques.name: Account Manipulation
techniques.use: Kimsuky has added accounts to specific groups with net localgroup.

techniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used Blogspot pages for C2.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Kimsuky has downloaded additional scripts, tools, and malware onto victim systems.

techniques.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Interception
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used a proprietary tool to intercept one time passwords required for two-factor authentication.

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: Kimsuky has modified Registry settings for default file associations to enable all macros and for persistence.

techniques.name: Remote Email Collection
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used tools such as the MailFetch mail crawler to collect victim emails (excluding spam) from online services via IMAP.

techniques.name: Email Forwarding Rule
techniques.use: Kimsuky has set auto-forward rules on victim's e-mail accounts.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used RDP to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: Kimsuky has created accounts with net user.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: Kimsuky has decoded malicious VBScripts using Base64.

techniques.name: Browser Extensions
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used Google Chrome browser extensions to infect victims and to steal passwords and cookies.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.use: Kimsuky has exploited various vulnerabilities for initial access, including Microsoft Exchange vulnerability CVE-2020-0688.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: Kimsuky has lured victims into clicking malicious links.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used attempted to lure victims into opening malicious e-mail attachments.

techniques.name: Mshta
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used mshta.exe to run malicious scripts on the system.

techniques.name: Regsvr32
techniques.use: Kimsuky has executed malware with regsvr32s.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used rundll32.exe to execute malicious scripts and malware on a victim's network.

techniques.name: Remote Access Software
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used a modified TeamViewer client as a command and control channel.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used modified versions of open source PHP web shells to maintain access, often adding "Dinosaur"references within the code.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: Kimsuky has checked for the presence of antivirus software with powershell Get-CimInstance -Namespace root/securityCenter2 – classname antivirusproduct.

techniques.name: Internal Spearphishing
techniques.use: Kimsuky has sent internal spearphishing emails for lateral movement after stealing victim information.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: Kimsuky has created new services for persistence.

techniques.name: Change Default File Association
techniques.use: Kimsuky has a HWP document stealer module which changes the default program association in the registry to open HWP documents.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Kimsuky has placed scripts in the startup folder for persistence and modified the HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce Registry key.

techniques.name: Pass the Hash
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used pass the hash for authentication to remote access software used in C2.

techniques.name: Credentials In Files
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from saved mail.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: Kimsuky has signed files with the name EGIS CO,. Ltd..

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used browser extensions including Google Chrome to steal passwords and cookies from browsers. Kimsuky has also used Nirsoft's WebBrowserPassView tool to dump the passwords obtained from victims.

techniques.name: Adversary-in-the-Middle
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used modified versions of PHProxy to examine web traffic between the victim and the accessed website.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used QuickZip to archive stolen files before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Archive via Custom Method
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used RC4 encryption before exfil.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: Kimsuky has been observed turning off Windows Security Center and can hide the AV software window from the view of the infected user.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
techniques.use: Kimsuky has been observed disabling the system firewall.

techniques.name: Hidden Users
techniques.use: Kimsuky has run reg add ‘HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\UserList’ /v to hide a newly created user.

techniques.name: Hidden Window
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used an information gathering module that will hide an AV software window from the victim.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used emails containing Word, Excel and/or HWP (Hangul Word Processor) documents in their spearphishing campaigns.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: Kimsuky has sent spearphishing emails containing a link to a document that contained malicious macros or took the victim to an actor-controlled domain.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: Kimsuky has exfiltrated stolen files and data to actor-controlled Blogspot accounts.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: Kimsuky has registered domains to spoof targeted organizations and trusted third parties.

techniques.name: Server
techniques.use: Kimsuky has purchased hosting servers with virtual currency and prepaid cards.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: Kimsuky has hosted content used for targeting efforts via web services such as Blogspot.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: Kimsuky has compromised legitimate sites and used them to distribute malware.

techniques.name: Social Media Accounts
techniques.use: Kimsuky has created social media accounts to monitor news and security trends as well as potential targets.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: Kimsuky has created email accounts for phishing operations.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: Kimsuky has compromised email accounts to send spearphishing e-mails.

techniques.name: Develop Capabilities
techniques.use: Kimsuky created and used a mailing toolkit to use in spearphishing attacks.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: Kimsuky has developed its own unique malware such as MailFetch.py for use in operations.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Kimsuky has obtained and used tools such as Nirsoft WebBrowserPassVIew, Mimikatz, and PsExec.

techniques.name: Exploits
techniques.use: Kimsuky has obtained exploit code for various CVEs.

techniques.name: Email Addresses
techniques.use: Kimsuky has collected valid email addresses that were subsequently used in spearphishing campaigns.

techniques.name: Employee Names
techniques.use: Kimsuky has collected victim employee name information.

techniques.name: Gather Victim Org Information
techniques.use: Kimsuky has collected victim organization information including but not limited to organization hierarchy, functions, press releases, and others.

techniques.name: Social Media
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used Twitter to monitor potential victims and to prepare targeted phishing e-mails.

techniques.name: Search Engines
techniques.use: Kimsuky has searched for vulnerabilities, tools, and geopolitical trends on Google to target victims.

techniques.name: Search Victim-Owned Websites
techniques.use: Kimsuky has searched for information on the target company's website.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used links in e-mail to steal account information.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: Kimsuky has used Blogspot to host malicious content such as beacons, file exfiltrators, and implants.

name: Kinsing
description: This group started operating during the first quarter of 2022. They published samples of alleged stolen data from companies on their site on Tor. It is unclear if they conducted the attacks themselves, or if they bought leaked databases from third parties.

name: Kiss-a-Dog
description: CrowdStrike identified a cryptojacking campaign targeting vulnerable Docker and Kubernetes infrastructure. Called “Kiss-a-dog,” the campaign targets Docker and Kubernetes infrastructure using an obscure domain from the payload, container escape attempt and anonymized “dog” mining pools.

name: KromSec
description: KromSec is a hacktivist group that claims to be composed of hackers, activists, writers, and journalists. The group has been involved in a number of high-profile cyberattacks, including a cyber offensive against Iran in September 2022 and the sale of the database of the Iran Ministry of Industries and Mines on a hacker forum in November 2023. KromSec's attacks have been met with mixed reactions, but the group has quickly made a name for itself as a significant threat to governments and organizations around the world.

name: LAPSUS$
description: LAPSUS$ is cyber criminal threat group that has been active since at least mid-2021. LAPSUS$ specializes in large-scale social engineering and extortion operations, including destructive attacks without the use of ransomware. The group has targeted organizations globally, including in the government, manufacturing, higher education, energy, healthcare, technology, telecommunications, and media sectors.

techniques.name: NTDS
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has used Windows built-in tool ntdsutil to extract the Active Directory (AD) database.

techniques.name: DCSync
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has used DCSync attacks to gather credentials for privilege escalation routines.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ uploaded sensitive files, information, and credentials from a targeted organization for extortion or public release.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has exploited unpatched vulnerabilities on internally accessible servers including JIRA, GitLab, and Confluence for privilege escalation.

techniques.name: Domain Groups
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has used the AD Explorer tool to enumerate groups on a victim's network.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has used compromised credentials and/or session tokens to gain access into a victim's VPN, VDI, RDP, and IAMs.

techniques.name: Cloud Accounts
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has used compromised credentials to access cloud assets within a target organization.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has used the AD Explorer tool to enumerate users on a victim's network.

techniques.name: Proxy
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has leverage NordVPN for its egress points when targeting intended victims.

techniques.name: Additional Cloud Roles
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has added the global admin role to accounts they have created in the targeted organization's cloud instances.

techniques.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Interception
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has replayed stolen session token and passwords to trigger simple-approval MFA prompts in hope of the legitimate user will grant necessary approval.

techniques.name: Email Forwarding Rule
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has set an Office 365 tenant level mail transport rule to send all mail in and out of the targeted organization to the newly created account.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has gained access to internet-facing systems and applications, including virtual private network (VPN), remote desktop protocol (RDP), and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) including Citrix.

techniques.name: Cloud Account
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has created global admin accounts in the targeted organization's cloud instances to gain persistence.

techniques.name: Trusted Relationship
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has accessed internet-facing identity providers such as Azure Active Directory and Okta to target specific organizations.

techniques.name: User Execution
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has recruited target organization employees or contractors who provide credentials and approve an associated MFA prompt, or install remote management software onto a corporate workstation, allowing LAPSUS$ to take control of an authenticated system.

techniques.name: Data from Information Repositories
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has searched a victim's network for organization collaboration channels like MS Teams or Slack to discover further high-privilege account credentials.

techniques.name: Confluence
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has searched a victim's network for collaboration platforms like Confluence and JIRA to discover further high-privilege account credentials.

techniques.name: Sharepoint
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has searched a victim's network for collaboration platforms like SharePoint to discover further high-privilege account credentials.

techniques.name: Code Repositories
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has searched a victim's network for code repositories like GitLab and GitHub to discover further high-privilege account credentials.

techniques.name: Data Destruction
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has deleted the target's systems and resources both on-premises and in the cloud.

techniques.name: Service Stop
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has shut down virtual machines from within a victim's on-premise VMware ESXi infrastructure.

techniques.name: Account Access Removal
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has removed a targeted organization's global admin accounts to lock the organization out of all access.

techniques.name: Chat Messages
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has targeted various collaboration tools like Slack, Teams, JIRA, Confluence, and others to hunt for exposed credentials to support privilege escalation and lateral movement.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has obtained passwords and session tokens with the use of the Redline password stealer.

techniques.name: Password Managers
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has accessed local password managers and databases to obtain further credentials from a compromised network.

techniques.name: Create Cloud Instance
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has created new virtual machines within the target's cloud environment after leveraging credential access to cloud assets.

techniques.name: Delete Cloud Instance
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has deleted the target's systems and resources in the cloud to trigger the organization's incident and crisis response process.

techniques.name: Virtual Private Server
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has used VPS hosting providers for infrastructure.

techniques.name: DNS Server
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has reconfigured a victim's DNS records to actor-controlled domains and websites.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has payed employees, suppliers, and business partners of target organizations for credentials.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ acquired and used the Redline password stealer in their operations.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has obtained tools such as RVTools and AD Explorer for their operations.

techniques.name: Gather Victim Identity Information
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has gathered detailed information of target employees to enhance their social engineering lures.

techniques.name: Credentials
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has gathered user identities and credentials to gain initial access to a victim's organization; the group has also called an organization's help desk to reset a target's credentials.

techniques.name: Email Addresses
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has gathered employee email addresses, including personal accounts, for social engineering and initial access efforts.

techniques.name: Business Relationships
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has gathered detailed knowledge of an organization's supply chain relationships.

techniques.name: Identify Roles
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has gathered detailed knowledge of team structures within a target organization.

techniques.name: Code Repositories
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has searched public code repositories for exposed credentials.

techniques.name: Purchase Technical Data
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has purchased credentials and session tokens from criminal underground forums.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Voice
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has called victims' help desk to convince the support personnel to reset a privileged account’s credentials.

techniques.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Request Generation
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has spammed target users with MFA prompts in the hope that the legitimate user will grant necessary approval.

techniques.name: Impersonation
techniques.use: LAPSUS$ has called victims' help desk and impersonated legitimate users with previously gathered information in order to gain access to privileged accounts.

name: LUNAR SPIDER
description:
According to CrowdStrike, this actor is using BokBok/IcedID, potentially buying distribution through Emotet infections.
On March 17, 2019, CrowdStrike Intelligence observed the use of a new BokBot (developed and operated by LUNAR SPIDER) proxy module in conjunction with TrickBot (developed and operated by WIZARD SPIDER), which may provide WIZARD SPIDER with additional tools to steal sensitive information and conduct fraudulent wire transfers. This activity also provides further evidence to support the existence of a flourishing relationship between these two actors.
Lunar Spider is reportedly associated withGrim Spider and Wizard Spider.

name: LabHost
description: LabHost is a threat actor group targeting Canadian Banks with Phishing-as-a-Service attacks. They have been observed using tools like LabRat and LabSend for real-time campaign management and SMS lures. LabHost's phishing campaigns have similarities to Frappo campaigns, but they operate separately and offer different subscription packages.

name: Lancefly
description:
(Symantec) The Lancefly advanced persistent threat (APT) group is using a custom-written backdoor in attacks targeting organizations in South and Southeast Asia, in activity that has been ongoing for several years.

Lancefly may have some links to previously known groups, but these are low confidence, which led researchers at Symantec, by Broadcom Software, to classify this activity under a new group name.

Lancefly’s custom malware, which we have dubbed Merdoor, is a powerful backdoor that appears to have existed since 2018. Symantec researchers observed it being used in some activity in 2020 and 2021, as well as this more recent campaign, which continued into the first quarter of 2023. The motivation behind both these campaigns is believed to be intelligence gathering.

name: Lazarus Group
description: Lazarus Group is a North Korean state-sponsored cyber threat group that has been attributed to the Reconnaissance General Bureau. The group has been active since at least 2009 and was reportedly responsible for the November 2014 destructive wiper attack against Sony Pictures Entertainment as part of a campaign named Operation Blockbuster by Novetta. Malware used by Lazarus Group correlates to other reported campaigns, including Operation Flame, Operation 1Mission, Operation Troy, DarkSeoul, and Ten Days of Rain.North Korean group definitions are known to have significant overlap, and some security researchers report all North Korean state-sponsored cyber activity under the name Lazarus Group instead of tracking clusters or subgroups, such as Andariel, APT37, APT38, and Kimsuky.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has been observed targeting organizations using spearphishing documents with embedded malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Protocol Impersonation
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware also uses a unique form of communication encryption known as FakeTLS that mimics TLS but uses a different encryption method, potentially evading SSL traffic inspection/decryption.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has collected data and files from compromised networks.

techniques.name: Fallback Channels
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware SierraAlfa sends data to one of the hard-coded C2 servers chosen at random, and if the transmission fails, chooses a new C2 server to attempt the transmission again.

techniques.name: Application Window Discovery
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server the title of the window for each running process. The KilaAlfa keylogger also reports the title of the window in the foreground.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia checks Registry keys within HKCU and HKLM to determine if certain applications are present, including SecureCRT, Terminal Services, RealVNC, TightVNC, UltraVNC, Radmin, mRemote, TeamViewer, FileZilla, pcAnyware, and Remote Desktop. Another Lazarus Group malware sample checks for the presence of the following Registry key:HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server information about the first network interface card’s configuration, including IP address, gateways, subnet mask, DHCP information, and whether WINS is available.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware SierraCharlie uses RDP for propagation.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware SierraAlfa accesses the ADMIN$ share via SMB to conduct lateral movement.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: Lazarus Group used SSH and the PuTTy PSCP utility to gain access to a restricted segment of a compromised network.

Lazarus Group has used multiple types of encryption and encoding for their payloads, including AES, Caracachs, RC4, XOR, Base64, and other tricks such as creating aliases in code for Native API function names.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group packed malicious .db files with Themida to evade detection.

techniques.name: Steganography
techniques.use: Andariel has hidden malicious executables within PNG files.

techniques.name: Dynamic API Resolution
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used a custom hashing method to resolve APIs used in shellcode.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: Various Lazarus Group malware enumerates logged-on users.

techniques.name: Rename System Utilities
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has renamed system utilities such as wscript.exe and mshta.exe.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used a scheduled task named SRCheck to mask the execution of a malicious .dll.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has renamed malicious code to disguise it as Microsoft's narrator and other legitimate files.

techniques.name: Masquerade File Type
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group disguised malicious template files as JPEG files to avoid detection.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has exfiltrated data and files over a C2 channel through its various tools and malware.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used nmap from a router VM to scan ports on systems within the restricted segment of an enterprise network.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used WMIC for discovery as well as to execute payloads for persistence and lateral movement.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware SierraBravo-Two generates an email message via SMTP containing information about newly infected victims.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used net use to identify and establish a network connection with a remote host.

techniques.name: Cron
techniques.use: APT38 has used cron to create pre-scheduled and periodic background jobs on a Linux system.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used schtasks for persistence including through the periodic execution of a remote XSL script or a dropped VBS payload.

techniques.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
techniques.use: A Lazarus Group malware sample performs reflective DLL injection.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware KiloAlfa contains keylogging functionality.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Several Lazarus Group malware families gather a list of running processes on a victim system and send it to their C2 server. A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group also gathers process times.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used PowerShell to execute commands and malicious code.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware uses cmd.exe to execute commands on a compromised host.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used VBA and embedded macros in Word documents to execute malicious code.

techniques.name: Indicator Removal
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has restored malicious KernelCallbackTable code to its original state after the process execution flow has been hijacked.

techniques.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
techniques.use: APT38 clears Window Event logs and Sysmon logs from the system.

techniques.name: Clear Command History
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has routinely deleted log files on a compromised router, including automatic log deletion through the use of the logrotate utility.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware has deleted files in various ways, including "suicide scripts"to delete malware binaries from the victim. Lazarus Group also uses secure file deletion to delete files from the victim.

techniques.name: Timestomp
techniques.use: Several Lazarus Group malware families use timestomping, including modifying the last write timestamp of a specified Registry key to a random date, as well as copying the timestamp for legitimate .exe files (such as calc.exe or mspaint.exe) to its dropped files.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has conducted C2 over HTTP and HTTPS.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is saved in the %TEMP% directory, then compressed, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used administrator credentials to gain access to restricted network segments.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Several Lazarus Group malware families collect information on the type and version of the victim OS, as well as the victim computer name and CPU information. A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group also collects disk space information and sends it to its C2 server.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware can use a common function to identify target files by their extension, and some also enumerate files and directories, including a Destover-like variant that lists files and gathers information for all drives.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group queried compromised victim's active directory servers to obtain the list of employees including administrator accounts.

techniques.name: Internal Proxy
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used a compromised router to serve as a proxy between a victim network's corporate and restricted segments.

techniques.name: External Proxy
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used multiple proxies to obfuscate network traffic from victims.

techniques.name: Account Manipulation
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware WhiskeyDelta-Two contains a function that attempts to rename the administrator’s account.

techniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used GitHub as C2, pulling hosted image payloads then committing command execution output to files in specific directories.

techniques.name: Multi-Stage Channels
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used multi-stage malware components that inject later stages into separate processes.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has downloaded files, malware, and tools from its C2 onto a compromised host.

techniques.name: Native API
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used the Windows API ObtainUserAgentString to obtain the User-Agent from a compromised host to connect to a C2 server.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.use: APT38 has used brute force techniques to attempt account access when passwords are unknown or when password hashes are unavailable.

techniques.name: Password Spraying
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware attempts to connect to Windows shares for lateral movement by using a generated list of usernames, which center around permutations of the username Administrator, and weak passwords.

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: APT38 uses a tool called CLEANTOAD that has the capability to modify Registry keys.

techniques.name: Clipboard Data
techniques.use: APT38 used a Trojan called KEYLIME to collect data from the clipboard.

techniques.name: System Time Discovery
techniques.use: A Destover-like implant used by Lazarus Group can obtain the current system time and send it to the C2 server.

techniques.name: Standard Encoding
techniques.use: A Lazarus Group malware sample encodes data with base64.

techniques.name: Create Process with Token
techniques.use: Lazarus Group keylogger KiloAlfa obtains user tokens from interactive sessions to execute itself with API call CreateProcessAsUserA under that user's context.

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: APT38 has enumerated network shares on a compromised host.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used shellcode within macros to decrypt and manually map DLLs and shellcode into memory at runtime.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Lazarus Group delivered RATANKBA and other malicious code to victims via a compromised legitimate website.

techniques.name: Indirect Command Execution
techniques.use: Lazarus Group persistence mechanisms have used forfiles.exe to execute .htm files.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has exploited Adobe Flash vulnerability CVE-2018-4878 for execution.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group lured users into executing a malicious link to disclose private account information or provide initial access.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has attempted to get users to launch a malicious Microsoft Word attachment delivered via a spearphishing email.

techniques.name: Browser Information Discovery
techniques.use: APT38 has collected browser bookmark information to learn more about compromised hosts, obtain personal information about users, and acquire details about internal network resources.

techniques.name: System Binary Proxy Execution
techniques.use: Lazarus Group lnk files used for persistence have abused the Windows Update Client (wuauclt.exe) to execute a malicious DLL.

techniques.name: Compiled HTML File
techniques.use: APT38 has used CHM files to move concealed payloads.

techniques.name: Mshta
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used mshta.exe to execute HTML pages downloaded by initial access documents.

techniques.name: Regsvr32
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used regsvr32 to execute malware.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used rundll32 to execute malicious payloads on a compromised host.

techniques.name: XSL Script Processing
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used a remote XSL script to download a Base64-encoded DLL custom downloader.

techniques.name: Template Injection
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used DOCX files to retrieve a malicious document template/DOTM file.

techniques.name: Data Destruction
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used a custom secure delete function to overwrite file contents with data from heap memory.

techniques.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
techniques.use: APT38 has used Hermes ransomware to encrypt files with AES256.

techniques.name: Service Stop
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has stopped the MSExchangeIS service to render Exchange contents inaccessible to users.

techniques.name: Internal Defacement
techniques.use: Lazarus Group replaced the background wallpaper of systems with a threatening image after rendering the system unbootable with a Disk Structure Wipe.

techniques.name: System Checks
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used tools that conducted a variety of system checks to detect sandboxes or VMware services.

techniques.name: Time Based Evasion
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used tools that collected GetTickCount and GetSystemTimeAsFileTime data to detect sandbox or VMware services.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: APT38 has used web shells for persistence or to ensure redundant access.

techniques.name: IIS Components
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group targeted Windows servers running Internet Information Systems (IIS) to install C2 components.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: APT38 has identified security software, configurations, defensive tools, and sensors installed on a compromised system.

techniques.name: System Shutdown/Reboot
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has rebooted systems after destroying files and wiping the MBR on infected systems.

techniques.name: Internal Spearphishing
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group conducted internal spearphishing from within a compromised organization.

techniques.name: Bootkit
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware WhiskeyAlfa-Three modifies sector 0 of the Master Boot Record (MBR) to ensure that the malware will persist even if a victim machine shuts down.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: Several Lazarus Group malware families install themselves as new services.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has maintained persistence by loading malicious code into a startup folder or by adding a Registry Run key.

techniques.name: Shortcut Modification
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware has maintained persistence on a system by creating a LNK shortcut in the user’s Startup folder.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has digitally signed malware and utilities to evade detection.

techniques.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay
techniques.use: Lazarus Group executed Responder using the command

techniques.name: Archive Collected Data
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has compressed exfiltrated data with RAR and used RomeoDelta malware to archive specified directories in .zip format, encrypt the .zip file, and upload it to C2.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group archived victim's data into a RAR file.

techniques.name: Archive via Library
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server.

techniques.name: Archive via Custom Method
techniques.use: A Lazarus Group malware sample encrypts data using a simple byte based XOR operation prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Disk Content Wipe
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used malware like WhiskeyAlfa to overwrite the first 64MB of every drive with a mix of static and random buffers. A similar process is then used to wipe content in logical drives and, finally, attempt to wipe every byte of every sector on every drive. WhiskeyBravo can be used to overwrite the first 4.9MB of physical drives. WhiskeyDelta can overwrite the first 132MB or 1.5MB of each drive with random data from heap memory.

techniques.name: Disk Structure Wipe
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware SHARPKNOT overwrites and deletes the Master Boot Record (MBR) on the victim's machine and has possessed MBR wiper malware since at least 2009.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: Lazarus Group malware TangoDelta attempts to terminate various processes associated with McAfee. Additionally, Lazarus Group malware SHARPKNOT disables the Microsoft Windows System Event Notification and Alerter services.

techniques.name: Impair Command History Logging
techniques.use: APT38 has prepended a space to all of their terminal commands to operate without leaving traces in the HISTCONTROL environment.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
techniques.use: Various Lazarus Group malware modifies the Windows firewall to allow incoming connections or disable it entirely using netsh.

techniques.name: Hidden Files and Directories
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used a VBA Macro to set its file attributes to System and Hidden and has named files with a dot prefix to hide them from the Finder application.

techniques.name: Stored Data Manipulation
techniques.use: APT38 has used DYEPACK to create, delete, and alter records in databases used for SWIFT transactions.

techniques.name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
techniques.use: APT38 has used DYEPACK to manipulate SWIFT messages en route to a printer.

techniques.name: Runtime Data Manipulation
techniques.use: APT38 has used DYEPACK.FOX to manipulate PDF data as it is accessed to remove traces of fraudulent SWIFT transactions from the data displayed to the end user.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has sent malicious links to victims via email.

techniques.name: Spearphishing via Service
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has used social media platforms, including LinkedIn and Twitter, to send spearphishing messages.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used a custom build of open-source command-line dbxcli to exfiltrate stolen data to Dropbox.

techniques.name: Service Execution
techniques.use: APT38 has created new services or modified existing ones to run executables, commands, or scripts.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.use: Some Lazarus Group malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, creating port-protocol mismatches.

techniques.name: Symmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: Several Lazarus Group malware families encrypt C2 traffic using custom code that uses XOR with an ADD operation and XOR with a SUB operation. Another Lazarus Group malware sample XORs C2 traffic. Other Lazarus Group malware uses Caracachs encryption to encrypt C2 payloads. Lazarus Group has also used AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has replaced win_fw.dll, an internal component that is executed during IDA Pro installation, with a malicious DLL to download and execute a payload.

techniques.name: KernelCallbackTable
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has abused the KernelCallbackTable to hijack process control flow and execute shellcode.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has acquired domains related to their campaigns to act as distribution points and C2 channels.

techniques.name: Server
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group acquired servers to host their malicious tools.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has hosted malicious downloads on Github.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: For Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group compromised domains in Italy and other countries for their C2 infrastructure.

techniques.name: Server
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has compromised servers to stage malicious tools.

techniques.name: Social Media Accounts
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has created new Twitter accounts to conduct social engineering against potential victims.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has created new email accounts for spearphishing operations.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has developed custom malware for use in their operations.

techniques.name: Code Signing Certificates
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group digitally signed their malware and the dbxcli utility.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: Andariel has used a variety of publicly-available remote access Trojans (RATs) for its operations.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has obtained a variety of tools for their operations, including Responder and PuTTy PSCP.

techniques.name: Code Signing Certificates
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used code signing certificates issued by Sectigo RSA for some of its malware and tools.

techniques.name: Digital Certificates
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has obtained SSL certificates for their C2 domains.

techniques.name: Email Addresses
techniques.use: Lazarus Group collected email addresses belonging to various departments of a targeted organization which were used in follow-on phishing campaigns.

techniques.name: IP Addresses
techniques.use: Andariel has limited its watering hole attacks to specific IP address ranges.

techniques.name: Gather Victim Org Information
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has studied publicly available information about a targeted organization to tailor spearphishing efforts against specific departments and/or individuals.

techniques.name: Identify Roles
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group targeted specific individuals within an organization with tailored job vacancy announcements.

techniques.name: Software
techniques.use: Andariel has inserted a malicious script within compromised websites to collect potential victim information such as browser type, system language, Flash Player version, and other data.

techniques.name: Social Media
techniques.use: For Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used LinkedIn to identify and target employees within a chosen organization.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: For Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used compromised servers to host malware.

techniques.name: Upload Tool
techniques.use: For Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used multiple servers to host malicious tools.

techniques.name: System Language Discovery
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group deployed malware designed not to run on computers set to Korean, Japanese, or Chinese in Windows language preferences.

techniques.name: Reflective Code Loading
techniques.use: Lazarus Group has changed memory protection permissions then overwritten in memory DLL function code with shellcode, which was later executed via KernelCallbackTable hijacking. Lazarus Group has also used shellcode within macros to decrypt and manually map DLLs into memory at runtime.

techniques.name: Debugger Evasion
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used tools that used the IsDebuggerPresent call to detect debuggers.

techniques.name: Impersonation
techniques.use: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group impersonated HR hiring personnel through LinkedIn messages and conducted interviews with victims in order to deceive them into downloading malware.

name: LazyScripter
description: LazyScripter is threat group that has mainly targeted the airlines industry since at least 2018, primarily using open-source toolsets.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: LazyScripter has leveraged the BatchEncryption tool to perform advanced batch script obfuscation and encoding techniques.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used several different security software icons to disguise executables.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used PowerShell scripts to execute malicious code.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used batch files to deploy open-source and multi-stage RATs.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used VBScript to execute malicious code.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used JavaScript in its attacks.

techniques.name: DNS
techniques.use: LazyScripter has leveraged dynamic DNS providers for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used GitHub to host its payloads to operate spam campaigns.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: LazyScripter had downloaded additional tools to a compromised host.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: LazyScripter has relied upon users clicking on links to malicious files.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: LazyScripter has lured users to open malicious email attachments.

techniques.name: Mshta
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used mshta.exe to execute Koadic stagers.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used rundll32.exe to execute Koadic stagers.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: LazyScripter has achieved persistence via writing a PowerShell script to the autorun registry key.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used spam emails weaponized with archive or document files as its initial infection vector.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used spam emails that contain a link that redirects the victim to download a malicious document.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used dynamic DNS providers to create legitimate-looking subdomains for C2.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: LazyScripter has established GitHub accounts to host its toolsets.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: LazyScripter has used a variety of open-source remote access Trojans for its operations.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: LazyScripter has hosted open-source remote access Trojans used in its operations in GitHub.

name: Leafminer
description: Leafminer is an Iranian threat group that has targeted government organizations and business entities in the Middle East since at least early 2017.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: Leafminer used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne and Mimikatz.

techniques.name: LSA Secrets
techniques.use: Leafminer used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

techniques.name: Cached Domain Credentials
techniques.use: Leafminer used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Leafminer used Microsoft’s Sysinternals tools to gather detailed information about remote systems.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: Leafminer obfuscated scripts that were used on victim machines.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: Leafminer scanned network services to search for vulnerabilities in the victim system.

techniques.name: Process Doppelgänging
techniques.use: Leafminer has used Process Doppelgänging to evade security software while deploying tools on compromised systems.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: Leafminer infected victims using JavaScript code.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Leafminer used a tool called MailSniper to search for files on the desktop and another utility called Sobolsoft to extract attachments from EML files.

techniques.name: Password Spraying
techniques.use: Leafminer used a tool called Total SMB BruteForcer to perform internal password spraying.

techniques.name: Remote Email Collection
techniques.use: Leafminer used a tool called MailSniper to search through the Exchange server mailboxes for keywords.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: Leafminer used a tool called Imecab to set up a persistent remote access account on the victim machine.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Leafminer has infected victims using watering holes.

techniques.name: Credentials In Files
techniques.use: Leafminer used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

techniques.name: Credentials from Password Stores
techniques.use: Leafminer used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: Leafminer used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Leafminer has obtained and used tools such as LaZagne, Mimikatz, PsExec, and MailSniper.

name: Leviathan
description: Leviathan is a Chinese state-sponsored cyber espionage group that has been attributed to the Ministry of State Security's (MSS) Hainan State Security Department and an affiliated front company. Active since at least 2009, Leviathan has targeted the following sectors: academia, aerospace/aviation, biomedical, defense industrial base, government, healthcare, manufacturing, maritime, and transportation across the US, Canada, Europe, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, Ministry of State Security, Hainan province

techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.use: Leviathan has used publicly available tools to dump password hashes, including HOMEFRY.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: Leviathan has used publicly available tools to dump password hashes, including ProcDump and WCE.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: Leviathan has targeted RDP credentials and used it to move through the victim environment.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: Leviathan used ssh for internal reconnaissance.
Leviathan has obfuscated code using base64 and gzip compression.

techniques.name: Binary Padding
techniques.use: Leviathan has inserted garbage characters into code, presumably to avoid anti-virus detection.

techniques.name: Steganography
techniques.use: Leviathan has used steganography to hide stolen data inside other files stored on Github.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: Leviathan has exfiltrated data over its C2 channel.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: Leviathan has used WMI for execution.

techniques.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
techniques.use: Leviathan has utilized techniques like reflective DLL loading to write a DLL into memory and load a shell that provides backdoor access to the victim.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Leviathan has used PowerShell for execution.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: Leviathan has used VBScript.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: Leviathan has used C:\Windows\Debug and C:\Perflogs as staging directories.

techniques.name: Remote Data Staging
techniques.use: Leviathan has staged data remotely prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: Leviathan has obtained valid accounts to gain initial access.

techniques.name: Multi-hop Proxy
techniques.use: Leviathan has used multi-hop proxies to disguise the source of their malicious traffic.

techniques.name: One-Way Communication
techniques.use: Leviathan has received C2 instructions from user profiles created on legitimate websites such as Github and TechNet.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Leviathan has downloaded additional scripts and files from adversary-controlled servers.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: Leviathan has used external remote services such as virtual private networks (VPN) to gain initial access.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: Leviathan has used a DLL known as SeDll to decrypt and execute other JavaScript backdoors.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Leviathan has infected victims using watering holes.

techniques.name: BITS Jobs
techniques.use: Leviathan has used BITSAdmin to download additional tools.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: Leviathan has exploited multiple Microsoft Office and .NET vulnerabilities for execution, including CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-8759, and CVE-2017-11882.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
