Proofpoint assesses with high confidence that TA571 infections can lead to ransomware.

name: TA575
description: TA575 is a Dridex affiliate tracked by Proofpoint since late 2020. This group distributes malware such as Dridex, Qakbot, and WastedLocker via malicious URLs, Office attachments, and password-protected files. On average, TA575 distributes almost 4,000 messages per campaign impacting hundreds of organizations.

name: TA577
description: TA577 is a prolific cybercrime threat actor tracked by Proofpoint since mid-2020. This actor conducts broad targeting across various industries and geographies, and Proofpoint has observed TA577 deliver payloads including Qbot, IcedID, SystemBC, SmokeLoader, Ursnif, and Cobalt Strike.

name: TA578
description: TA578, a threat actor that Proofpoint researchers have been tracking since May of 2020. TA578 has previously been observed in email-based campaigns delivering Ursnif, IcedID, KPOT Stealer, Buer Loader, BazaLoader, and Cobalt Strike.

name: TA579
description: TA579, a threat actor that Proofpoint researchers have been tracking since August 2021. This actor frequently delivered BazaLoader and IcedID in past campaigns.

name: TA800
description:
This attacker is an affiliate distributor of the The Trick, also known as Trickbot, and BazaLoader. (For more on how affiliates work, see the description of TA573).
TA800 has targeted a wide range of industries in North America, infecting victims with banking Trojans and malware loaders (malware designed to download other malware onto a compromised device). Malicious emails have often included recipients’ names, titles and employers along with phishing pages designed to look like the targeted company. Lures have included hard-to-resist subjects such as related to payment, meetings, termination, bonuses and complaints in the subject line or body of the email.

name: TA866
description: According to Proofpoint, TA866 is a newly identified threat actor that distributes malware via email utilizing both commodity and custom tools. While most of the activity observed occurred since October 2022, Proofpoint researchers identified multiple activity clusters since 2019 that overlap with TA866 activity. Most of the activity recently observed by Proofpoint suggests recent campaigns are financially motivated, however assessment of historic related activities suggests a possible, additional espionage objective.

name: TAG-100
description: (Recorded Future) Recorded Future’s Insikt Group identified new suspected cyber-espionage activity targeting high-profile government, intergovernmental, and private sector organizations globally. This activity, which we are tracking under the temporary group designator TAG100, has employed open-source remote access capabilities and exploited a wide range of internet-facing appliances for initial access. Using Recorded Future® Network Intelligence data, Insikt Group identified the likely compromise of the secretariats of two major Asia-Pacific intergovernmental organizations by TAG100 using the open-source, multi-platform Go backdoor Pantegana. Other targeted organizations include multiple diplomatic entities and ministries of foreign affairs, as well as industry trade associations and semiconductor supply-chain, non-profit, and religious organizations globally. At this time, Insikt Group is continuing to explore potential attribution for this activity; however, the specific targeting and victimology identified align with a suspected espionage motive.

name: TAG-28
description: (Recorded Future) We have identified further suspected intrusions targeting the Indian media conglomerate Bennett Coleman And Co Ltd (BCCL), commonly known as “The Times Group”; the Unique Identification Authority of India (UIDAI); and the Madhya Pradesh Police department. The UIDAI is the Indian government agency responsible for the national identification database, more commonly called “Aadhaar”, which contains private biometric information for over 1 billion Indian citizens. These intrusions were conducted by an activity group we track using a temporary designation, TAG-28.

name: TAG-38
description:
(Recorded Future) In recent months, we observed likely network intrusions targeting at least 7 Indian State Load Despatch Centres (SLDCs) responsible for carrying out real-time operations for grid control and electricity dispatch within these respective states. Notably, this targeting has been geographically concentrated, with the identified SLDCs located in North India, in proximity to the disputed India-China border in Ladakh. One of these SLDCs was also targeted in previous RedEcho activity. This latest set of intrusions, however, is composed of an almost entirely different set of victim organizations. In addition to the targeting of power grid assets, we also identified the compromise of a national emergency response system and the Indian subsidiary of a multinational logistics company by the same threat activity group. To achieve this, the group likely compromised and co-opted internet-facing DVR/IP camera devices for command and control (C2) of Shadowpad malware infections, as well as use of the open source tool FastReverseProxy (FRP).

Despite a partial troop disengagement between India and China from February 2021, the prolonged targeting of Indian critical infrastructure continues to raise concerns over pre-positioning activity being conducted by Chinese adversaries. While this latest activity displays targeting and capability consistencies with previously identified RedEcho activity, there are also some notable distinctions. At this time, we have not identified technical evidence allowing us to attribute it to RedEcho, and we are currently clustering this latest activity under the temporary group name Threat Activity Group 38 (TAG-38).

name: TAG-56
description: TAG-56 is a threat actor group that shares similarities with the APT42 group. They use tactics such as fake registration pages and spearphishing to target victims, often using encrypted chat platforms like WhatsApp or Telegram. TAG-56 is believed to be part of a broader campaign led by an Iran-nexus threat activity group. They have been observed using shared web hosts and recycled code, indicating a preference for acquiring purpose-built infrastructure rather than establishing their own.

name: TEMP.Veles
description: TEMP.Veles is a Russia-based threat group that has targeted critical infrastructure. The group has been observed utilizing TRITON, a malware framework designed to manipulate industrial safety systems.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, Central Scientific Research Institute of Chemistry and Mechanics

techniques.name: Command-Line Interface
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles’ tool took one option from the command line, which was a single IP address of the target Triconex device.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: TEMP.Veles utilizes watering hole websites to target industrial employees.

techniques.name: Loss of Productivity and Revenue
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles tripped a controller into a failed safe state, which caused an automatic shutdown of the plant, this resulted in a pause of plant operations for more than a week. Thereby impacting industrial processes and halting productivity.

techniques.name: Adversary-in-the-Middle
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles changed phone numbers tied to certain specific accounts in a designated contact list. They then used the changed phone numbers to redirect network traffic to websites controlled by them, thereby allowing them to capture and use any login codes sent to the devices via text message.

techniques.name: Program Download
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles downloaded multiple rounds of control logic to the Safety Instrumented System (SIS) controllers through a program append operation.

techniques.name: Scripting
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles used a publicly available PowerShell-based tool, WMImplant.

techniques.name: Unauthorized Command Message
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles leveraged Triton to send unauthorized command messages to the Triconex safety controllers.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles used valid credentials when laterally moving through RDP jump boxes into the ICS environment.

techniques.name: Supply Chain Compromise
techniques.use: TEMP.Veles targeted several ICS vendors and manufacturers.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles made attempts on multiple victim machines to transfer and execute the WMImplant tool.

techniques.name: Indicator Removal on Host
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles would programmatically return the controller to a normal running state if the Triton malware failed. If the controller could not recover in a defined time window, TEMP.Veles programmatically overwrote their malicious program with invalid data.

techniques.name: Remote Services
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles utilized remote desktop protocol (RDP) jump boxes, poorly configured OT firewalls

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles used Mimikatz.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles utilized RDP throughout an operation.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles relied on encrypted SSH-based tunnels to transfer tools and for remote command/program execution.

techniques.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles modified files based on the open-source project cryptcat in an apparent attempt to decrease anti-virus detection rates.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles renamed files to look like legitimate files, such as Windows update files or Schneider Electric application files.During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles renamed files to look like legitimate files, such as Windows update files or Schneider Electric application files.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles installed scheduled tasks defined in XML files.

techniques.name: Web Portal Capture
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles captured credentials as they were being changed by redirecting text-based login codes to websites they controlled.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles used a publicly available PowerShell-based tool, WMImplant.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles routinely deleted tools, logs, and other files after they were finished with them.

techniques.name: Timestomp
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles used timestomping to modify the $STANDARD_INFORMATION attribute on tools.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles used staging folders that are infrequently used by legitimate users or processes to store data for exfiltration and tool deployment.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles used compromised VPN accounts.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles used VPN access to persist in the victim environment.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles planted Web shells on Outlook Exchange servers.

techniques.name: Image File Execution Options Injection
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles modified and added entries within HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options to maintain persistence.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles used port-protocol mismatches on ports such as 443, 4444, 8531, and 50501 during C2.

techniques.name: Protocol Tunneling
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles used encrypted SSH-based PLINK tunnels to transfer tools and enable RDP connections throughout the environment.

techniques.name: Encrypted Channel
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles used cryptcat binaries to encrypt their traffic.

techniques.name: Virtual Private Server
techniques.use: During the C0032 campaign, TEMP.Veles used Virtual Private Server (VPS) infrastructure.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles developed, prior to the attack, malware capabilities that would require access to specific and specialized hardware and software.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles used tools such as Mimikatz and other open-source software.

techniques.name: Active Scanning
techniques.use: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles engaged in network reconnaissance against targets of interest.

name: TIDRONE
description: TIDRONE is an unidentified threat actor linked to Chinese-speaking groups, with a focus on military-related industry chains, particularly drone manufacturers in Taiwan. The actor employs advanced malware variants such as CXCLNT and CLNTEND, which are distributed through ERP software or remote desktops. The consistency in file compilation times and operational patterns aligns with other Chinese espionage activities, indicating a likely espionage motive.

name: TOXIC PANDA
description: A group targeting dissident groups in China and at the boundaries.

name: Taidoor
description:
(Trend Micro) The Taidoor attackers have been actively engaging in targeted attacks since at least March 4, 2009. Despite some exceptions, the Taidoor campaign often used Taiwanese IP addresses as C&C servers and email addresses to send out socially engineered emails with malware as attachments. One of the primary targets of the Taidoor campaign appeared to be the Taiwanese government. The attackers spoofed Taiwanese government email addresses to send out socially engineered emails in the Chinese language that typically leveraged Taiwan-themed issues. The attackers actively sent out malicious documents and maintained several IP addresses for command and control.

As part of their social engineering ploy, the Taidoor attackers attach a decoy document to their emails that, when opened, displays the contents of a legitimate document but executes a malicious payload in the background.

We were only able to gather a limited amount of information regarding the Taidoor attackers’ activities after they have compromised a target. We did, however, find that the Taidoor malware allowed attackers to operate an interactive shell on compromised computers and to upload and download files. In order to determine the operational capabilities of the attackers behind the Taidoor campaign, we monitored a compromised honeypot. The attackers issued out some basic commands in an attempt to map out the extent of the network compromise but quickly realized that the honeypot was not an intended targeted and so promptly disabled the Taidoor malware running on it. This indicated that while Taidoor malware were more widely distributed compared with those tied to other targeted campaigns, the attackers could quickly assess their targets and distinguish these from inadvertently compromised computers and honeypots.

name: TaskMasters
description:
(Positive Technologies}) The main objective of the group is to steal confidential information. The attackers attempt to burrow into corporate information systems for extended periods and obtain access to key servers, executive workstations, and business-critical systems.

At one of the attacked companies, the earliest traces of the group's presence on infrastructure dated to 2010. Since the group had obtained full control of some servers and workstations by that time, the initial breach must have occurred much earlier.

Most of the attacked companies relate to manufacturing and industry. In total we are aware of compromise of over 30 companies and organizations in various sectors, including:

• Manufacturing and industry
• Energy
• Government
• Science and technology
• Systems integration
• Software development
• Geology
• Transport and logistics
• Real estate
• Construction

The group attacked companies in a number of countries. A significant number of their targets were located in Russia and the CIS.

name: Team-Xecuter
description: Team-Xecuter is a hacking group led by Gary Bowser, also known as GaryOPA. They were involved in a piracy conspiracy against Nintendo, creating and selling illegal circumvention devices that allowed users to hack video game consoles for playing pirated games. Gary Bowser has admitted his participation in this activity and is facing legal consequences.

name: TeamSpy Crew
description:
(Kaspersky) Researchers have uncovered a long-term cyber-espionage campaign that used a combination of legitimate software packages and commodity malware tools to target a variety of heavy industry, government intelligence agencies and political activists. Known as the TeamSpy crew because of its affinity for using the legitimate TeamViewer application as part of its toolset, the attackers may have been active for as long as 10 years, researchers say.

The attack appears to be a years-long espionage campaign, but experts who have analyzed the victim profile, malware components and command-and-control infrastructure say that it’s not entirely clear what kind of data the attackers are going after. What is clear, though, is that the attackers have been at this for a long time and that they have specific people in mind as targets.

Researchers at the CrySyS Lab in Hungary were alerted by the Hungarian National Security Authority to an attack against a high-profile target in the country and began looking into the campaign. They quickly discovered that some of the infrastructure being used in the attack had been in use for some time and that the target they were investigating was by no means the only one.

name: TeamTNT
description: TeamTNT is a threat group that has primarily targeted cloud and containerized environments. The group as been active since at least October 2019 and has mainly focused its efforts on leveraging cloud and container resources to deploy cryptocurrency miners in victim environments.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has searched for services such as Alibaba Cloud Security's aliyun service and BMC Helix Cloud Security's bmc-agent service in order to disable them.

techniques.name: Rootkit
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used rootkits such as the open-source Diamorphine rootkit and their custom bots to hide cryptocurrency mining activities on the machine.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has enumerated the host machine’s IP address.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used SSH to connect back to victim machines.
TeamTNT has encrypted its binaries via AES and encoded files using Base64.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used UPX and Ezuri packer to pack its binaries.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.use: TeamTNT has disguised their scripts with docker-related file names.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: TeamTNT has replaced .dockerd and .dockerenv with their own scripts and cryptocurrency mining software.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used masscan to search for open Docker API ports and Kubernetes clusters.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
techniques.use: TeamTNT has sent locally staged files with collected credentials to C2 servers using cURL.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has run netstat -anp to search for rival malware connections.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has searched for rival malware and removes it if found.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: TeamTNT has executed PowerShell commands in batch scripts.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used batch scripts to download tools and executing cryptocurrency miners.

techniques.name: Unix Shell
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used shell scripts for execution.

techniques.name: Cloud API
techniques.use: TeamTNT has leveraged AWS CLI to enumerate cloud environments with compromised credentials.

techniques.name: Clear Linux or Mac System Logs
techniques.use: TeamTNT has removed system logs from /var/log/syslog.

techniques.name: Clear Command History
techniques.use: TeamTNT has cleared command history with history -c.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used a payload that removes itself after running. TeamTNT also has deleted locally staged files for collecting credentials or scan results for local IP addresses after exfiltrating them.

techniques.name: Application Layer Protocol
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used an IRC bot for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: TeamTNT has the curl command to send credentials over HTTP and the curl and wget commands to download new software.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: TeamTNT has aggregated collected credentials in text files before exfiltrating.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has searched for system version, architecture, disk partition, logical volume, and hostname information.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used a script that checks /proc/*/environ for environment variables related to AWS.

techniques.name: SSH Authorized Keys
techniques.use: TeamTNT has added RSA keys in authorized_keys.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: TeamTNT has leveraged iplogger.org to send collected data back to C2.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: TeamTNT has the curl and wget commands as well as batch scripts to download new tools.

techniques.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has searched for attached VGA devices using lspci.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used open-source tools such as Weave Scope to target exposed Docker API ports and gain initial access to victim environments.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: TeamTNT has created local privileged users on victim machines.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used a script that decodes a Base64-encoded version of WeaveWorks Scope.

techniques.name: Malicious Image
techniques.use: TeamTNT has relied on users to download and execute malicious Docker images.

techniques.name: Remote Access Software
techniques.use: TeamTNT has established tmate sessions for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
techniques.use: TeamTNT has modified the permissions on binaries with chattr.

techniques.name: Resource Hijacking
techniques.use: TeamTNT has deployed XMRig Docker images to mine cryptocurrency.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has searched for security products on infected machines.

techniques.name: Systemd Service
techniques.use: TeamTNT has established persistence through the creation of a cryptocurrency mining system service using systemctl.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: TeamTNT has used malware that adds cryptocurrency miners as a service.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: TeamTNT has added batch scripts to the startup folder.

techniques.name: Credentials In Files
techniques.use: TeamTNT has searched for unsecured AWS credentials and Docker API credentials.

techniques.name: Private Keys
techniques.use: TeamTNT has searched for unsecured SSH keys.

techniques.name: Cloud Instance Metadata API
techniques.use: TeamTNT has queried the AWS instance metadata service for credentials.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: TeamTNT has disabled and uninstalled security tools such as Alibaba, Tencent, and BMC cloud monitoring agents on cloud-based infrastructure.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
techniques.use: TeamTNT has disabled iptables.

techniques.name: System Services
techniques.use: TeamTNT has created system services to execute cryptocurrency mining software.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: TeamTNT has obtained domains to host their payloads.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: TeamTNT has developed custom malware such as Hildegard.

techniques.name: Scanning IP Blocks
techniques.use: TeamTNT has scanned specific lists of target IP addresses.

techniques.name: Vulnerability Scanning
techniques.use: TeamTNT has scanned for vulnerabilities in IoT devices and other related resources such as the Docker API.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: TeamTNT has uploaded backdoored Docker images to Docker Hub.

techniques.name: Container Administration Command
techniques.use: TeamTNT executed Hildegard through the kubelet API run command and by executing commands on running containers.

techniques.name: Deploy Container
techniques.use: TeamTNT has deployed different types of containers into victim environments to facilitate execution.

techniques.name: Escape to Host
techniques.use: TeamTNT has deployed privileged containers that mount the filesystem of victim machine.

techniques.name: Container and Resource Discovery
techniques.use: TeamTNT has checked for running containers with docker ps and for specific container names with docker inspect.

name: TempTick
description: This threat actor targets organizations in the finance, defense, aerospace, technology, health-care, and automotive sectors and media organizations in East Asia for the purpose of espionage. Believed to be responsible for the targeting of South Korean actors prior to the meeting of Donald J. Trump and Kim Jong-un

name: Tempting Cedar Spyware
description:
(ZDNet) A hacking campaign used fake Facebook profiles to trick targets into downloading malware capable of stealing vast swathes of information, including messages, photos, audio recordings and even the exact location of victims.

The group has been operating since as early as 2015 and is thought to have infected the Android phones of hundreds selected targets across the Middle East. The the highest concentration of infections is in Israel, but victims have also been seen in the US, China, Germany and France.

Uncovered by researchers at Avast, the operation has been dubbed 'Tempting Cedar Spyware'. The name combines the main means of attack - by tricking victims using fake social media profiles purporting to be those of a young woman - with the Cedar tree, which features prominently on the flag of Lebanon.

The campaign for distributing the malware begins with fake Facebook profiles which are designed to lure in victims - predominantly men - with 'flirty' conversations.

name: Terbium
description:
(Microsoft) A few weeks ago, multiple organizations in the Middle East fell victim to targeted and destructive attacks that wiped data from computers, and in many cases rendering them unstable and unbootable. Destructive attacks like these have been observed repeatedly over the years and the Windows Defender and Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection Threat Intelligence teams are working on protection, detection, and response to these threats.

Microsoft Threat Intelligence identified similarities between this recent attack and previous 2012 attacks against tens of thousands of computers belonging to organizations in the energy sector. Microsoft Threat Intelligence refers to the activity group behind these attacks as Terbium, following our internal practice of assigning rogue actors chemical element names.

name: TetrisPhantom
description: TetrisPhantom relies on compromising of certain type of secure USB drives that provide hardware encryption and is commonly used by government organizations. While investigating this threat, experts identified an entire spying campaign that uses a range of malicious modules to execute commands, collect files and information from compromised computers and transfer them to other machines also using secure USB drives.

name: The Big Bang
description:
(Talos) Talos continuously monitors malicious emails campaigns. We identified one specific spear phishing campaign launched against targets within Palestine, and specifically against Palestinian law enforcement agencies. This campaign started in April 2017, using a spear phishing campaign to deliver the MICROPSIA payload in order to remotely control infected systems. Although this technique is not new, it remains an effective technique for attackers.

The malware itself was developed in Delphi; in this article, we describe the features and the network communication to the command and control server used by the attackers. The threat actor has chosen to reference TV show characters and include German language words within the attack. Most significantly, the attacker has appeared to have used genuine documents stolen from Palestinian sources as well as a controversial music video as part of the attack.

(Check Point) While the APT has gone through significant upgrades over the past year, the conductors of these campaigns maintained evident fingerprints, both in the delivery methods and malware development conventions. These unique traces assisted us in correlating the current wave to past attacks, and may also have some resemblance to attacks related to the Molerats, Extreme Jackal, Gaza Cybergang APT group.

name: The Shadow Brokers
description: The Shadow Brokers (TSB) is a hacker group who first appeared in the summer of 2016. They published several leaks containing hacking tools from the National Security Agency (NSA, including several zero-day exploits.[1] Specifically, these exploits and vulnerabilities targeted enterprise firewalls, antivirus software, and Microsoft products. The Shadow Brokers originally attributed the leaks to the Equation Group threat actor, who have been tied to the NSA's Tailored Access Operations unit.

name: The White Company
description: The White Company is a likely state-sponsored threat actor with advanced capabilities. From 2017 through 2018, the group led an espionage campaign called Operation Shaheen targeting government and military organizations in Pakistan.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: The White Company has obfuscated their payloads through packing.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: The White Company has the ability to delete its malware entirely from the target system.

techniques.name: System Time Discovery
techniques.use: The White Company has checked the current date on the victim system.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: The White Company has taken advantage of a known vulnerability in Microsoft Word (CVE 2012-0158) to execute code.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: The White Company has used phishing lure documents that trick users into opening them and infecting their computers.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: The White Company has checked for specific antivirus products on the target’s computer, including Kaspersky, Quick Heal, AVG, BitDefender, Avira, Sophos, Avast!, and ESET.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: The White Company has sent phishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to victims.

name: TheDarkOverlord
description: The Dark Overlord is a financially motivated ransomware group that has been active since 2016. The group is known for targeting large organizations, including Netflix, ABC, and Miramax.

name: Threat Actor 888
description: Threat actor 888 is a hacker active in 2024, targeting companies for data breaches. They've hit Microsoft, BMW (Hong Kong), and others in tech, freight, and oil & gas industries

name: Threat Group-1314
description: Threat Group-1314 is an unattributed threat group that has used compromised credentials to log into a victim's remote access infrastructure.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: Threat Group-1314 actors mapped network drives using net use.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Threat Group-1314 actors spawned shells on remote systems on a victim network to execute commands.

techniques.name: Software Deployment Tools
techniques.use: Threat Group-1314 actors used a victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Domain Accounts
techniques.use: Threat Group-1314 actors used compromised domain credentials for the victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, to move laterally.

name: Threat Group-3390
description: Threat Group-3390 is a Chinese threat group that has extensively used strategic Web compromises to target victims. The group has been active since at least 2010 and has targeted organizations in the aerospace, government, defense, technology, energy, manufacturing and gambling/betting sectors.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors have used a modified version of Mimikatz called Wrapikatz to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.

techniques.name: Security Account Manager
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors have used gsecdump to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.

techniques.name: LSA Secrets
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors have used gsecdump to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can read and decrypt stored Registry values.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors use NBTscan to discover vulnerable systems.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used the net view command.

techniques.name: Windows Remote Management
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used WinRM to enable remote execution.
A Threat Group-3390 tool can encrypt payloads using XOR. Threat Group-3390 malware is also obfuscated using Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has packed malware and tools, including using VMProtect.

techniques.name: Data Transfer Size Limits
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used whoami to collect system user information.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors use the Hunter tool to conduct network service discovery for vulnerable systems.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can use WMI to execute a binary.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used net use and netstat to conduct internal discovery of systems. The group has also used quser.exe to identify existing RDP sessions on a victim.

techniques.name: At
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors use at to schedule tasks to run self-extracting RAR archives, which install HTTPBrowser or PlugX on other victims on a network.

techniques.name: Process Hollowing
techniques.use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can spawn svchost.exe and inject the payload into that process.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors installed a credential logger on Microsoft Exchange servers. Threat Group-3390 also leveraged the reconnaissance framework, ScanBox, to capture keystrokes.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used PowerShell for execution.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used command-line interfaces for execution.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used CVE-2014-6324 and CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has deleted existing logs and exfiltrated file archives from a victim.

techniques.name: Network Share Connection Removal
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has detached network shares after exfiltrating files, likely to evade detection.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 malware has used HTTP for C2.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has locally staged encrypted archives for later exfiltration efforts.

techniques.name: Remote Data Staging
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has moved staged encrypted archives to Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with China Chopper prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors obtain legitimate credentials using a variety of methods and use them to further lateral movement on victim networks.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has used net user to conduct internal discovery of systems.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has downloaded additional malware and tools, including through the use of certutil, onto a compromised host .

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: A Threat Group-3390 tool has created new Registry keys under HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\ and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services.

techniques.name: Automated Collection
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 actors look for and use VPN profiles during an operation to access the network using external VPN services.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: During execution, Threat Group-3390 malware deobfuscates and decompresses code that was encoded with Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Threat Group-3390 has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application

techniques.name: Compromise Software Supply Chain

techniques.name: Trusted Relationship

name: Threatsec
description: ThreatSec is a hacktivist group that has targeted various organizations, including internet service providers in Gaza. They claim to fight for the rights and freedom of the oppressed and do not prioritize monetary gain. The group is part of the "Five Families"consortium, which includes other hacktivist groups such as GhostSec and Stormous. ThreatSec has been involved in cyberattacks, data breaches, and ransomware activities.

name: Thrip
description: Thrip is an espionage group that has targeted satellite communications, telecoms, and defense contractor companies in the U.S. and Southeast Asia. The group uses custom malware as well as "living off the land"techniques.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Naikon uses commands such as netsh interface show to discover network interface settings.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Naikon has used a netbios scanner for remote machine identification.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: Naikon renamed a malicious service taskmgr to appear to be a legitimate version of Task Manager.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: Naikon has disguised malicious programs as Google Chrome, Adobe, and VMware executables.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: Naikon has used the LadonGo scanner to scan target networks.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: Thrip has used WinSCP to exfiltrate data from a targeted organization over FTP.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: Naikon has used schtasks.exe for lateral movement in compromised networks.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Thrip leveraged PowerShell to run commands to download payloads, traverse the compromised networks, and carry out reconnaissance.

techniques.name: Domain Accounts
techniques.use: Naikon has used administrator credentials for lateral movement in compromised networks.

techniques.name: Add-ins
techniques.use: Naikon has used the RoyalRoad exploit builder to drop a second stage loader, intel.wll, into the Word Startup folder on the compromised host.
APT30 has relied on users to execute malicious file attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Naikon has convinced victims to open malicious attachments to execute malware.

techniques.name: Remote Access Software
techniques.use: Thrip used a cloud-based remote access software called LogMeIn for their attacks.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: Naikon uses commands such as netsh advfirewall firewall to discover local firewall settings.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Naikon has modified a victim's Windows Run registry to establish persistence.
APT30 has used spearphishing emails with malicious DOC attachments.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Naikon has used malicious e-mail attachments to deliver malware.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: Naikon has used DLL side-loading to load malicious DLL's into legitimate executables.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Thrip has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz and PsExec.

name: TiltedTemple
description: One of their notable tools is a custom backdoor called SockDetour, which operates filelessly and socketlessly on compromised Windows servers. The group's activities have been linked to the exploitation of vulnerabilities in Zoho ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus and ServiceDesk Plus.

name: Tiny Spider
description:
(ForcePoint) It all starts with the delivery of a small loader called TinyLoader, an obfuscated executable withsimple–yet powerful –downloader functionality. Upon execution, it will first brute force its own decryption key (a 32-bit value, meaning this takes a fraction of second on modern PCs) before using this to decrypt the main program code.

The core functionality of the decrypted code is communication with a set of hardcoded C2 servers by IP and port. If the C2 is active, it will provide what is effectively a piece of shellcode, encrypted by another 32-bit constant. This shellcode is not ‘fire and forget’: it instead sees the loader establish a semi-interactive two-way communication with the C2. Note that the earliest traits and mentions of TinyLoader go back to as far as 2015.

name: ToddyCat
description: ToddyCat is a sophisticated threat group that has been active since at least 2020 using custom loaders and malware in multi-stage infection chains against government and military targets across Europe and Asia.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: ToddyCat has run scripts to collect documents from targeted hosts.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used ping %REMOTE_HOST% for post exploit discovery.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used locally mounted network shares for lateral movement through targated environments.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used the name debug.exe for malware components.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used WMI to execute scripts for post exploit document collection.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used netstat -anop tcp to discover TCP connections to compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used scheduled tasks to execute discovery commands and scripts for collection.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: ToddyCat has run cmd /c start /b tasklist to enumerate processes.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used Powershell scripts to perform post exploit collection.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used .bat scripts and cmd for execution on compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Domain Groups
techniques.use: ToddyCat has executed net group "domain admins"/dom for discovery on compromised machines.

techniques.name: Remote Data Staging
techniques.use: ToddyCat manually transferred collected files to an exfiltration host using xcopy.

techniques.name: Domain Accounts
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used compromised domain admin credentials to mount local network shares.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: ToddyCat has collected information on bootable drives including model, vendor, and serial numbers.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: ToddyCat has run scripts to enumerate recently modified documents having either a .pdf, .doc, .docx, .xls or .xlsx extension.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: ToddyCat has run net user %USER% /dom for account discovery.

techniques.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used a passive backdoor that receives commands with UDP packets.

techniques.name: Native API
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used WinExec to execute commands received from C2 on compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.use: ToddyCat has exploited the ProxyLogon vulnerability (CVE-2021-26855) to compromise Exchange Servers at multiple organizations.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: ToddyCat can determine is Kaspersky software is running on an endpoint by running cmd /c wmic process where name="avp.exe".

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: ToddyCat has leveraged xcopy, 7zip, and RAR to stage and compress collected documents prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
techniques.use: Prior to executing a backdoor ToddyCat has run cmd /c start /b netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="SGAccessInboundRule"dir=in protocol=udp action=allow localport=49683 to allow the targeted system to receive UDP packets on port 49683.

techniques.name: Hidden Window
techniques.use: ToddyCat has hidden malicious scripts using powershell.exe -windowstyle hidden.

techniques.name: Spearphishing via Service
techniques.use: ToddyCat has sent loaders configured to run Ninja as zip archives via Telegram.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: ToddyCat has used a DropBox uploader to exfiltrate stolen files.

name: Tomiris
description:
(Kaspersky) Tomiris focuses on intelligence gathering in Central Asia. Tomiris’s endgame consistently appears to be the regular theft of internal documents.

The threat actor targets government and diplomatic entities in the CIS. The occasional victims discovered in other regions (such as the Middle East or South-East Asia) turn out to be foreign representations of CIS countries, illustrating Tomiris’s narrow focus.

It is characterized by its tendency to develop numerous low-sophistication “burner” implants in a variety of programming languages that are repeatedly deployed against the same targets, using elementary but efficient packaging and distribution techniques. Tomiris occasionally leverages commercial or open-source RATs.
Language artifacts discovered in Tomiris’s implant families and infrastructure from distinct campaigns all indicate that the threat actor is Russian-speaking.

Overall, Tomiris is a very agile and determined actor, open to experimentation – for instance with delivery methods (DNS hijacking) or command and control (C2) channels (Telegram).

Kaspersky also asserts that there exists a form of deliberate cooperation between Tomiris and Turla, Waterbug, Venomous Bear.

name: Tonto Team
description: Tonto Team is a suspected Chinese state-sponsored cyber espionage threat group that has primarily targeted South Korea, Japan, Taiwan, and the United States since at least 2009; by 2020 they expanded operations to include other Asian as well as Eastern European countries. Tonto Team has targeted government, military, energy, mining, financial, education, healthcare, and technology organizations, including through the Heartbeat Campaign (2009-2012) and Operation Bitter Biscuit (2017).
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, Shenyang Military Region Technical Reconnaissance Bureau, possibly Unit 65017

techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used a variety of credential dumping tools.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used keylogging tools in their operations.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used PowerShell to download additional payloads.

techniques.name: Python
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used Python-based tools for execution.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: Tonto Team has exploited CVE-2019-0803 and MS16-032 to escalate privileges.

techniques.name: Local Groups
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used the ShowLocalGroupDetails command to identify administrator, user, and guest accounts on a compromised host.

techniques.name: External Proxy
techniques.use: Tonto Team has routed their traffic through an external server in order to obfuscate their location.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Tonto Team has downloaded malicious DLLs which served as a ShadowPad loader.

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used tools such as NBTscan to enumerate network shares.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: Tonto Team has exploited Microsoft vulnerabilities, including CVE-2018-0798, CVE-2018-8174, CVE-2018-0802, CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2019-9489 CVE-2020-8468, and CVE-2018-0798 to enable execution of their delivered malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Tonto Team has relied on user interaction to open their malicious RTF documents.

techniques.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used EternalBlue exploits for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: Tonto Team has used a first stage web shell after compromising a vulnerable Exchange server.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Tonto Team has delivered payloads via spearphishing attachments.

techniques.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
techniques.use: Tonto Team abuses a legitimate and signed Microsoft executable to launch a malicious DLL.

name: Tortilla
description:
(Talos) Cisco Talos recently discovered a malicious campaign deploying variants of the Babuk ransomware predominantly affecting users in the U.S. with smaller number of infections in U.K., Germany, Ukraine, Finland, Brazil, Honduras and Thailand.

The actor of the campaign is sometimes referred to as Tortilla, based on the payload file names used in the campaign. This is a new actor operating since July 2021. Prior to this ransomware, Tortilla has been experimenting with other payloads, such as the PowerShell-based netcat clone Powercat, which is known to provide attackers with unauthorized access to Windows machines.

We assess with moderate confidence that the initial infection vector is exploitation of ProxyShell vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange Server through the deployment of China Chopper web shell.

name: Tracer Kitten
description:
(CrowdStrike) In April 2020, OverWatch discovered Iran-based adversary TRACER KITTEN conducting malicious interactive activity against multiple hosts at a telecommunications company in the Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) region. The actor was found operating under valid user accounts, using custom backdoors in combination with SSH tunnels for C2. The adversary leveraged their foothold to conduct a variety of reconnaissance activities, undertake credential harvesting and prepare for data exfiltration.

Telecommunications is currently the third most frequently targeted vertical. This industry still remains firmly within the crosshairs for targeted attacks, the motivations of which are likely associated with espionage and data theft objectives.

name: Transparent Tribe
description: Transparent Tribe is a suspected Pakistan-based threat group that has been active since at least 2013, primarily targeting diplomatic, defense, and research organizations in India and Afghanistan.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: SideCopy has identified the IP address of a compromised host.
Transparent Tribe has dropped encoded executables on compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Visual Basic

techniques.name: System Information Discovery

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer

techniques.name: Native API

techniques.name: Modify Registry

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: Gorgon Group malware can decode contents from a payload that was Base64 encoded and write the contents to a file.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has used websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with Crimson, njRAT, and other malicious tools.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has crafted malicious files to exploit CVE-2012-0158 and CVE-2010-3333 for execution.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has directed users to open URLs hosting malicious content.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has used weaponized documents in e-mail to compromise targeted systems.

techniques.name: Mshta

techniques.name: Software Discovery
techniques.use: SideCopy has collected browser information from a compromised host.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

techniques.name: Shortcut Modification
techniques.use: Gorgon Group malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools

techniques.name: Hidden Window

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has sent spearphishing e-mails with attachments to deliver malicious payloads.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has embedded links to malicious downloads in e-mails.

techniques.name: Dynamic Resolution
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has used dynamic DNS services to set up C2.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: SideCopy has used a malicious loader DLL file to execute the credwiz.exe process and side-load the malicious payload Duser.dll.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has registered domains to mimic file sharing, government, defense, and research websites for use in targeted campaigns.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has compromised domains for use in targeted malicious campaigns.

techniques.name: Digital Certificates
techniques.use: For C0011, Transparent Tribe established SSL certificates on the typo-squatted domains the group registered.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Gorgon Group has obtained and used tools such as QuasarRAT and Remcos.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: SideCopy has crafted generic lures for spam campaigns to collect emails and credentials for targeting efforts.

techniques.name: Upload Malware
techniques.use: For C0011, Transparent Tribe hosted malicious documents on domains registered by the group.

techniques.name: Drive-by Target
techniques.use: Transparent Tribe has set up websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with Crimson, njRAT, and other malicious tools.

techniques.name: System Location Discovery
techniques.use: SideCopy has identified the country location of a compromised host.

name: Traveling Spider
description:
(BleepingComputer) A new ransomware has been spotted over the weekend, carrying references to the Russian president and antivirus software. The researchers call it Nemty.

This is the first version of Nemty ransomware, named so after the extension it adds to the files following the encryption process.

name: Tropic Trooper
description: Tropic Trooper is an unaffiliated threat group that has led targeted campaigns against targets in Taiwan, the Philippines, and Hong Kong. Tropic Trooper focuses on targeting government, healthcare, transportation, and high-tech industries and has been active since 2011.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has used scripts to collect the host's network topology.

techniques.name: Automated Exfiltration
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has used a copy function to automatically exfiltrate sensitive data from air-gapped systems using USB storage.
Tropic Trooper has encrypted configuration files.

techniques.name: Steganography
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has used JPG files with encrypted payloads to mask their backdoor routines and evade detection.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper used letmein to scan for saved usernames on the target system.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has hidden payloads in Flash directories and fake installer files.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper used pr and an openly available tool to scan for open ports on target systems.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has tested if the localhost network is available and other connection capability on an infected system using command scripts.

techniques.name: Exfiltration over USB
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has exfiltrated data using USB storage devices.

techniques.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper is capable of enumerating the running processes on the system using pslist.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has used Windows command scripts.

techniques.name: File Deletion

techniques.name: Web Protocols

techniques.name: DNS
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper's backdoor has communicated to the C2 over the DNS protocol.

techniques.name: Local Accounts

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has detected a target system’s OS version and system volume information.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has monitored files' modified time.

techniques.name: Replication Through Removable Media
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has attempted to transfer USBferry from an infected USB device by copying an Autorun function to the target machine.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has used a delivered trojan to download additional files.

techniques.name: Native API
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has used multiple Windows APIs including HttpInitialize, HttpCreateHttpHandle, and HttpAddUrl.

techniques.name: Automated Collection
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has collected information automatically using the adversary's USBferry attack.

techniques.name: Standard Encoding

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper used shellcode with an XOR algorithm to decrypt a payload. Tropic Trooper also decrypted image files which contained a payload.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution

techniques.name: Malicious File

techniques.name: Web Shell

techniques.name: Software Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper's backdoor could list the infected system's installed software.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper can search for anti-virus software running on the system.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has installed a service pointing to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has created shortcuts in the Startup folder to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Winlogon Helper DLL

techniques.name: Hidden Files and Directories

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment

techniques.name: Encrypted Channel

techniques.name: Asymmetric Cryptography

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: Tropic Trooper has been known to side-load DLLs using a valid version of a Windows Address Book and Windows Defender executable with one of their tools.

name: Tropical Scorpius
description: (Palo Alto) The most recent Unit 42 Ransomware Threat Report includes observations of Cuba Ransomware impacting 33 organizations. As of July 2022, Tropical Scorpius has used Cuba Ransomware to impact 27 additional organizations across multiple vectors, such as Professional and Legal Services, State and Local Government, Manufacturing, Transportation and Logistics, Wholesale and Retail, Real Estate, Financial Services, Health Care, High Technology, Utilities and Energy, Construction, and Education. A total of 60 organizations were exposed by this ransomware gang on its leak site since the group first surfaced in 2019.

name: TunnelSnake
description: The TunnelSnake campaign demonstrates the activity of a sophisticated actor that invests significant resources in designing an evasive toolset and infiltrating networks of high-profile organizations. By leveraging Windows drivers, covert communications channels and proprietary malware, the group behind it maintains a considerable level of stealth. That said, some of its TTPs, like the usage of a commodity webshell and open-source legacy code for loading unsigned drivers, may get detected and in fact were flagged by Kaspersky's product, giving them visibility into the group’s operation.

name: TurkHackTeam
description: Founded in 2004, Turkhackteam is one of Turkey’s oldest and most high-profile hacking collectives. According to a list compiled on Turkhackteam’s forum, the group has carried out almost 30 highly publicized hacking campaigns targeting foreign government and commercial websites, including websites of international corporations.

name: Turla
description: Turla is a cyber espionage threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB). They have compromised victims in over 50 countries since at least 2004, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies. Turla is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns, and leveraging in-house tools and malware, such as Uroburos.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Turla RPC backdoors can upload files from victim machines.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the tasklist /svc command.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the reg query command.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover network configuration details using the arp -a, nbtstat -n, net config, ipconfig /all, and route commands, as well as NBTscan.

techniques.name: Internet Connection Discovery
techniques.use: Turla has used tracert to check internet connectivity.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the net view and net view /DOMAIN commands. Turla has also used net group "Domain Computers"/domain, net group "Domain Controllers"/domain, and net group "Exchange Servers"/domain to enumerate domain computers, including the organization's DC and Exchange Server.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: Turla used net use commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.

techniques.name: Data from Removable Media
techniques.use: Turla RPC backdoors can collect files from USB thumb drives.

techniques.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
techniques.use: Based on comparison of Gazer versions, Turla made an effort to obfuscate strings in the malware that could be used as IoCs, including the mutex name and named pipe.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: Turla has used encryption (including salted 3DES via PowerSploit's Out-EncryptedScript.ps1), random variable names, and base64 encoding to obfuscate PowerShell commands and payloads.

techniques.name: Fileless Storage
techniques.use: Turla has used the Registry to store encrypted and encoded payloads.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover active local network connections using the netstat -an, net use, net file, and net session commands.

techniques.name: Process Injection
techniques.use: Turla has also used PowerSploit's Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1 to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.

techniques.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
techniques.use: Turla has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover running processes using the tasklist /v command.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Turla has used PowerShell to execute commands/scripts, in some cases via a custom executable or code from Empire's PSInject.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Turla RPC backdoors have used cmd.exe to execute commands.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: Turla has used VBS scripts throughout its operations.

techniques.name: Python
techniques.use: Turla has used IronPython scripts as part of the IronNetInjector toolchain to drop payloads.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: Turla has used various JavaScript-based backdoors.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: Turla has exploited vulnerabilities in the VBoxDrv.sys driver to obtain kernel mode privileges.

techniques.name: Local Groups
techniques.use: Turla has used net localgroup and net localgroup Administrators to enumerate group information, including members of the local administrators group.

techniques.name: Domain Groups
techniques.use: Turla has used net group "Domain Admins"/domain to identify domain administrators.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Turla has used HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Mail Protocols
techniques.use: Turla has used multiple backdoors which communicate with a C2 server via email attachments.

techniques.name: Local Accounts
techniques.use: Turla has abused local accounts that have the same password across the victim’s network.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the systeminfo and set commands.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, the Program Files directory, and Recent.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: Turla has used net user to enumerate local accounts on the system.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: Turla has used net user /domain to enumerate domain accounts.

techniques.name: Proxy
techniques.use: Turla RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.

techniques.name: Internal Proxy
techniques.use: Turla has compromised internal network systems to act as a proxy to forward traffic to C2.

techniques.name: Web Service
techniques.use: Turla has used legitimate web services including Pastebin, Dropbox, and GitHub for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
techniques.use: A Turla JavaScript backdoor has used Google Apps Script as its C2 server.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Turla has used shellcode to download Meterpreter after compromising a victim.

techniques.name: Native API
techniques.use: Turla and its RPC backdoors have used APIs calls for various tasks related to subverting AMSI and accessing then executing commands through RPC and/or named pipes.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.use: Turla may attempt to connect to systems within a victim's network using net use commands and a predefined list or collection of passwords.

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: Turla has modify Registry values to store payloads.

techniques.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
techniques.use: Turla has used fsutil fsinfo drives to list connected drives.

techniques.name: System Time Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the net time command.

techniques.name: Create Process with Token
techniques.use: Turla RPC backdoors can impersonate or steal process tokens before executing commands.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: Turla has used a custom decryption routine, which pulls key and salt values from other artifacts such as a WMI filter or PowerShell Profile, to decode encrypted PowerShell payloads.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Turla has infected victims using watering holes.

techniques.name: Password Policy Discovery
techniques.use: Turla has used net accounts and net accounts /domain to acquire password policy information.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: Turla has used spearphishing via a link to get users to download and run their malware.

techniques.name: Data from Information Repositories
techniques.use: Turla has used a custom .NET tool to collect documents from an organization's internal central database.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: Turla has obtained information on security software, including security logging information that may indicate whether their malware has been detected.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
techniques.use: Turla has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.

techniques.name: PowerShell Profile
techniques.use: Turla has used PowerShell profiles to maintain persistence on an infected machine.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: A Turla Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence. Additionally, a Turla custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.

techniques.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
techniques.use: Turla established persistence by adding a Shell value under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.

techniques.name: Code Signing Policy Modification
techniques.use: Turla has modified variables in kernel memory to turn off Driver Signature Enforcement after exploiting vulnerabilities that obtained kernel mode privileges.

techniques.name: Windows Credential Manager
techniques.use: Turla has gathered credentials from the Windows Credential Manager tool.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: Turla has encrypted files stolen from connected USB drives into a RAR file before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: Turla has used a AMSI bypass, which patches the in-memory amsi.dll, in PowerShell scripts to bypass Windows antimalware products.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: Turla attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: Turla has used WebDAV to upload stolen USB files to a cloud drive.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Turla RPC backdoors can be used to transfer files to/from victim machines on the local network.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: Turla has created web accounts including Dropbox and GitHub for C2 and document exfiltration.

techniques.name: Virtual Private Server
techniques.use: Turla has used the VPS infrastructure of compromised Iranian threat actors.

techniques.name: Server
techniques.use: Turla has used compromised servers as infrastructure.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: Turla has frequently used compromised WordPress sites for C2 infrastructure.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: Turla has developed its own unique malware for use in operations.

techniques.name: Malware
techniques.use: Turla has used malware obtained after compromising other threat actors, such as OilRig.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Turla has obtained and customized publicly-available tools like Mimikatz.

techniques.name: Group Policy Discovery
techniques.use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover Group Policy details using the gpresult command.

name: Twisted Panda
description:
(Check Point) Check Point Research (CPR) unveils a targeted campaign against at least two research institutes in Russia, which are part of the Rostec corporation, a state-owned defense conglomerate.

This campaign is a continuation of what is believed to be a long-running espionage operation against Russian-related entities that has persisted since at least July 2021. The operation may still be ongoing, as the most recent activity was observed in April 2022.

This activity was attributed to a Chinese threat actor, with possible connections to Stone Panda, APT 10, menuPass, a sophisticated and experienced nation-state-backed actor, and Mustang Panda, another proficient China-based cyber espionage group. The campaign has been dubbed Twisted Panda to reflect the sophistication of the tools observed and the attribution to China.

The hackers use new tools, which have not previously been described: a sophisticated multi-layered loader and a backdoor dubbed SPINNER. These tools use advanced evasion and anti-analysis techniques such as multi-layer in-memory loaders and compiler-level obfuscations.

name: UAC-0006
description: UAC-0006 is a financially motivated threat actor that has been active since at least 2013. They primarily target Ukrainian organizations, particularly accountants, with phishing emails containing the SmokeLoader malware. Their goal is to steal credentials and execute unauthorized fund transfers, posing a significant risk to financial systems.

name: UAC-0020
description: Vermin is a threat actor group linked to the Luhansk People’s Republic and believed to be acting on behalf of the Kremlin. They have targeted Ukrainian government infrastructure using malware like Spectr and legitimate tools like SyncThing for data exfiltration. Vermin has been active since at least 2018, using custom-made RATs like Vermin and open-source tools like Quasar for cyber-espionage. The group has resurfaced after periods of inactivity to conduct espionage operations against Ukraine's military and defense sectors.

name: UAC-0050
description: UAC-0050 is a threat actor that has been active since 2020, targeting government agencies in Ukraine. They have been distributing the Remcos RAT malware through phishing campaigns, using tactics such as impersonating the Security Service of Ukraine and sending emails with malicious attachments. The group has also been linked to other hacking collectives, such as UAC-0096, and has previously used remote administration tools like Remote Utilities. The motive behind their attacks is likely espionage.

name: UAC-0094
description: State Service of Special Communication and Information Protection of Ukraine spotted a new wave of cyber attacks aimed at gaining access to users’ Telegram accounts. The Ukrainian CERT attributes the hacking campaign to threat actors tracked as UAC-0094. Threat actors are targeting Telegram users by sending Telegram messages with malicious links to the Telegram website in order to gain unauthorized access to the records and transfer a one-time code from SMS.

name: UAC-0099
description: UAC-0099 is a threat actor that has been active since at least May 2023, targeting Ukrainian entities. They have been observed using a known WinRAR vulnerability to carry out attacks, indicating a level of sophistication. The actor relies on PowerShell and the creation of scheduled tasks to execute malicious VBS files for initial infection. Monitoring and limiting the functionality of these components can help mitigate the risk of UAC-0099 attacks.

name: UAC-0102
description: UAC-0102 is a threat actor group targeting UKR.NET users through phishing attacks. They distribute emails with HTML file attachments that redirect users to a fraudulent website to steal authentication data. Security teams can use Sigma rules to detect their phishing campaigns and leverage IOCs provided by CERT-UA to hunt for their activity in SIEM or EDR environments.

name: UAC-0118
description: From Russia with Love, is a threat actor group that emerged during the Russia-Ukraine war in 2022. They primarily engage in DDoS attacks and have targeted critical infrastructure, media, energy, and government entities. FRwL has been linked to the use of the Somnia ransomware, which they employ as a wiper rather than for financial gain. While there is no direct evidence linking FRwL to the Russian Main Intelligence Directorate, it is possible that they coordinate activities with state-aligned hacktivist groups.

name: UAC-0154
description: UAC-0154 is a threat actor orchestrating the STARK#VORTEX phishing campaign, specifically targeting Ukraine’s military. They employ a Microsoft Help file containing obfuscated JavaScript as a lure, disguised as a manual for Pilot-in-Command Drones, to deliver the MerlinAgent malware. This PowerShell-based RAT is heavily obfuscated and downloads a payload from a remote server, enabling full control over compromised systems. The group initially targeted Ukrainian entities using military-themed documents sent via email to @ukr.net addresses.

name: UAC-0184
