techniques.use: Windshift has used WMI to collect information about target machines.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Windshift has used malware to enumerate active processes.

techniques.name: Visual Basic
techniques.use: Windshift has used Visual Basic 6 (VB6) payloads.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Windshift has used tools that communicate with C2 over HTTP.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Windshift has used malware to identify the computer name of a compromised host.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Windshift has used tools to deploy additional payloads to compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.use: Windshift has used compromised websites to register custom URL schemes on a remote system.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: Windshift has used links embedded in e-mails to lure victims into executing malicious code.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Windshift has used e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malicious code.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.use: Windshift has encrypted application strings using AES in ECB mode and Blowfish, and stored strings encoded in hex during Operation BULL. Further, in Operation BULL, encryption keys were stored within the application’s launcher icon file.

techniques.name: Download New Code at Runtime
techniques.use: Windshift has included malware functionality capable of downloading new DEX files at runtime during Operation BULL.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: Windshift has included keylogging capabilities as part of Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Windshift has included file enumeration in the malicious apps deployed as part of Operation BULL and Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Windshift has included system information enumeration in the malicious apps deployed as part of Operation BULL and Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: Audio Capture
techniques.use: Windshift has included phone call and audio recording capabilities in the malicious apps deployed as part of Operation BULL and Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: Location Tracking
techniques.use: Windshift has included location tracking capabilities in the malicious apps deployed as part of Operation BULL and Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: Video Capture
techniques.use: Windshift has included video recording in the malicious apps deployed as part of Operation BULL.

techniques.name: Software Discovery
techniques.use: Windshift has used malware to identify installed software.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: Windshift has used malware to identify installed AV and commonly used forensic and malware analysis tools.

techniques.name: Symmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: Windshift has encrypted C2 communications using AES in CBC mode during Operation BULL and Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Windshift has exfiltrated local account data and calendar information as part of Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Windshift has created LNK files in the Startup folder to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Windshift has sent spearphishing emails with attachment to harvest credentials and deliver malware.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: Windshift has sent spearphishing emails with links to harvest credentials and deliver malware.

techniques.name: Spearphishing via Service
techniques.use: Windshift has used fake personas on social media to engage and target victims.

techniques.name: Geofencing
techniques.use: Windshift has region-locked their malicious applications during their Operation BULL campaign.
Windshift has hidden multimedia files from the user.

techniques.name: Code Signing Policy Modification
techniques.use: Windshift has installed malicious MDM profiles on iOS devices as part of Operation ROCK.

techniques.name: System Checks
techniques.use: Windshift has deployed anti-analysis capabilities during their Operation BULL campaign.

techniques.name: Contact List
techniques.use: Windshift has included contact list exfiltration in the malicious apps deployed as part of Operation BULL.

techniques.name: SMS Messages
techniques.use: Windshift has included SMS message exfiltration in the malicious apps deployed as part of Operation BULL and Operation ROCK.

name: Winnti Group
description: Winnti Group is a threat group with Chinese origins that has been active since at least 2010. The group has heavily targeted the gaming industry, but it has also expanded the scope of its targeting. Some reporting suggests a number of other groups, including Axiom, APT17, and Ke3chang, are closely linked to Winnti Group.

techniques.name: Protocol Impersonation
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 frequently configured the URL endpoints of their stealthy passive backdoor LOWKEY.PASSIVE to masquerade as normal web application traffic on an infected server.

techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.use: Suckfly used a signed credential-dumping tool to obtain victim account credentials.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: APT41 has used hashdump, Mimikatz, and the Windows Credential Editor to dump password hashes from memory and authenticate to other user accounts.

techniques.name: Security Account Manager
techniques.use: APT41 extracted user account data from the Security Account Managerr (SAM), making a copy of this database from the registry using the reg save command or by exploiting volume shadow copies.

techniques.name: NTDS
techniques.use: APT41 used ntdsutil to obtain a copy of the victim environment ntds.dit file.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: APT41 has uploaded files and data from a compromised host.

techniques.name: Fallback Channels
techniques.use: APT41 used the Steam community page as a fallback mechanism for C2.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: APT41 queried registry values to determine items such as configured RDP ports and network configurations.

techniques.name: Rootkit
techniques.use: Winnti Group used a rootkit to modify typical server functionality.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: APT41 collected MAC addresses from victim machines.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: APT41 used RDP for lateral movement.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: APT41 has transferred implant files using Windows Admin Shares.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.use: APT41 used VMProtected binaries in multiple intrusions.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: APT41 uses packers such as Themida to obfuscate malicious files.

techniques.name: Data Transfer Size Limits
techniques.use: APT41 transfers post-exploitation files dividing the payload into fixed-size chunks to evade detection.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: APT41 has executed whoami commands, including using the WMIEXEC utility to execute this on remote machines.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: APT41 has created services to appear as benign system tools.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: APT41 attempted to masquerade their files as popular anti-virus software.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 used its Cloudflare services C2 channels for data exfiltration.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: Suckfly the victim's internal network for hosts with ports 8080, 5900, and 40 open.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: APT41 used WMI in several ways, including for execution of commands via WMIEXEC as well as for persistence via PowerSploit.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 exfiltrated victim data via DNS lookups by encoding and prepending it as subdomains to the attacker-controlled domain.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: APT41 has enumerated IP addresses of network resources and used the netstat command as part of network reconnaissance. The group has also used a malware variant, HIGHNOON, to enumerate active RDP sessions.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: APT41 used a compromised account to create a scheduled task on a system.

techniques.name: Process Injection
techniques.use: APT41 malware TIDYELF loaded the main WINTERLOVE component by injecting it into the iexplore.exe process.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: APT41 used a keylogger called GEARSHIFT on a target system.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.use: Winnti Group looked for a specific process running on infected servers.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: APT41 leveraged PowerShell to deploy malware families in victims’ environments.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Several tools used by Suckfly have been command-line driven.

techniques.name: Unix Shell
techniques.use: APT41 executed file /bin/pwd in activity exploiting CVE-2019-19781 against Citrix devices.

techniques.name: JavaScript
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 deployed JScript web shells on compromised systems.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 abused named pipe impersonation for privilege escalation.

techniques.name: Permission Groups Discovery
techniques.use: APT41 used net group commands to enumerate various Windows user groups and permissions.

techniques.name: Clear Windows Event Logs
techniques.use: APT41 attempted to remove evidence of some of its activity by clearing Windows security and system events.

techniques.name: Clear Command History
techniques.use: APT41 attempted to remove evidence of some of its activity by deleting Bash histories.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: APT41 deleted files from the system.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: APT41 used HTTP to download payloads for CVE-2019-19781 and CVE-2020-10189 exploits.

techniques.name: File Transfer Protocols
techniques.use: APT41 used exploit payloads that initiate download via ftp.

techniques.name: DNS
techniques.use: APT41 used DNS for C2 communications.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 copied the local SAM and SYSTEM Registry hives to a staging directory.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: Suckfly used legitimate account credentials that they dumped to navigate the internal victim network as though they were the legitimate account owner.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: APT41 uses multiple built-in commands such as systeminfo and net config Workstation to enumerate victim system basic configuration information.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: Winnti Group has used a program named ff.exe to search for specific documents on compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: APT41 used built-in net commands to enumerate local administrator groups.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: APT41 used built-in net commands to enumerate domain administrator users.

techniques.name: Proxy
techniques.use: APT41 used a tool called CLASSFON to covertly proxy network communications.

techniques.name: Account Manipulation
techniques.use: APT41 has added user accounts to the User and Admin groups.

techniques.name: Dead Drop Resolver
techniques.use: APT41 used legitimate websites for C2 through dead drop resolvers (DDR), including GitHub, Pastebin, and Microsoft TechNet.

techniques.name: Multi-Stage Channels
techniques.use: APT41 used the storescyncsvc.dll BEACON backdoor to download a secondary backdoor.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Winnti Group has downloaded an auxiliary program named ff.exe to infected machines.

techniques.name: Password Cracking
techniques.use: APT41 performed password brute-force attacks on the local admin account.

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: APT41 used a malware variant called GOODLUCK to modify the registry in order to steal credentials.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: APT41 compromised an online billing/payment service using VPN access between a third-party service provider and the targeted payment service.

techniques.name: Access Token Manipulation
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 used a ConfuserEx obfuscated BADPOTATO exploit to abuse named-pipe impersonation for local NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM privilege escalation.

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: APT41 used the net share command as part of network reconnaissance.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: APT41 has created user accounts.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 used the DUSTPAN loader to decrypt embedded payloads.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.use: APT41 exploited CVE-2020-10189 against Zoho ManageEngine Desktop Central through unsafe deserialization, and CVE-2019-19781 to compromise Citrix Application Delivery Controllers (ADC) and gateway devices.

techniques.name: Compromise Software Supply Chain
techniques.use: APT41 gained access to production environments where they could inject malicious code into legitimate, signed files and widely distribute them to end users.

techniques.name: BITS Jobs
techniques.use: APT41 used BITSAdmin to download and install payloads.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: APT41 leveraged the follow exploits in their operations: CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2015-1641, CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2019-3396.

techniques.name: Code Repositories
techniques.use: APT41 cloned victim user Git repositories during intrusions.

techniques.name: Compiled HTML File
techniques.use: APT41 used compiled HTML (.chm) files for targeting.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: APT41 has used rundll32.exe to execute a loader.

techniques.name: Environmental Keying
techniques.use: APT41 has encrypted payloads using the Data Protection API (DPAPI), which relies on keys tied to specific user accounts on specific machines. APT41 has also environmentally keyed second stage malware with an RC5 key derived in part from the infected system's volume serial number.

techniques.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
techniques.use: APT41 used a ransomware called Encryptor RaaS to encrypt files on the targeted systems and provide a ransom note to the user.

techniques.name: Resource Hijacking
techniques.use: APT41 deployed a Monero cryptocurrency mining tool in a victim’s environment.

techniques.name: Web Shell
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 deployed JScript web shells through the creation of malicious ViewState objects.

techniques.name: Bootkit
techniques.use: APT41 deployed Master Boot Record bootkits on Windows systems to hide their malware and maintain persistence on victim systems.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: APT41 modified legitimate Windows services to install malware backdoors.

techniques.name: Accessibility Features
techniques.use: APT41 leveraged sticky keys to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: APT41 created and modified startup files for persistence.

techniques.name: Pass the Hash
techniques.use: APT41 uses tools such as Mimikatz to enable lateral movement via captured password hashes.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: Winnti Group used stolen certificates to sign its malware.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: APT41 used BrowserGhost, a tool designed to obtain credentials from browsers, to retrieve information from password stores.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: APT41 created a RAR archive of targeted files for exfiltration.

techniques.name: Archive via Custom Method
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 hex-encoded PII data prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Indicator Blocking
techniques.use: APT41 developed a custom injector that enables an Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) bypass, making malicious processes invisible to Windows logging.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: APT41 sent spearphishing emails with attachments such as compiled HTML (.chm) files to initially compromise their victims.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Web Service
techniques.use: During C0017, APT41 used Cloudflare services for data exfiltration.

techniques.name: Domain Generation Algorithms
techniques.use: APT41 has used DGAs to change their C2 servers monthly.

techniques.name: Service Execution
techniques.use: APT41 used svchost.exe and Net to execute a system service installed to launch a Cobalt Strike BEACON loader.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.use: APT41 uses remote shares to move and remotely execute payloads during lateral movemement.

techniques.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
techniques.use: APT41 has used search order hijacking to execute malicious payloads, such as Winnti RAT.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: APT41 used legitimate executables to perform DLL side-loading of their malware.

techniques.name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
techniques.use: APT41 has configured payloads to load via LD_PRELOAD.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: Winnti Group has registered domains for C2 that mimicked sites of their intended targets.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: APT41 has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz, pwdump, PowerSploit, and Windows Credential Editor.

techniques.name: Credentials
techniques.use: To support initial access, APT41 gained access to databases with information about existing accounts as well as plaintext and hashed passwords.

techniques.name: Employee Names
techniques.use: To support initial access, APT41 gained access to databases with information about existing accounts and lists of employees.

techniques.name: Vulnerability Scanning
techniques.use: APT41 used the Acunetix SQL injection vulnerability scanner in target reconnaissance operations, as well as the JexBoss tool to identify vulnerabilities in Java applications.

techniques.name: Wordlist Scanning
techniques.use: APT41 leverages various tools and frameworks to brute-force directories on web servers.

techniques.name: Scan Databases
techniques.use: APT41 uses the Chinese website fofa.su, similar to the Shodan scanning service, for passive scanning of victims.

name: Winter Vivern
description:
(SentinelLabs) The Winter Vivern Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) is a noteworthy yet relatively underreported group that operates with pro-Russian objectives. DomainTools initially publicized the group in early 2021, naming it based on an initial command-and-control beacon URL string “wintervivern,” which is no longer in use. Subsequently, Lab52 shared additional analysis several months later, identifying new activity associated with Winter Vivern.

The group has avoided public disclosure since then, until recent attacks targeting Ukraine. A part of a Winter Vivern campaign was reported in recent weeks by the Polish CBZC, and then the Ukraine CERT as UAC-0114. In this activity, CERT-UA and the CBZC collaborated on the release of private technical details which assisted in our research to identify a wider set of activity on the threat actor, in addition to new victims and previously unknown specific technical details. Overall, we find that the Winter Vivern APT is a resource-limited but highly creative group that shows restraint in the scope of their attacks. Our analysis indicates that Winter Vivern activity aligns closely with global objectives that support the interests of Belarus and Russia’s governments.

Also see MoustachedBouncer.

name: Wizard Spider
description: Wizard Spider is a Russia-based financially motivated threat group originally known for the creation and deployment of TrickBot since at least 2016. Wizard Spider possesses a diverse aresenal of tools and has conducted ransomware campaigns against a variety of organizations, ranging from major corporations to hospitals.

techniques.name: LSASS Memory
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has dumped the lsass.exe memory to harvest credentials with the use of open-source tool LaZagne.

techniques.name: Security Account Manager
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has acquired credentials from the SAM/SECURITY registry hives.

techniques.name: NTDS
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has gained access to credentials via exported copies of the ntds.dit Active Directory database. Wizard Spider has also created a volume shadow copy and used a batch script file to collect NTDS.dit with the use of the Windows utility, ntdsutil.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has collected data from a compromised host prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used ipconfig to identify the network configuration of a victim machine. Wizard Spider has also used the PowerShell cmdlet Get-ADComputer to collect IP address data from Active Directory.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used networkdll for network discovery and psfin specifically for financial and point of sale indicators. Wizard Spider has also used AdFind, nltest/dclist, and PowerShell script Get-DataInfo.ps1 to enumerate domain computers, including the domain controller.

techniques.name: Remote Services
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used the WebDAV protocol to execute Ryuk payloads hosted on network file shares.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used RDP for lateral movement and to deploy ransomware interactively.

techniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used SMB to drop Cobalt Strike Beacon on a domain controller for lateral movement.

techniques.name: Windows Remote Management
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used Window Remote Management to move laterally through a victim network.

techniques.name: Command Obfuscation
techniques.use: Wizard Spider used Base64 encoding to obfuscate an Empire service and PowerShell commands.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used "whoami"to identify the local user and their privileges.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used scheduled tasks to install TrickBot, using task names to appear legitimate such as WinDotNet, GoogleTask, or Sysnetsf.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has exfiltrated domain credentials and network enumeration information over command and control (C2) channels.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used WMI and LDAP queries for network discovery and to move laterally. Wizard Spider has also used batch scripts to leverage WMIC to deploy ransomware.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has exfiltrated victim information using FTP.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for TrickBot and other malware.

techniques.name: Process Injection
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used process injection to execute payloads to escalate privileges.

techniques.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has injected malicious DLLs into memory with read, write, and execute permissions.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used macros to execute PowerShell scripts to download malware on victim's machines.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used cmd.exe to execute commands on a victim's machine.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used file deletion to remove some modules and configurations from an infected host after use.

techniques.name: Web Protocols
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used HTTP for network communications.

techniques.name: Data Staged
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has collected and staged credentials and network enumeration information, using the networkdll and psfin TrickBot modules.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has staged ZIP files in local directories such as, C:\PerfLogs\1\ and C:\User\1\ prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used valid credentials for privileged accounts with the goal of accessing domain controllers.

techniques.name: Domain Accounts
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used administrative accounts, including Domain Admin, to move laterally within a victim network.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used Systeminfo and similar commands to acquire detailed configuration information of a victim's machine. Wizard Spider has also utilized the PowerShell cmdlet Get-ADComputer to collect DNS hostnames, last logon dates, and operating system information from Active Directory.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has identified domain admins through the use of net group "Domain admins"/DOMAIN. Wizard Spider has also leveraged the PowerShell cmdlet Get-ADComputer to collect account names from Active Directory data.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Wizard Spider can transfer malicious payloads such as ransomware to compromised machines.

techniques.name: Modify Registry
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has modified the Registry key HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest by setting the UseLogonCredential registry value to 1 in order to force credentials to be stored in clear text in memory. Wizard Spider has also modified the WDigest registry key to allow plaintext credentials to be cached in memory.

techniques.name: External Remote Services
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has accessed victim networks by using stolen credentials to access the corporate VPN infrastructure.

techniques.name: Network Share Discovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used the "net view"command to locate mapped network shares.

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has created local administrator accounts to maintain persistence in compromised networks.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has created and used new accounts within a victim's Active Directory environment to maintain persistence.

techniques.name: BITS Jobs
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used batch scripts that utilizes WMIC to execute a BITSAdmin transfer of a ransomware payload to each compromised machine.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has lured victims into clicking a malicious link delivered through spearphishing.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has lured victims to execute malware with spearphishing attachments containing macros to download either Emotet, Bokbot, TrickBot, or Bazar.

techniques.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has exploited or attempted to exploit Zerologon (CVE-2020-1472) and EternalBlue (MS17-010) vulnerabilities.

techniques.name: Rundll32
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has utilized rundll32.exe to deploy ransomware commands with the use of WebDAV.

techniques.name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used the icacls command to modify access control to backup servers, providing them with full control of all the system folders.

techniques.name: Service Stop
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used taskkill.exe and net.exe to stop backup, catalog, cloud, and other services prior to network encryption.

techniques.name: Inhibit System Recovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used WMIC and vssadmin to manually delete volume shadow copies. Wizard Spider has also used Conti ransomware to delete volume shadow copies automatically with the use of vssadmin.

techniques.name: Software Discovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has utilized the PowerShell script Get-DataInfo.ps1 to collect installed backup software information from a compromised machine.

techniques.name: Security Software Discovery
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used WMI to identify anti-virus products installed on a victim's machine.

techniques.name: Windows Service
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has installed TrickBot as a service named ControlServiceA in order to establish persistence.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has established persistence via the Registry key HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run and a shortcut within the startup folder.

techniques.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has established persistence using Userinit by adding the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.

techniques.name: Pass the Hash
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used the Invoke-SMBExec PowerShell cmdlet to execute the pass-the-hash technique and utilized stolen password hashes to move laterally.

techniques.name: Group Policy Preferences
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used PowerShell cmdlets Get-GPPPassword and Find-GPOPassword to find unsecured credentials in a compromised network group policy.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used Digicert code-signing certificates for some of its malware.

techniques.name: Windows Credential Manager
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used PowerShell cmdlet Invoke-WCMDump to enumerate Windows credentials in the Credential Manager in a compromised network.

techniques.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used the Invoke-Inveigh PowerShell cmdlets, likely for name service poisoning.

techniques.name: Kerberoasting
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used Rubeus, MimiKatz Kerberos module, and the Invoke-Kerberoast cmdlet to steal AES hashes.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has archived data into ZIP files on compromised machines.

techniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has shut down or uninstalled security applications on victim systems that might prevent ransomware from executing.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used spearphishing attachments to deliver Microsoft documents containing macros or PDFs containing malicious links to download either Emotet, Bokbot, TrickBot, or Bazar.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has sent phishing emails containing a link to an actor-controlled Google Drive document or other free online file hosting services.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has exfiltrated stolen victim data to various cloud storage providers.

techniques.name: Service Execution
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used services.exe to execute scripts and executables during lateral movement within a victim's network. Wizard Spider has also used batch scripts that leverage PsExec to execute a previously transferred ransomware payload on a victim's network.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has used stolen credentials to copy tools into the %TEMP% directory of domain controllers.

techniques.name: Email Accounts
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has leveraged ProtonMail email addresses in ransom notes when delivering Ryuk ransomware.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has utilized tools such as Empire, Cobalt Strike, Cobalt Strike, Rubeus, AdFind, BloodHound, Metasploit, Advanced IP Scanner, Nirsoft PingInfoView, and SoftPerfect Network Scanner for targeting efforts.

techniques.name: Code Signing Certificates
techniques.use: Wizard Spider has obtained code signing certificates signed by DigiCert, GlobalSign, and COMOOD for malware payloads.

name: WizardOpium
description: The elevation of privilege exploit used in Operation WizardOpium was built to support Windows 7, Windows 10 build 10240 and Windows 10 build 14393. It’s also important to note that Google Chrome has a special security feature called Win32k lockdown. This security feature eliminates the whole win32k attack surface by disabling access to win32k syscalls from inside Chrome processes. Unfortunately, Win32k lockdown is only supported on machines running Windows 10. So, it’s fair to assume that Operation WizardOpium targeted users running Windows 7.

name: Worok
description:
(ESET) ESET researchers recently found targeted attacks that used undocumented tools against various high-profile companies and local governments mostly in Asia. These attacks were conducted by a previously unknown espionage group that we have named Worok and that has been active since at least 2020. Worok’s toolset includes a C++ loader CLRLoad, a PowerShell backdoor PowHeartBeat, and a C# loader PNGLoad that uses steganography to extract hidden malicious payloads from PNG files.

Activity times and toolset indicate possible ties with TA428, but we make this assessment with low confidence.

name: XDSpy
description:
(ESET) Rare is the APT group that goes largely undetected for nine years, but XDSpy is just that; a previously undocumented espionage group that has been active since 2011. It has attracted very little public attention, with the exception of an advisory from the Belarusian CERT in February 2020. In the interim, the group compromised many government agencies and private companies in Eastern Europe and the Balkans.

In this paper, we present our analysis of this nine-year-long espionage campaign, active since 2011, but which apparently went dark in February 2020.

With its primary purpose seemingly being cyber espionage, this group stole documents and other sensitive files, such as victims’ mailboxes. These outcomes were achieved through the use of the XDSpy malware ecosystem, composed of at least seven components: XDDown, XDRecon, XDList, XDMonitor, XDUpload, XDLoc and XDPass. As our research has not uncovered links with any previously known APT groups, we have attributed this malware toolset to a previously unknown group.

name: XakNet
description: XakNet is a self-proclaimed hacktivist group that has targeted Ukraine. They claim to be comprised of Russian patriotic volunteers and have conducted various threat activities, including DDoS attacks, compromises, data leaks, and website defacements. They coordinate their operations with other hacktivist groups and have connections to APT28, a cyber espionage group sponsored by the GRU.

name: Xcatze
description: Cloud security company Lacework says it discovered a threat actor group named Xcatze that uses a Python named AndroxGh0st to take over AWS servers and send out massive email spam campaigns. Lacework says the malware operates by scanning web apps written in the Laravel PHP framework for exposed configuration files to identify and steal server credentials. Researchers said AndroxGh0st specifically searches for AWS, SendGrid, and Twilio credentials, which it uses to take control of email servers and accounts and send out the spam campaigns.

name: Xiaoqiying
description: Xiaoqiying is a primarily Chinese-speaking threat group that is most well known for conducting website defacement and data exfiltration attacks on more than a dozen South Korean research and academic institutions in late-January 2023. Research from Recorded Futures Insikt Group has found that the groups affiliated threat actors have signaled a new round of cyberattacks against organizations in Japan and Taiwan. Although it shows no clear ties to the Chinese government, Xiaoqiying is staunchly pro-China and vows to target NATO countries as well as any country or region that is deemed hostile to China.

name: Yanbian Gang
description: RiskIQ characterizes the Yanbian Gang as a group that targeted South Korean Android mobile banking customers since 2013 with malicious Android apps purporting to be from major banks, namely Shinhan Savings Bank, Saemaul Geumgo, Shinhan Finance, KB Kookmin Bank, and NH Savings Bank.

name: YoroTrooper
description:
(Talos) Cisco Talos has identified a new threat actor, which we are naming “YoroTrooper,” that has been running several successful espionage campaigns since at least June 2022.

YoroTrooper’s main targets are government or energy organizations in Azerbaijan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and other Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), based on our analysis. We also observed YoroTrooper compromise accounts from at least two international organizations: a critical European Union (EU) health care agency and the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO). Successful compromises also included Embassies of European countries including Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan. We assess the actor also likely targets other organizations across Europe and Turkish (Türkiye) government agencies.

Information stolen from successful compromises include credentials from multiple applications, browser histories & cookies, system information and screenshots.

name: ZIRCONIUM
description: ZIRCONIUM is a threat group operating out of China, active since at least 2017, that has targeted individuals associated with the 2020 US presidential election and prominent leaders in the international affairs community.

techniques.name: Query Registry
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to query the Registry for proxy settings.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to enumerate proxy settings in the target environment.

techniques.name: Software Packing
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used multi-stage packers for exploit code.

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to capture the username on a compromised host in order to register it with C2.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has spoofed legitimate applications in phishing lures and changed file extensions to conceal installation of malware.

techniques.name: Masquerade Task or Service
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has created a run key named Dropbox Update Setup to mask a persistence mechanism for a malicious binary.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has exfiltrated files via the Dropbox API C2.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to open a Windows Command Shell on a remote host.

techniques.name: Python
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used Python-based implants to interact with compromised hosts.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has exploited CVE-2017-0005 for local privilege escalation.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to capture the processor architecture of a compromised host in order to register it with C2.

techniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used Dropbox for C2 allowing upload and download of files as well as execution of arbitrary commands.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used tools to download malicious files to compromised hosts.

techniques.name: System Time Discovery
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to capture the time on a compromised host in order to register it with C2.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used the AES256 algorithm with a SHA1 derived key to decrypt exploit code.

techniques.name: Malicious Link
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used malicious links in e-mails to lure victims into downloading malware.

techniques.name: Msiexec
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used the msiexec.exe command-line utility to download and execute malicious MSI files.

techniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has created a Registry Run key named Dropbox Update Setup to establish persistence for a malicious Python binary.

techniques.name: Credentials from Web Browsers
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used a tool to steal credentials from installed web browsers including Microsoft Internet Explorer and Google Chrome.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used malicious links in e-mails to deliver malware.

techniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has exfiltrated stolen data to Dropbox.

techniques.name: Symmetric Cryptography
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used AES encrypted communications in C2.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has purchased domains for use in targeted campaigns.

techniques.name: Web Services
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used GitHub to host malware linked in spearphishing e-mails.

techniques.name: Phishing for Information
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM targeted presidential campaign staffers with credential phishing e-mails.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Link
techniques.use: ZIRCONIUM has used web beacons in e-mails to track hits to attacker-controlled URL's.

name: ZOMBIE SPIDER
description: On April 7, 2017, Pytor Levashov — who predominantly used the alias Severa or Peter Severa and whom Falcon Intelligence tracks as ZOMBIE SPIDER — was arrested in an international law enforcement operation led by the FBI. ZOMBIE SPIDER’s specialty was large-scale spam distribution, a fundamental component of cybercrime operations. Levashov was the primary threat actor behind a botnet known as Kelihos and its predecessors, Waledac and Storm. In addition to Levashov’s arrest, there was a technical operation conducted by Falcon Intelligence to seize control of the Kelihos botnet.

name: Zarya
description: Zarya is a pro-Russian hacktivist group that emerged in March 2022. Initially operating as a special forces unit under the command of Killnet, Zarya has since become an independent entity. The group is primarily known for engaging in Denial-of-Service attacks, website defacement campaigns, and data leaks. Zarya targets government agencies, service providers, critical infrastructure, and civil service employees, both domestically and internationally.

name: ZeroSevenGroup
description: ZeroSevenGroup is a threat actor that claims to have breached a U.S. branch of Toyota, stealing 240GB of sensitive data, including employee and customer information, contracts, and financial details. They have also allegedly gained full network access to critical Israeli infrastructure, with access to 80TB of sensitive data across various sectors. The group has threatened to use the stolen data for malicious activities, including ransomware attacks. Their operations involve exploiting vulnerabilities, as indicated by their reference to manipulating memory through buffer overflow techniques.

name: ZooPark
description:
(Kaspersky) ZooPark is a cyberespionage operation that has been focusing on Middle Eastern targets since at least June 2015. The threat actors behind ZooPark infect Android devices using several generations of malware we label from v1-v4, with v4 being the most recent version deployed in 2017.

The preferred infection vector for ZooPark is waterhole attacks. We found several news websites that have been hacked by the attackers to redirect visitors to a downloading site that serves malicious APKs. Some of the themes observed in campaign include “Kurdistan referendum”, “TelegramGroups” and “Alnaharegypt news”, among others.

Target profile has evolved during the last years of campaign, focusing on victims in Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, Lebanon and Iran.

name: admin@338
description: admin@338 is a China-based cyber threat group. It has previously used newsworthy events as lures to deliver malware and has primarily targeted organizations involved in financial, economic, and trade policy, typically using publicly available RATs such as PoisonIvy, as well as some non-public backdoors.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about services: net start >> %temp%\download

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following command after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to acquire information about local networks: ipconfig /all >> %temp%\download

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following command to rename one of their tools to a benign file name: ren "%temp%\upload"audiodg.exe

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to display network connections: netstat -ano >> %temp%\download

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: Following exploitation with LOWBALL malware, admin@338 actors created a file containing a list of commands to be executed on the compromised computer.

techniques.name: Local Groups
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to list local groups: net localgroup administrator >> %temp%\download

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about the OS: ver >> %temp%\download systeminfo >> %temp%\download

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about files and directories: dir c:\ >> %temp%\download dir "c:\Documents and Settings">> %temp%\download dir "c:\Program Files\">> %temp%\download dir d:\ >> %temp%\download

techniques.name: Local Account
techniques.use: admin@338 actors used the following commands following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to enumerate user accounts: net user >> %temp%\download net user /domain >> %temp%\download

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.use: admin@338 has exploited client software vulnerabilities for execution, such as Microsoft Word CVE-2012-0158.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: admin@338 has attempted to get victims to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: admin@338 has sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.

name: leetMX
description:
(ClearSky) leetMX is a widespread cyber-attack campaign originating from Mexico and focused on targets in Mexico, El Salvador, and other countries in Latin America, such as Guatemala, Argentina and Costa Rica. It has been operating since November 2016 at least. We are uncertain of its objectives but estimate it is criminally motivated.

leetMX infrastructure includes 27 hosts and domains used for malware delivery or for command and control.  Hundreds of malware samples have been used, most are Remote Access Trojans and keyloggers.

Interestingly, the attackers camouflage one of their delivery domains by redirecting visitors to El Universal, a major Mexican newspaper.

name: luoxk
description: Luoxk is a malware campaign targeting web servers throughout Asia, Europe and North America.

name: menuPass
description: menuPass is a threat group that has been active since at least 2006. Individual members of menuPass are known to have acted in association with the Chinese Ministry of State Security's (MSS) Tianjin State Security Bureau and worked for the Huaying Haitai Science and Technology Development Company.menuPass has targeted healthcare, defense, aerospace, finance, maritime, biotechnology, energy, and government sectors globally, with an emphasis on Japanese organizations. In 2016 and 2017, the group is known to have targeted managed IT service providers (MSPs), manufacturing and mining companies, and a university.
sponsoredBy: State-sponsored, Tianjin bureau of the Chinese Ministry of State Security, Huaying Haitai

techniques.name: Security Account Manager
techniques.use: menuPass has used a modified version of pentesting tools wmiexec.vbs and secretsdump.py to dump credentials.

techniques.name: NTDS
techniques.use: menuPass has used Ntdsutil to dump credentials.

techniques.name: LSA Secrets
techniques.use: menuPass has used a modified version of pentesting tools wmiexec.vbs and secretsdump.py to dump credentials.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.use: menuPass has collected various files from the compromised computers.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.use: menuPass has used several tools to scan for open NetBIOS nameservers and enumerate NetBIOS sessions.

techniques.name: Remote System Discovery
techniques.use: menuPass uses scripts to enumerate IP ranges on the victim network. menuPass has also issued the command net view /domain to a PlugX implant to gather information about remote systems on the network.

techniques.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.use: menuPass has used RDP connections to move across the victim network.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.use: menuPass has used Putty Secure Copy Client (PSCP) to transfer data.
menuPass has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.use: menuPass has used esentutl to change file extensions to their true type that were masquerading as .txt files.

techniques.name: Rename System Utilities
techniques.use: menuPass has renamed certutil and moved it to a different location on the system to avoid detection based on use of the tool.

techniques.name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
techniques.use: menuPass has been seen changing malicious files to appear legitimate.

techniques.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
techniques.use: menuPass has collected data from remote systems by mounting network shares with net use and using Robocopy to transfer data.

techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.use: menuPass has used tcping.exe, similar to Ping, to probe port status on systems of interest.

techniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques.use: menuPass has used a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs, which logs into a remote machine using WMI.

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.use: menuPass has used net use to conduct connectivity checks to machines.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task
techniques.use: menuPass has used a script (atexec.py) to execute a command on a target machine via Task Scheduler.

techniques.name: Process Hollowing
techniques.use: menuPass has used process hollowing in iexplore.exe to load the RedLeaves implant.

techniques.name: Keylogging
techniques.use: menuPass has used key loggers to steal usernames and passwords.

techniques.name: PowerShell
techniques.use: menuPass uses PowerSploit to inject shellcode into PowerShell.

techniques.name: Windows Command Shell
techniques.use: menuPass executes commands using a command-line interface and reverse shell. The group has used a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs to execute commands.

techniques.name: Clear Command History
techniques.use: menuPass has used Wevtutil to remove PowerShell execution logs.

techniques.name: File Deletion
techniques.use: A menuPass macro deletes files after it has decoded and decompressed them.

techniques.name: Local Data Staging
techniques.use: menuPass stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin.

techniques.name: Remote Data Staging
techniques.use: menuPass has staged data on remote MSP systems or other victim networks prior to exfiltration.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.use: menuPass has used valid accounts including shared between Managed Service Providers and clients to move between the two environments.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.use: menuPass has searched compromised systems for folders of interest including those related to HR, audit and expense, and meeting memos.

techniques.name: Domain Account
techniques.use: menuPass has used the Microsoft administration tool csvde.exe to export Active Directory data.

techniques.name: External Proxy
techniques.use: menuPass has used a global service provider's IP as a proxy for C2 traffic from a victim.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.use: menuPass has installed updates and new malware on victims.

techniques.name: Native API
techniques.use: menuPass has used native APIs including GetModuleFileName, lstrcat, CreateFile, and ReadFile.

techniques.name: Automated Collection
techniques.use: menuPass has used the Csvde tool to collect Active Directory files and data.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.use: menuPass has used certutil in a macro to decode base64-encoded content contained in a dropper document attached to an email. The group has also used certutil -decode to decode files on the victim’s machine when dropping UPPERCUT.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.use: menuPass has leveraged vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure VPNs to hijack sessions.

techniques.name: Trusted Relationship
techniques.use: menuPass has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.

techniques.name: Malicious File
techniques.use: menuPass has attempted to get victims to open malicious files such as Windows Shortcuts (.lnk) and/or Microsoft Office documents, sent via email as part of spearphishing campaigns.

techniques.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
techniques.use: menuPass has used tools to exploit the ZeroLogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472).

techniques.name: InstallUtil
techniques.use: menuPass has used InstallUtil.exe to execute malicious software.

techniques.name: Code Signing
techniques.use: menuPass has resized and added data to the certificate table to enable the signing of modified files with legitimate signatures.

techniques.name: Archive Collected Data
techniques.use: menuPass has encrypted files and information before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Archive via Utility
techniques.use: menuPass has compressed files before exfiltration using TAR and RAR.

techniques.name: Spearphishing Attachment
techniques.use: menuPass has sent malicious Office documents via email as part of spearphishing campaigns as well as executables disguised as documents.

techniques.name: Fast Flux DNS
techniques.use: menuPass has used dynamic DNS service providers to host malicious domains.

techniques.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
techniques.use: menuPass has used DLL search order hijacking.

techniques.name: DLL Side-Loading
techniques.use: menuPass has used DLL side-loading to launch versions of Mimikatz and PwDump6 as well as UPPERCUT.

techniques.name: Domains
techniques.use: menuPass has registered malicious domains for use in intrusion campaigns.

techniques.name: Tool
techniques.use: menuPass has used and modified open-source tools like Impacket, Mimikatz, and pwdump.

name: xHunt
description:
(Palo Alto) Between May and June 2019, Unit 42 observed previously unknown tools used in the targeting of transportation and shipping organizations based in Kuwait.

The first known attack in this campaign targeted a Kuwait transportation and shipping company in which the actors installed a backdoor tool named Hisoka. Several custom tools were later downloaded to the system in order to carry out post-exploitation activities. All of these tools appear to have been created by the same developer. We were able to collect several variations of these tools including one dating back to July 2018.

The developer of the collected tools used character names from the anime series Hunter x Hunter, which is the basis for the campaign name “xHunt.” The names of the tools collected include backdoor tools Sakabota, Hisoka, Netero and Killua. These tools not only use HTTP for their command and control (C2) channels, but certain variants of these tools use DNS tunneling or emails to communicate with their C2 as well. While DNS tunneling as a C2 channel is fairly common, the specific method in which this group used email to facilitate C2 communications has not been observed by Unit 42 in quite some time. This method uses Exchange Web Services (EWS) and stolen credentials to create email “drafts” to communicate between the actor and the tool. In addition to the aforementioned backdoor tools, we also observed tools referred to as Gon and EYE, which provide the backdoor access and the ability to carry out post-exploitation activities.
